—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer the Minister to Mr Beazley's comments yesterday regarding the Prime Minister's proposed youth summit to be held next month when he said he was not absolutely certain how the summit would operate or whether the teenage jobless would be represented, and not sure whether the summit would be a public forum, despite the fact that the Prime Minister plans to announce details of that summit tomorrow. Has the Minister or Mr Beazley been consulted on the Prime Minister's plans for a youth summit next month or is Mr Beazley's lack of knowledge on Government policy just another example, as today's Australian Financial Review says, of a government reduced to the frenetic decision making of one man, the Prime Minister, Mr Keating?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The summit was announced by the Prime Minister on 3 June at the `Lighten the Load' forum on youth unemployment. It has received, I might say, a very positive response from many quarters, the youth sector in particular. The Australian of the Year, Archbishop Hollingworth, gave it a good rap and social workers and others have also praised the initiative. Young people, business, unions, community groups and other leaders in the field will be invited to the summit.

PARA.TAB: Senator Campbell asks whether we have been consulted. The summit has been under consideration within the Government but, as Senator Campbell knows, it is not a fair question to ask a Minister what happens within the processes of Cabinet or of Cabinet committees. Those matters are, of course, fairly confidential; so I do not propose, should Senator Campbell's incubating supplementary question be, `What was discussed?', to go into that matter. These matters have been considered.

The Government does have a number of proposals that it wishes to canvass for the youth summit. We are keen to hear what key groups in the community have to say about long term solutions for youth unemployment. In particular, we are interested in hearing from business about what role it can play in training young people for new jobs and jobs that will come out of the restructuring we have undertaken in the economy when industrial growth takes a stronger hold. We will be concentrating on positive things and constructive measures in dealing with youth unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Contrary to the Minister's implication about the incubation of a supplementary question, my concern is about the lack of incubation of policy on the side of the Government. The Prime Minister seems to be dropping unincubated eggs on the run. My supplementary question relates to Mr Beazley's seemingly total lack of knowledge on how this youth jobless summit will take place. As Mr Beazley is the Minister who is directly responsible for teenage unemployment, the question really is: was Mr Beazley included in talks with the Prime Minister and the ACTU last Friday regarding the youth summit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have answered the last part of the supplementary question but the first part of the original question as it is now rephrased. I am somewhat taken by surprise by Senator Campbell's statements that he is interested in improving the lot of young people in this country. I am taken by surprise because that marks him down as a Liberal who does not support the Fightback package. The consumption tax package, we all know, involves kicking people off the dole after nine months. That is hardly a constructive measure to deal with people who are in the hardship of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: The consumption tax package, we all know, involves the abolition of the CES and the youth access centres. We would have to say that is hardly the mark of a party interested in trying to find placement or provide assistance for those people put in the unfortunate position of being unemployed.

We also know that under the Fightback package—the consumption tax package as it is more accurately called—TAFE is to be downgraded. The Opposition will provide $75m in grants to TAFE. In the One Nation statement we provide $720m. So let us mark on the scales of fairness the Opposition's $75m and our $720m. Of course, the Opposition would abolish the student homeless allowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: my supplementary question was directly related to Mr Beazley's inclusion in talks with the Prime Minister; it had nothing to do with the Fightback package. So I would ask you to draw the Minister's attention to the relevance of his answer.
—I ask the Minister to be relevant.

—Thank you, Mr President. I am replying to that part of Senator Campbell's question that talked about his concern for youth unemployment. I thought there was a very logical connection between the abolition of the student homeless allowance as provided for in Fightback and this question of concern. I should have thought that if Senator Campbell's concern was genuine he might oppose that and other elements of the Fightback package.

—Has the Minister for Industrial Relations seen the Housing Industry Association's advertisement in relation to independent contractors which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday? Is the HIA telling the truth in this advertisement? Who are the other industry organisations referred to in the advertisement? I ask the last part of the question with a straight face: does the Minister suggest people should donate to this campaign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some ironies in politics. Were this not a serious matter, one could indulge oneself in the sense of irony that arises when the Housing Industry Association advertises in New South Wales against the independent contractors legislation of the Government when our legislation is in fact a more narrowly drawn version of the existing Greiner Government legislation.

PARA.TAB: Where, for example, are the HIA's advertisements calling on the Greiner Government to do what it more generously does for independent contractors than that which we do? Where is it being fair and even-handed about the so-called and alleged injustice of our legislation when it simply concentrates on us and says nothing whatsoever about where we drew inspiration in the first place—from the Greiner Government legislation on the statute book in New South Wales now for at least a decade?

There is nothing that approaches truth in the Housing Industry Association advertisement. Perhaps the more startling revelation is that it has established a $5m fund to campaign and is soliciting donations for this $5m fund. I say to all Australians: do not be duped; do not fall for the confidence trick; and do not accept the lies and deceit inherent in the HIA's advertisement and contribute to this fund.

Senator Aulich asks me: who are the other industry groups? The other industry groups are the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Business Council of Australia, the Master Builders Association, the Metal Trades Industry Association and the Chamber of Manufactures. They are the other groups, along with this Government, that are being attacked by the HIA about getting the facts wrong. It could well be—but it would take an extraordinary leap of imagination to believe it—that the rest of the world is wrong and the HIA is right. But one has only to have resort to the black letter of the Bill to see that the HIA is wrong.

In the Melbourne Age today, a letter from Mr John Murray, the Executive Director of the Master Builders Association, was published which makes that point very explicitly. I conclude my answer by quoting from the letter by John Murray. The letter says:

ANSWER.PARA: The Bill now retains only a limited provision allowing the Industrial Relations Commission to review individual harsh and unconscionable contracts at the request of the contractor involved—a provision similar to, but narrower than, those which already exist in NSW, SA and Queensland industrial legislation, and which have been operating for some years without any ill effects.
I emphasise `without any ill-effects'. The letter continues:
that is, the Master Builders Association—
do not believe that these provisions will increase housing costs—

and it would be most unfortunate if cost increases were imposed on the public using this legislation as an excuse. Master Builders-CHAA will certainly be recommending to its members that they do not need to make any allowance for extra costs on the basis of this legislation.

We remain convinced that this legislation is not needed in the building industry, but after legal advice we are convinced that the amendments we secured will spare home owners a price hike such as we had originally feared.
That is the Master Builders-Construction and Housing Association Australia—a reputable organisation—speaking about what the HIA is lying to the Australian community about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to recent speculation that the Government is considering introducing a youth training wage to alleviate massive youth unemployment—a move described yesterday by the New South Wales Young Labor organisation as `a cheap gimmick' which would be inadequate for young people's needs and would create no new jobs. Does the Minister agree with the comments of the New South Wales Young Labor organisation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen what Senator Vanstone alleges are the quotes of the New South Wales Young Labor organisation, but if they are accurately quoted and quoted in context in her question I disagree with them. I disagree with them because of the premise upon which it seems this question is predicated and upon which those remarks appear, given reference to the question, to be based; that is, that the youth training wage we are trying to introduce into Australia has nothing to do in the immediate context with trying to alleviate youth unemployment. That will be an effect of it, but that is not its purpose. Its purpose is to skill the Australian community, particularly young workers, so that they not only can take jobs in the future but also can look forward to careers, given that they become parts of a highly skilled Australian work force able to absorb rapid technological change and be one of the key inputs in making this country world competitive by using a highly skilled base in the Australian community to add to the industry changes that we are making.

PARA.TAB: The key purpose of a youth training wage arises from the Carmichael report into youth and training and, in particular, access to trade training. It is about addressing that particular problem. It is not an unemployment strategy; it is a training and economic strategy related to the skills in the labour market. For these reasons, if the Young Labor organisation did say what Senator Vanstone said it did, I disagree with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister's Government has been in power for eight or nine years. How come it has taken him so long to come to this conclusion in respect of the need for a youth training wage? Further, since the Minister has been talking about it, at least in this place, since the beginning of this session, when will he actually achieve something? How urgent is this problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a quite urgent problem. We have been in power, as Senator Vanstone says, for over nine years. During that time, in real dollar terms we have increased expenditure on education and training by 42 per cent. We have created the equivalent of 17 new universities in Australia and we have doubled the retention rates.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I am not accustomed to raising points of order during Question Time but this matter, where Ministers are asked questions on specific matters and go off on some wild goose chase, has really got out of hand.

PARA.TAB: The supplementary question related to the competence of the Minister's Government in relation to the youth training wage, and in particular to the competence of the Minister himself and the Minister whom he represents. That is what the Minister has been asked about. He has not been asked to make some long ramble about education and every other topic he likes to raise. Mr President, unless you enforce your capacity to make Ministers relevant to the questions that are put to them, it is making a farce of this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I want speak to the point of order. As I heard it, the question also related to the seriousness of the problems facing young people in Australia today, to which this is a perfectly adequate answer and it is in order. This is just another example of the disruption of Question Time by the taking of bogus points of order.
—Order! I listened carefully to the Minister and I thought he was answering the general subject. But I would ask him not to debate other issues.
—Thank you, Mr President. Of course, I will not debate other issues. These issues were introduced in the supplementary question.

PARA.TAB: We have also doubled the high school retention rate. The point is that our approach to the labour market is to concentrate on educational opportunity, skill and training, without its being a precondition that people have to be rich to go to university as the Fightback package or the consumption tax package of the Opposition would require them to be. I conclude by saying that, of course, we are concerned about the level of youth unemployment in the community. We have a comprehensive package of labour market support initiatives to try to deal with it. We have in place the One Nation statement which will lead to economic growth in the economy, which is the complete answer to the whole problem of unemployment. We are not about, as Mr Howard says, creating dead-end jobs and we are not about abolishing the labour market supports so necessary in stringent times like these.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Tariffs and Import Quotas

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of the joint submission made to the Federal Government by the Victorian Premier, Mrs Kirner, and her South Australian counterpart, Mr Bannon, recommending that textiles, clothing and footwear tariffs and import quotas be frozen immediately? Secondly, how much longer does the Minister intend to stand by and ignore the devastating damage caused by the Federal Government's 1991 decision to fast-track textiles, clothing and footwear tariff cuts? Thirdly, is the Minister now prepared to reconsider the Government's lack of support for my motion to establish a Senate select committee of inquiry into tariffs? Will the Minister now support it so that the issue can be fully debated and researched and sound industry policy formulated?

—I have seen some of the press reports of the comments made by the two Premiers. Indeed, I had discussions with Ministers in the Victorian and South Australian governments about some of these issues a week or two ago. Officials have also had discussions about the issues. In terms of Senator Spindler's question, I am aware of the issues.

PARA.TAB: The current concern of the Premiers in those two States arises from the impact of high unemployment. High unemployment is largely a consequence of the recession, although it is said by some to be a consequence of changes in tariff structures. In relation to the employment issue and the impact of the recession, employment in the year to September 1991 in the textiles industry declined by 10 per cent, the clothing industry by 14 per cent and the footwear industry by 19 per cent. That should be compared with declines in employment in other industries, such as 12 per cent in paper and paper products; metal products, 14 per cent; miscellaneous transport equipment, 20 per cent; miscellaneous manufacturing, 15 per cent; and financial services industries, 25 per cent.

The financial services industries are not protected by any tariffs and never have been. The decline in employment in these industries, for a variety of reasons which I do not want or need to go into at this stage, has been much more significant than it has, for example, in the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. This certainly is true in some other areas of what are effectively more straight up and down manufacturing activities. The eye of the storm in relation to this debate has become the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, because they are the industries which have been used to the highest protection and have been used to relying on protection as a solution to their problems.

While I have seen the Premiers' statement on the TCF sector and while I think there are many things that can be done for this sector, I do not agree that one of them is to change the structural adjustment measures which are already in place. The reason for that, simply, is that tariffs as a mechanism of supporting industry are inward looking mechanisms, not outward looking mechanisms. There are plenty of things that I am prepared to look at which might be regarded as outward looking mechanisms and, indeed, I will be making an announcement about this in relation to the textiles, clothing and footwear industries in the not too distant future.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Parliament is sitting?

—I hope so. As far as Senator Spindler's proposed select committee is concerned, for reasons which I have hinted at in my answer to this question, I am not sure that it is a profitable exercise to tie up senators' time with inward looking measures. As I have said here before, it would be a cruel delusion to think that the competitiveness and employment problems of this economy are pre-eminently related to tariffs. It would be a cruel delusion to pretend that by taking what I would regard as a backward step in relation to tariffs in these industries, we would be arresting what is a difficult and unfortunate decline in employment. That decline is related to a whole range of factors apart from this—most importantly, the recession, but also lack of investment in the past, lack of management initiatives and a whole range of issues—which I think are more important issues to address than those implicit in this question.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer and in particular for his foreshadowing of his statement, which I understand is due on Wednesday, about those outward looking mechanisms for the TCF industries. I think that comparing the TCF industries with other industries does not answer the question on TCF industries. What we really must do is look at each individual industry sector. Is the Minister prepared to accept the premise that the time for a wholesale treatment of all industries across the board in the same simplistic measure is long since gone, and that we must intervene on a selective basis? I ask the Minister to address that question.

—The comparison with other industries was just to make the point, first of all, that one-third or more of Australia's manufacturing industry has no protection at all and has not had for some time. Industries such as the services sector, particularly the financial sector, which have seen the highest fall in employment, are not subject to any protection and there probably is no neat equation between the decline in protection and the employment patterns in particular industry sectors.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Spindler wants, in the latter part of his question, to poke me along the direction of announcing some selective interventionist measures, I am not going to do that—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have already done that with the Customs Bill.
—You have already done that with the car industry, John.

—I am not going to respond to Senator Spindler in Question Time on that issue. As the interjectors rightly point out, in a variety of industry sectors the Government has adopted industry specific measures of one kind or another which would be described by the flat earthers as interventions. I make no apologies for that. I do not want to argue in here the 1970 Farmers Federation show, which is what the Opposition is on about in terms of industry policy. That is widely recognised internationally as well as here.

PARA.TAB: The Far Eastern Economic Review commented a while ago that my Opposition spokesman, as they put it—they called him Ian McVeigh—is a card-carrying member of the Flat Earth Society in a period when Australian industry needs leadership and consistency. That is not my comment; that is a comment from the Far Eastern Economic Review.

I do not want to start the pain process so early in the week by pointing out some of the deficiencies of Opposition policy in answer to a question from Senator Spindler. The point I am simply making is that I am not going to embark on an answer to his question at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Tourism. The Minister for Tourism recently released the Government's strategy for the development of the tourism industry. Can the Minister inform the Senate about the significance of the tourism industry to employment growth in Australia? In view of Australia's need to generate employment, what policies are contained in the strategy to boost international tourism numbers over the remainder of the decade? In addition, what priorities has the Government set to enable it to achieve the growth targets outlined in the strategy?

—Tourism is already one of our fastest growth industries and has enormous future potential. This industry already employs around 450,000 Australians. All of the recent changes and progressive developments that the Government has made in the aviation area, for example, are planned to enhance this important industry. This Government does recognise the importance of this industry and recently released a national tourism strategy entitled Tourism: Australia's Passport to Growth. This report is a comprehensive blueprint for the development of the industry and is a result of extensive consultation with the tourism industry itself, State, Territory and local governments and the community at large.

PARA.TAB: When launching this strategy, Mr Griffiths outlined six key priority areas for further development in the industry: vigorous promotion of Australia as a tourist destination; creation of a favourable investment climate for the industry, which of course was recently enhanced with the initiatives in the One Nation statement; development of a competitive transport sector, particularly in aviation; improving the statistical base of the industry; developing the skills base of the industry work force; and targeting the growth of key market segments.

The strategy will improve the coordination of government policy as it affects the industry and will help the industry to achieve its growth potential. The targets in the strategy are based on annual growth rates of between 8 per cent and 11 per cent in international tourism numbers to Australia. To accommodate the growth in tourist numbers, the strategy points out that 90,000 additional hotel rooms will be needed in Australia by the turn of the century.

The Government is confident that the positive framework provided by the national tourism strategy will assist the industry to fulfil this potential. We expect that the industry will generate another 200,000 jobs by the end of this decade. We expect that annual foreign exchange earnings from tourism will rise to as much as $18 billion per year—that is, in today's dollars. Our strategy is based on research based projections and strategic development. The Government's policy on tourism is well and truly in place and will help to generate both jobs and export income for this country.

I do not know—I have been trying to find out for some time—precisely what the Opposition's tourism policy is. The Opposition recently announced that it had put a committee together that was going to workshop—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. We have had over half an hour of Question Time and senators on this side of the chamber have asked two questions. Senator Collins has just read a statement—the appropriate time for statements is after Question Time—and now he wants to debate our policy under the guise of questions without notice. Mr President, I ask that you require him to comply with the Standing Orders and not continue in this way.
—Counting supplementary questions, we have had nine questions. It is not a good total. I ask the Minister to be conscious of the time taken in answering questions.

—Mr President, I was about to conclude by saying that the Opposition would do the tourism industry—one of the largest job creating and export earning industries of this country—a great favour if, instead of workshopping its policy on the consumption tax, it buried it.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said last week, whether the Foreign Investment Review Board guidelines are complied with is a matter for the Foreign Investment Review Board. As I also said last week, in most foreign investment applications to the Board—as in this one which was made by two companies, one a Danish company and one an Australian company—the applicants are stated and there is no detailed analysis. For example, in the case of Danpork, the fact that it is a cooperative in Denmark and things of that kind are not included in the application. —Are you indifferent to ministerial misrepresentation?
—Order! Senator Alston, Senator Hill asked the question.
—I will have a look at the rules which Senator Hill read out and provide him with a further answer in due course.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the rise from 60c to 85c in the price of Power Brewing Company shares in the second week of June—a massive 41 per cent rise in a week? Has the Minister's attention also been drawn to the subsequent announcement last week that Power Brewing Company Ltd and Carlton and United Breweries have struck a strategic 20-year alliance, reportedly to bring commercial benefits to both companies? In view of these facts, will the Government's commercial and corporate watchdogs be investigating the matter to identify whether insider trading or some other pernicious practice occurred with regard to the shares of Power Brewing Company?

—Quite clearly, the importance of investor confidence in the integrity of the market is a crucial element in Australia's recovery from some of the excesses of the late 1980s. Indeed, I believe that the major impediment and frustration in the reform of companies and securities law undertaken by this Government was the Legislative Council of Western Australia. It was whipped into submission by Senator Campbell and Senator Crichton-Browne and I thank those honourable senators for assisting in that respect.

PARA.TAB: But I must say that it has been a first priority of the Government to put in place a regulatory framework for the Australian companies and securities regime which will, as I say, restore integrity to the marketplace and, therefore, enhance investor confidence, which is so important for the creation of wealth in the Australian community. One of the first measures introduced by this Government after the new national scheme came into place on 1 January 1991 was a complete overhaul of the insider trading regulations and provisions. Those provisions, which took effect from 1 August 1991, contain much greater clarity with respect to what will count as insider trading and, thereby, we hope this will facilitate prosecutions for the offence.

Maximum penalties for breach of the provisions have also been increased tenfold, which I think indicates the serious way in which Parliament looks at this matter. In fact, fines of up to $200,000 can be levied on individuals and up to $1m on bodies corporate. Individuals also face a maximum of five years imprisonment for breach of the insider trading provisions.

The question of whether insider trading has occurred in the instance raised by Senator Maguire is a matter entirely for the Australian Securities Commission, which is an independent statutory body charged with responsibility for the administration and enforcement of company law. As such, not only would it be inappropriate for the Attorney-General to intervene or to try to influence that particular investigation but, indeed, under the Act he is expressly prohibited from giving a direction to the Securities Commission with respect to a particular case.

I think Senator Maguire also raised the question of the linking of Carlton and United Breweries and Power Brewing for a 20-year strategic alliance. I understand that that matter is being examined by the Trade Practices Commission. Professor Fels indicated that it was a matter of some concern and that an investigation was required. However, he did not indicate in his press release any particular prejudice concerning an outcome of that investigation. I believe that both our securities watchdog and the Trade Practices Commission have Senator Maguire's matters of concern well under surveillance at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer the Minister to comments made by Senator Ray, the Minister for Defence, in Question Time last week when he announced that the Government would allow continuing discrimination against homosexual people in the Australian Defence Force. Senator Ray stated:

QUESTION.PARA: I also concede that this policy may end up in the courts if cases of dismissal are challenged.

I ask the Minister: what legally enforceable remedies exist under current Federal legislation should a member of the defence forces seek to challenge the policy? Under what international jurisdiction would recourse be available?

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, it would not be appropriate to offer legal advice in relation to any individual cases, but some general comments can be made about the matter. The fact is that, at common law, members of the Australian defence forces hold their appointments and perform their duties under the pleasure of the Crown. That means that members of the Defence Force can be discharged or have their appointments terminated by the Governor-General at any time for any reason or for no reason at all, and no right of action would result from such termination or discharge.

PARA.TAB: In addition, though, the legislation does provide that the relevant chief of staff is given a power to discharge soldiers and sailors for a prescribed reason and airmen for such reason as the chief of staff thinks fit. A breach of the ADF's policy in relation to homosexuality would constitute a prescribed reason under the Australian military regulations and the naval defence regulations. In that situation, if a soldier, sailor or airman were discharged by a chief of staff, he or she could seek to have the discharge set aside by a court on narrow grounds available for judicial review; that is, as to whether the dismissal or termination of appointment was lawfully undertaken, but certainly not as to the merits of the policy. No court can overturn the policy itself and, provided the policy is lawfully implemented, an aggrieved individual cannot ask the court to substitute its idea of public policy for that of the Minister.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has functions under its Act based on International Labour Organisation Convention 111. It can inquire into acts or practices which may constitute discrimination in employment. The regulations declare the ground of discrimination, including sexual preference, for the purposes of the Act effective as of 1 January 1990. It can also, under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, inquire into acts or practices of the Commonwealth which are inconsistent with or contrary to any human right, including the rights recognised in the covenant. Of course, the covenant protects the individual's right to privacy and equality before the law.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission can inquire into and attempt to conciliate in respect of any act or practice which may constitute discrimination. Where the Commissioner is of the opinion that an act or practice does constitute discrimination and where conciliation is ineffective or inappropriate, the Commission may report to the Minister. The Minister is required to table any such report in Parliament within 15 sitting days. The Act does not make discrimination unlawful, nor does it provide for enforcement mechanisms where the Commission finds discrimination to be established.

Senator Powell also asked about the international recourse that might be had. Under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Australia is under an obligation not to arbitrarily or unlawfully interfere with a person's privacy. That is under article 17 of the covenant. Under the first optional protocol, complaint can be made to the United Nations Human Rights Committee if an individual's rights under the covenant are violated, provided the individual has exhausted all domestic remedies. All the Committee can do is deliver a view; it cannot enforce any particular point of view.

As a party to International Labour Organisation Convention 111 on discrimination in employment or occupation, Australia has obligations to declare and pursue a national policy designed to promote equality of opportunity and treatment with a view to eliminating any discrimination. Sexual preference is a declared ground of discrimination. In that situation, all that the ILO can do is publish the representation and, where applicable, the fact of a lack of a satisfactory reply by a state.

That answer was a little longer than normally I would give, but it is a matter of great interest to both honourable senators and the community. I hope that it helps to clarify the general issues and not any particular case that might arise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister's answer ended in a rather circular way with the Minister who perpetrated the policy actually making the statement of dissatisfaction to this place. The Minister admitted that publication and report are all that are available in the end to people who may wish recourse under this policy allowed by the Government. Under ILO Convention 111, where this Government's responsibility is to pursue a national policy, would we be wrong in suggesting that this Government's pursuit of such a policy is under question, particularly as this same Government, having implemented this policy in the defence forces, has also refused to give gay and lesbian rights lobby groups representation on the National Advisory Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation, which is investigating that very same ILO convention?

—The Government is committed to implementing ILO Convention 111. The actual mechanisms it adopts to put itself in a position to comply are a matter for the Government. I am sure that the sorts of representations which are alluded to in Senator Powell's supplementary question as to those who might be on any advisory committee have been taken fully into account by the responsible Minister.

PARA.TAB: As far as the question of complying with ILO Convention 111 is concerned, whilst no individual can make a particular application to the international body by way of highlighting some personal grievance, there are mechanisms to allow that matter to be brought before the ILO. If that is undertaken, I am quite sure that if the Government is confronted with the need, in the view of the ILO, to better conform to that Convention it will undertake such steps.

Of course, in the last month the US has blocked the honouring of US cheques paid into Serbian and Montenegron banks.

PARA.TAB: In addition to this part of the problem, mail deliveries in the republics have been severely curtailed and alternative methods of payment cannot be guaranteed. The Australian Government did in fact approach the UN sanctions committee on 12 June and was given a response to its request. The response was that our request was rejected. SPEECH.PARA: COMPLAINTS (AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE)
REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT)
STATUTORY RULES 1992 NO.58
30 April 1992
Senator the Hon Michael Tate
Minister for Justice and
Consumer Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1992 No.58, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 30 April 1992.

The Explanatory Statement advises that recent advice had been received that an existing regulation to similar effect was invalidly made. No details of the reasons for the invalidity are given. We assume that it was because the repealed regulation was made in 1985 and lacked the authority which was expressly inserted (s.76(4)(aa)) in the parent Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 in 1987. However, we would be grateful for your advice.

On a more important matter, the present Regulations provide for the standard of proof required in proceedings before the Federal Police Disciplinary Tribunal to be beyond reasonable doubt, which is the same standard required for criminal cases. The Committee would appreciate your detailed advice on the reasons for this standard, rather than the civil standard of the balance of probabilities. Given the nature of the relevant proceedings, the personal rights and liberties of the public may be better protected by the civil standard of proof.

On another matter, r.3.1 provides that the amendment "extends to proceedings commenced, or concerning a matter that arose, before the date of commencement of these Regulations". If the previous regulation was invalid, the fact that the new regulation extends to these proceedings and matters raises the possibility that the present regulation could operate prejudicially. This may not be the case if, in the absence of the present regulations, the less strict balance of probabilities was to apply. The Committee would appreciate your assurance that the regulations do not have prejudicial retrospectivity.
Yours sincerely
Patricia Giles
Chair
Dear Senator Giles
I refer to your letter of 30 April 1992 concerning the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1992 No.58.
You ask my advice on three matters in relation to this Amendment.

First, you ask what were the reasons for the invalidity of the previous r.9 which is replaced by the Amendment. Your Committee is right in its assumption that the reason is that the repealed r.9 was made in 1985 and that it now appears that no authority for such a regulation was provided by the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 until the enactment of s.76(4)(aa) in 1987.

Secondly, you ask why the regulation adopts the criminal rather than the civil standard of proof in proceedings before the Federal Police Disciplinary Tribunal. In practice, this standard has been in use since 1985, when the repealed r.9 was made following prolonged consultation between relevant Departments and the Australian Federal Police Association (the AFPA). When the invalidity of that regulation came to light late last year I did not consider it appropriate to make use of this technicality to overturn the existing arrangement. The purpose of the Amendment is to rectify the invalidity of r.9 rather than to implement a new policy decision.

That said, I believe the considerations which led to the original decision on this matter are still valid. The penalties which can be imposed as a result of disciplinary proceedings, while differing in their legal character from criminal penalties, can have practical consequences as severe as any criminal sentence short of imprisonment. Moreover, many acts constituting a breach of discipline in the Australian Federal Police would also be crimes. (While this is not unique to policing, it is more significant than it would be for most other groups subject to disciplinary regimes, particularly because of the confrontational character of much police interaction with the public. One other area where disciplinary offences are often also criminal offences is the Defence Force, whose discipline code also prescribes the criminal standard of proof.) In my view it is not desirable to encourage the handling of such matters otherwise than by criminal prosecution. That view is already reflected in the requirement of the Australian Federal Police (Discipline) Regulations that where a prosecution is initiated any disciplinary proceeding in relation to the same matter should be suspended for the duration of the prosecution and in the practice of investigating a complaint as a crime rather than a breach of discipline in the first instance if there is any reason to suspect criminality. The prospect of being able to satisfy a lesser standard of proof before the Disciplinary Tribunal would inevitably tend to discourage rigorous pursuit of criminal investigations in such circumstances.

In any case, the AFP's Internal Investigation Division has the power to require a member under investigation for a breach of discipline to answer its questions even where an answer may tend to incriminate the member, an advantage not enjoyed by most disciplinary investigators and which does not have the potential to harm an honest member in the way that a lower standard of proof could do in ambiguous circumstances. In this regard it must be remembered that the complaints procedure provides not only an avenue of redress for the genuinely aggrieved but also a means for rightly accused persons to raise doubts about police evidence or avenge themselves on a member. Accusations against the police should therefore not be too lightly accepted.

Lastly, you ask for my assurance that the regulations do not have prejudicial retrospectivity by reason of the provisions of r.3.1. This provision was included in order to eliminate any doubt about the standard of proof applicable in subsequent hearings of cases which had in some sense begun before the commencement of the new r.9, so its operation is not strictly retrospective. In any case, no question of prejudice arises. The only people who could be prejudiced in a legal sense by a change in the standard of proof are AFP members facing charges. TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: audit report No. 42 of 1991-92, Project Audit—Department of Administrative Services—Debt Management.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate the Auditor-General on this excellent report, Project Audit—Department of Administrative Services—Debt Management. In the main, the responses from both the Department of Administrative Services and the Department of Finance have been very positive.

PARA.TAB: I consider the recommendations of the Auditor-General, as pointed out in the summary, to be applicable for all public sector agencies adopting private sector practices. I make that point because the Auditor-General has used DAS, which has a lot of corporatised operations, as an example and said, `Let's apply this across the board', where the Government has corporatised or commercialised various operations.

Let me touch on a few aspects of the report. The Auditor-General recommends that all business units develop and implement comprehensive debt management procedures. One worrying aspect of the Government's commercialisation, or corporatisation, is that debt collection is a key factor in any commercial operation, whether it be in the private or the public sector. This fact seems to have slipped by the Government and the various commercial departments in DAS. Failure to collect bad debts can result in liquidity problems, which can put a normal operation out of business. But the public sector, of course, has the Linus blanket—it can always go back to the Budget if it finds itself in difficulty.

Another recommendation in the Auditor-General's report is that business units develop and use memorandums of understanding or a similar arrangement in clarifying and formalising terms and conditions of trade. The Department has responded by saying that it will go in that direction by encouraging a clear delineation of provider procurer responsibilities through the greater use of memorandums of understanding, exchanging of correspondence and pre-engagement negotiations to avoid misunderstandings, including any relating to building and payment arrangements. These measures are critical in any commercial operation for the continued viability of a normal operation.

I will not go through all the recommendations of the Auditor-General. However, he recommends that greater emphasis be placed on debt performance indicators to assist in monitoring debt management performance. Again, this relates back to the importance that one sector of the community, the private sector, puts on debt management and the collection of debts and the real lack of interest that is shown by the public sector.

The Audit Office also recommends improvements by introducing techniques such as invoices with detachable remittance advice to facilitate the accurate and timely matching of payments with client accounts and associated debtor records. DAS, I believe quite correctly, points out that the proposed upgrade of the Department of Finance account payment system will address the referencing deficiency. So the Department is saying that it has flicked it back to the Department of Finance, and it deserves a little flick over the knuckles with the feather duster too.

The Audit Office recommends that public sector agencies improve their payment procedures to ensure the payment of correctly rendered invoices by the due date. Two points are made by the Auditor-General: one is that there is some doubt about the correct rendering of invoices; and the other one is that it seems that other public sector agencies tend to put their own brother organisations, if I can call them that, at the bottom of the pile. I see that the Minister responsible, the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), is sitting at the table. It might be useful if one day he sends the debt collectors to one of his other government agencies. It would be interesting to see the result.

TALK.START.PARA: —It won't be far off.

—The Minister says that it will not be long before that happens. The Audit Office also recommended—I was pleased to see that the Department actually took a guarded approach to this—that changes be made to the existing administrative and legislative frameworks through amendments to the finance regulations and directions to provide for debt management options, including the use of memoranda of understanding, the use of incentives and penalties, and debt factoring. I believe that the Department has quite correctly said that it is not really impressed with debt factoring—and neither, might I say, would I be. It has always been a sign of bankruptcy when a company starts to factor its own debts. From what I have seen in my career, companies pass the point of no return once they start factoring debt. I think it would be an interesting reflection on the government of the day, whatever colour it may be, if suddenly it was made known in the Australian Financial Review that that government was out factoring its debts, particularly to itself. I can see the problems associated with that.

PARA.TAB: The final recommendation is that DAS continue to examine service delivery arrangements which involve the payment for goods and services at the time of delivery. That has a lot of things going for it. It puts other departments, particularly recalcitrant departments, on notice that, if they want the goods that are provided quite efficiently by certain areas of DAS, they should pay up.

If one reads the DAS response, which I will not do in the interests of time because we have a lot of legislation to get through, one can see that it does have all the hallmarks of a Yes, Minister reply. So I draw the Minister's attention to the Department's response to recommendation No. 12 because it contains all the gobbledegook associated with a typical Yes, Minister reply. And as everyone knows, Jim Hacker was the Minister for Administrative Services in Yes, Minister.

Having dealt with the recommendations and responses, I would now like to refer to the key findings. The Audit Office found that the debt management programs of the business units of DAS have continued to be affected by a legacy of outstanding debts, inadequate debt collection procedures and systems, and inexperienced staff. The time for excuses of inexperienced staff has well passed. This has been going on for something like three years now. If one looks at the chart provided by the Auditor-General, one notices that the total outstanding debts have changed from just over $200m in September 1990 to $160m-odd in December 1991. So the improvement is pretty poor.

I commented earlier that the longstanding practice of public sector agencies giving low priority to payment of intra-Commonwealth debts has to be addressed. It seems to me that a debt is a debt by a government organisation, whether that debt is owed to DAS or whether it is owed to a private sector organisation. All debts should be given equal priority. I am not talking about DAS being a monopoly supplier. I am referring to other government departments being in a very strong buying position, almost a monopoly buying position, which can be used to their advantage. This is really to the disadvantage of the commercial operations because not only can it put them at risk but also it can put them out of business. The Audit Office also found that Commonwealth departments and agencies need to review account payment mechanisms to ensure that correctly rendered invoices are paid by the `due date'.

In summary, it seems that the Auditor-General is saying that more attention must be given, not only by DAS but by other commercial operations of government, to the collection of debts and that government departments themselves must give due diligence to the payment of debts owed, whether it be to DAS or any other government organisation or, for that matter, to anyone in the private sector.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
