TALK.START.PARA: —The first Bill in this package is the Migration Amendment (No. 2) Bill 1992 and the second is the Migration Amendment (No. 3) Bill 1992, and they are being debated with the following associated Bills: the Migration Agents Registration (Application) Levy Bill 1992 and the Migration Agents Registration (Renewal) Levy Bill 1992, migration agents being the principal subject of the third migration Bill.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition will support all of the Bills that are before the Senate. For many months we have been calling for the Government to get its act in order, for some degree of management competence to be shown by this failing Labor Government and for it to become aware of the huge extent to which public confidence is lacking in immigration in this country because of its failures.

These amending Bills strengthen the law, give appropriate greater powers to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs with regard to refugees and set up the Migration Agents Registration Board to attempt to overcome—and I am confident the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 3) will go some way towards doing so—abuses which have developed around the practice of charging fees for immigration advice that some Australians have taken up. There are appropriate exemptions and a reasonable structure has now emerged after careful consultation between the Minister and the Opposition.

I will begin with the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 2). Because there is a guillotine in operation—that is, there is a deadline for debate on these Bills—introduced by the Government and the Australian Democrats, we must restrain ourselves, keep to the point and leave out a number of matters that we would have liked to have raised, especially in terms of this Government's failures in immigration.

The principal change in the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 2) relates to refugees. We have in this country a compassionate history of welcoming to Australia bona fide refugees from what is now almost every part of the world. The two categories that are most in our minds are those refugees who fled from eastern Europe at the end of the Second World War and who have, in many thousands of cases, made excellent citizens of this country. The second is the wave of refugee immigrants to this country from Indo-China again following the events of oppressive communist governments. Again, thousands of these refugees have made excellent citizens of this country.

Australia has an enlightened and bipartisan approach towards playing its role in helping refugees to find a safe and stable life when their lives and livelihoods are in danger in their place of birth. But what has happened is that the law and regulations relating to refugees still contain some loopholes which have enabled litigious lawyers—and I do not put the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, in that category all of the time—

TALK.START.PARA: —Be charitable—any of the time.

—Not all of the time. Sometimes in Question Time Senator Button does turn on a point with what we would call casuistry, where the principle that is involved is understood by all. I do want not to blacken the important legal profession in this country but, rather, to say that there are some lawyers who have an over diligent legalistic approach when trying to help the poor arrivees in Australia who want to be refugees, but who are not given the status of refugees after due process because they do not meet the international definition of refugees. Nevertheless, such lawyers will still try to represent such persons, partly for their pecuniary advantage in doing so and partly out of a misplaced sense of duty, but whatever the event—
—You have more on your back bench than we have.

—Whatever the event, and however many lawyers there are on each side of the Parliament, it is to the frustration of the clear will of this Parliament, the intention of the law and, indeed, the best intentions of the Minister. It is appropriate that we have a better means available to the Minister, the Government and the very careful officials in the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to administer with certainty the immigration program that we have defined.

PARA.TAB: This Bill strengthens the hand of the Minister in a way which is entirely acceptable to the Opposition. It gives the Minister authority to deal with applications for refugee status in such order as the Minister considers appropriate. In addition, the Minister's obligation to decide refugee claims where the applicant holds a permanent entry permit, entry visa or even a PRC temporary entry permit is removed.

Another feature of this Migration Amendment Bill (No. 2) is that a conditional entry procedure for business migration is being made available for the first time. Unfortunately, we have found that a number of business migrants to Australia have not lived up to their stated intentions of investing the capital that they brought with them to generate employment and additional prosperity for themselves and for other Australians. A particular advantage is given to a small number of immigrants who bring more than half a million dollars and who otherwise meet the requirements to live in Australia. They are required to put that half a million dollars or more into an investment in Australia to the better interests of Australia.

Where this has not actually happened in practice, the Opposition believes that there is a need to tighten the requirement, monitor what happens and revoke the entry permit if the undertakings which were given are not lived up to. For the first time we will have a conditional entry: you can enter, we will monitor and if you live up to your undertakings given in the application, your permit to remain in Australia will be confirmed; if not, it will not be confirmed.

With regard to illegal fishermen, we welcome moves to make it less financially attractive for overseas persons to come into Australian waters. Where Australian law is broken, where there is trespass by an overseas fishing vessel into Australian waters, the costs involved in their apprehension, detention, transport back to their home country and any legal expenses may now be billed to those fishermen or to those companies and persons who are associated with the fishermen being in Australia.

There are a number of other matters relating to review authorities being able to remit their decisions to the decision maker without having to wait for the Department. There are minor amendments relating to when the Minister sets aside a decision within his Department, and the requirement in those cases for the Minister to report to the Parliament. There are also a number of technical amendments, all of which have been carefully discussed by the Minister and the Opposition. We thank him for that consultation. We support all elements of the Bill. However, on behalf of the Opposition, I move:
At end of motion, add ", but the Senate notes:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the long period of detention in which some claimants are being held;
(b)the failure of the Government to deal with claims expeditiously; and
(c)the failure of the Government to eliminate effectively from the process manifestly unfounded claims, undue legalism and protracted appeal entitlements".

On 25 February I asked a question in the Senate about some 56 illegal immigrants who landed in Western Australia on the last day of last year and were discovered early in January, in the heat of the summer. What has happened to them? They are still here. There is still a failure by this Government to deal not only with these illegal immigrants, according to law and due process in an expeditious manner, but also with the other boatloads who have been here 2 1/2 years now. They arrived here illegally, jumping the queue on the other one million persons around the world who want to migrate to Australia by lawful application, without discrimination and on the basis of our declared law. These queue jumpers have arrived here, no doubt desperate because they were in poverty and wanted to better their lives by coming to a happy and lucky country—Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what you tell us on most days.

—Relative to Cambodia at the moment, I think Senator Button would concede that even under the present Government, which has led to this country having one million unemployed and a Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who was not elected by the people and who lacks their confidence, for these poor people who braved the sea to come here, perhaps with the glimmer in their eye that there will be a Liberal and National government by May 1993, Australia is a better and safer place for them to get on with their lives. No-one contests that. We do not even contest that many illegal immigrants in this country will make hardworking, prosperous, good Australians.

PARA.TAB: But the point is that we have by this Parliament a defined immigration program that gives fairness and equality, with no discrimination and no queue jumping. It is administered according to law, fairly and with compassion. I hope Senator Coulter will concede that those of us who do require immigration according to law are not lacking in compassion. We have heart. We want an immigration program. Often the Democrats do not want any immigration at all. If anyone is lacking in compassion in the debate on immigration in this country, it would have to be the Democrats, who do not want cousins, brothers and sisters reunited with members of their family who have already migrated to this country from wherever in the world.

Those people who look through the barbed wire fence of the Port Hedland detention centre—I do not think it actually is barbed wire, but it is at least a cyclone fence—will see the faces of those illegal immigrants imploring Australians that they be able to remain here, even if they are illegal immigrants. We ought not to be moved only by our emotions; we ought to give a proper confirmation of what is law in this country, what is fair in this country and what is well managed in this country. If the Democrats were to criticise even Senator Button or even the Government for a lack of compassion in upholding the law of Australia in immigration matters, I think they would need to look at their own conduct with regard to their wanting to have virtually no immigration, or at least minimal immigration, into this country. What is compassionate?

I move on quickly to the matter of the abuses that have occurred as a result of persons charging fees—often exorbitant fees—on the grounds that they are giving migration advice to some person applying for a migration decision either within Australia or outside Australia. The Opposition supports the concept in this Bill that a migration agents registration board ought to be set up. It ought to have the powers to act quickly, to warn, to suspend, to deregister, to reject applications for registration, to test whether applicants who register as migration agents have the integrity and qualifications to offer to the public what they profess, and, generally, to administer this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will have to run the finger over some of your colleagues.

—There have been members of the Labor Party who have offended greatly in this way, whilst none come to mind from this side. I notice that this Bill allows members of parliament to register. As a personal aside, I would not allow members of parliament to register as migration agents. That is my personal view. I believe that members of parliament are already elected to represent the people and ought to give their advice entirely free. Woe be it if any senator puts up a billboard on his private office to say that he is a migration agent and charges fees for what he ought to be giving freely to any person who inquires of him. It would be a very brave member of parliament on either side who would go against that kind of moral suasion. I hope that it is effective suasion.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the consequences of offending. If someone says that he is a migration agent, without being registered, there is a fine of $5,000. If he charges somebody a fee, he would be liable to 10 years imprisonment or a $60,000 fine, or both. These are very heavy penalties. They are obviously to deter anyone from thinking about doing any of these things improperly once this law is passed.

I cannot go over the code of conduct that is to be determined. I know that it is in its draft stage at the moment; we have not seen it in its final form. If it is not acceptable after proper consultation with the Opposition, we would seek to disallow it when it comes before the Parliament. We do expect to be consulted and we hope that a satisfactory code can be determined.

We also briefly note that the Law Institute of Victoria in particular, the Law Council of Australia and various other lawyers bodies have very much resisted this Bill because they want lawyers to be able to give advice and receive fees for their advice without the constraints of and the regulation flowing from this Bill. It is a happy consequence that in the committee stage the Government will be introducing a late amendment with regard to lawyers and other persons who handle five or less cases per year. Instead of having a registration fee of $1,000 a year, they will have a fee of only $100 a year—that is 10 per cent—and they will trip the higher fee when they go to the sixth case. I think that is fair. It is the proposition that my party room was working towards. As a result of consultation between Mr Ruddock, the Opposition spokesman for immigration and ethnic affairs, and the Minister, Mr Hand, this amendment has come forward.

All consular and diplomatic persons in Australia will also be exempt from this Bill. They will be able to give advice to their own citizens. That is not intended to be made a transgression by this Bill. Regrettably, it is necessary to have these regulations. Liberals go very slowly into new areas of regulation. Because of the offences in this area, the law does need to be tidied up.

I conclude by repeating that these measures, especially in the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, are only part of the measures the Opposition has been calling for. We want an migration program that is well managed and wins the confidence of the public of Australia. That is not the case at the moment. I believe that the Government's failures in immigration will be another noose around its neck when the next election comes along. Because of the failures of the Labor Party in immigration, quite apart from the horrendous failures in the economy, it deserves to lose office. The sort of management that can win the confidence of the Australian people will be gained only when there is a Liberal-National Party government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating briefly this afternoon the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992, the Migration Agents Registration (Application) Levy Bill 1992 and the Migration Agents Registration (Renewal) Levy Bill 1992. I wish to speak to the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992 and in the process will pick up the related Bills. The Bills give effect to a registration scheme for migration agents and establish the Migration Agents Registration Board and a code of conduct for such agents.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats support this legislation in the interests of improving the standards of professional conduct and quality of service. We recognise that there have been complaints against incompetent or unscrupulous agents and the situation needs to be addressed. I note that Australia is the first country with a major migration program to introduce regulatory arrangements of this kind. Given the extent to which legal and illegal immigration appears to be almost out of control in some countries, notably in the USA, I hope that this legislation can be a model for other immigration host countries.

The Democrats welcome the introduction of a code of conduct, although, as Senator Baden Teague has said, we have not yet seen the code of conduct. We look forward to the opportunity to look at the draft code of conduct. Hopefully, this will provide appropriate guidelines for actual or intending migration agents and provide the basis for an improvement in professional standards. Just as important, it will provide a guide for consumers as well as for agents.

While we understand the opposition of the legal profession to the concept of an independent body—namely, the Migration Agents Registration Board—disciplining its members in cases of incompetence or misconduct, we recognise that there is a high level of fragmentation amongst migration agents with professions organised into their own distinct associations and a large number of people acting alone. It is hoped, however, that the Government will maintain a close dialogue with the legal profession as the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) stated that he hoped to do.

We welcome the most recent amendments which have the effect, as Senator Baden Teague has already indicated, of lowering the registration fee for migration agents from $1,000 to $100 where they deal with fewer than five cases per year. This takes into account the few hundred agents who, for various reasons, such as being based in rural towns, handle only a few cases each year. The amendments which exclude members of diplomatic missions, consular posts or certain international organisations, such as the United Nations High Commission on Refugees, are also welcome.

I would like to pick up on some of the things that Senator Baden Teague said about the Democrats. It is simply untrue that the Democrats are opposed on humanitarian grounds to immigration. We recognise several aspects. We recognise that we have a duty not only to the people who are living today but also to future generations of Australians. This inter-generational equity was well developed in the ESD process committees. It is a matter of fact that if we double the population in an area, all other things being equal, the environmental impact will be doubled. Consequently, we need to look at the ultimate carrying capacity of this country in terms of the ecological ability of Australia to carry that number of people.

It is a matter of demographic fact that with a net migration program of 50,000 per year, which is roughly where it is now, the population of Australia would gradually grow in an asymptote pattern to about 25 million and do it in a way which would not produce hiccups and difficulties in its age structure. So we have a commitment to stabilise the population over the long term, which will take about 60 years to achieve, and relate it to the actual carrying capacity of the country. We have made it abundantly clear that within that 50,000 we would put a very heavy emphasis on those most in need.

This is where I would take issue with Senator Teague and perhaps contrast briefly the difference between business migrants and refugees. Business migrants, by definition, are those who have made half a million dollars in their own country. If they have half a million dollars, it is very likely that in terms of wealth they exceed the amount of personal wealth of perhaps 95 per cent of Australians. They have made that money in a foreign country and they seek to move it to Australia for their own personal benefit. It seems to me naive for Australians to consider that people who have made an amount of money that large in a foreign country and who have simply moved it to Australia for further economic or financial benefit will necessarily have any loyalty to Australia and that when conditions here are not as good as in some third country they will simply not up sticks and take their money elsewhere. We have always had some difficulty with, as I say, the naivety of government that believes business migration will necessarily benefit the country, and benefit the country in the long term.

However, when one looks at refugees, by definition, these are people who for a variety of reasons simply cannot continue in their own country. Not only would it seem to us that those people are far more likely to make better long term citizens but also we would be exercising our responsibility as international citizens if we were to substantially increase the refugee component of our migration program. But, having said that, one has to recognise that the number of refugees in the world is so large and growing so rapidly that it is simply physically impossible for Australia to make a significant dent in the refugee problem by bringing any reasonable number of people into this country. For argument's sake, if we were to roughly double the refugee program and bring in 20,000 people each year, that would make but a very small dent in the 17 million refugees around the world, which number, as I say, is growing.

We have made quite clear on a number of occasions that we believe it is appropriate for Australia to increase very substantially its foreign aid program and target that increased foreign aid specifically towards the causes of people becoming refugees. Any honourable senators who saw the Couchman program last week on ABC television could not help but have been impressed by the fact that all those people in the program, irrespective of their country of origin, made the very strong point that in coming to Australia as refugees they had lost their identity; they had moved into a foreign culture; they had lost their birth certificate or marriage certificate. Just about everything which made them a person was lost upon being moved to a foreign country, and they had great difficulty in establishing a new identity in Australia.

Far from being uncaring, as Senator Teague tried to indicate, the Democrats, as I say, would substantially address this problem, firstly, by increasing the number of refugees coming to Australia and, secondly, by substantially increasing Australian foreign aid to other countries and directing it to those factors which cause people to become refugees so that, hopefully, more people will not become refugees and will be able to remain satisfactorily in their own home countries.

The Australian Democrats applaud this legislation, which leads to a tightening up of our immigration procedures. In 1987-88, the proposed 140,000 annual intake blew out to an actual 171,000. We are facing a world where there is increasing pressure on our shores and more and more people deeming Australia a relatively desirable place to live. Some seek genuine political asylum, others just a better life. However, those who request to stay here have a right to proper advice and to be protected from the unscrupulous. We commend to the Senate the Bills and the Government amendments.

We will not be supporting the second reading amendment which Senator Teague moved. We believe that it is hypocritical of members of the Opposition to move in that direction, particularly in light of the way they did not support our rejection of precisely the circumstances which related to 37 boat people who were, within less than 36 hours, to have their case heard in court. To now come weeping on our shoulders and try to maintain that they have a particular concern about these circumstances simply will not wash.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to briefly support the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992, the Migration Agents Registration (Application) Levy Bill 1992 and the Migration Agents Registration (Renewal) Levy Bill 1992 and the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Teague. Unfortunately, this is another situation where a set of very important Bills has to be rushed through this Parliament because the Australian Democrats have done a deal with the Government yet again. They have caved in and allowed these sorts of things to be done without proper scrutiny. It is of some regret that the comments I wish to make on the Bills generally are curtailed because of the Democrats and the Government getting together again to curtail free speech and to prevent proper scrutiny of the Bills.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague has very skilfully and capably mentioned the reason for the amendment and I will not, because of the shortness of time, say anything more about that. There were other matters in relation to the other Bills which I would have liked to have spoken on, but again I can only rely on the broad outline that my colleague was able to give, ever so capably, on the general thrust of the Bill.

I want to confine my remarks generally to the Migration Agents Registration (Application) Levy Bill 1992 and the associated Migration Agents Registration (Renewal) Levy Bill 1992. At this stage I should indicate that I am a lawyer; I have not practised for the last two years since I have been in parliament but, if that requires me to disclose an interest, I hereby do so. It is of some general concern to me and to the legal profession that lawyers will be required to register with a government agency before they can provide services normally provided by lawyers to clients. In fact, it seems quite silly to me that lawyers who are trained very well and who have a feeling for legislation and the law are now going to be required to register with some government body before they can give the advice and do the interpretations that they are, by their profession, required to do.

The legal profession is one of the very few professions or occupations that do have some self-regulatory mechanism. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) and even, I regret to say, some of my colleagues have mentioned problems with lawyers in relation to migration matters. If there are problems—and I suspect they are very few—as to charging or as to competence, then the legal profession throughout Australia has always had its own very strict regulatory bodies which will investigate any allegations of wrongdoing, overcharging or incompetence. That is what stands lawyers out from the general run of the mill occupations; they are very strictly and honestly policed to ensure that the very highest standards are maintained.

Of course, lawyers are not all immigration experts but they are trained to interpret the law. They are trained to make the right inquiries. They are trained to give general advice and to point people in the right direction if they cannot finally help them. They are very well trained to realise when a problem comes up that is not within their ability to handle, and they will then refer it either to counsel or to a migration expert, if they are aware of one, who can deal with the matter properly.

Lawyers whose work is limited to the provision of legal advice or lawyers acting in a professional capacity in the preparation of proceedings before a court or an administrative tribunal are not to be covered by this scheme. But apparently if they help to fill in some forms they will be covered by this scheme. How the demarcation between those two things will work is something that I will be interested to see in practice, because it will be very difficult to police.

As seems to be popular, the Minister, in his second reading speech, had a crack at lawyers and suggested that there may be some in the profession who need looking at. If that is the case and if there have been abuses by lawyers in the past, they should have been referred to their professional body for attention. This new body that we are setting up will simply duplicate, as far as lawyers are concerned, what has been happening with lawyers since they first became a profession many centuries ago. Lawyers have a self-regulatory mechanism. It seems unnecessary that they now need to be a part of this group yet again.

I hope this move is not a trend that is proceeding generally with this Government's legislation. It is one that should be resisted. It means simply more red tape, more fees, more bureaucracy and more boards and bureaus that the independent profession will have to answer to.

Apparently under this new scheme there will be some qualifications for persons to be able to give this advice and to qualify for registration. As I understand it—and the Minister might correct me if I am wrong—the regulations prescribing the qualifications have not yet been announced. I understand that the barrier is to be a fairly low one and that the qualifications do not have to be particularly high. That seems to be of some concern more generally. Of course, all lawyers who are involved will have to be properly qualified in the law.

I want to speak very briefly now about the costs of registration. I point out to the Minister, in case he is not aware or interested, that not many people on the Government side and certainly no-one in the Australian Democrats have any real concept of what it is like living in a small rural community or an area that is not fully serviced. If someone lives in a community where there is a migration agent on every corner, maybe the requirement to register migration agents is a good idea. But in many rural communities, and in suburban areas of the capital and provincial cities, lawyers do assist migrants in filling in forms and giving very general legal advice.

I can only talk from experiences I have had in rural Queensland. I know that many of my former colleagues in the law are in a similar situation where there are groups of migrants. There used to be a lot of Italians and Spaniards, and more recently Chinese and Vietnamese, where I come from. I might add as an aside that it is good to see them coming into those more remote areas. I wish there was some way of encouraging many of the immigrants who get into ghettos in the capital cities to get out into the better parts of Australia.

There are many migrants in rural areas. They do at times require a bit of advice—nothing terribly technical or substantial—and so they call upon their local solicitor, accountant or, at times, religious officer to get a little advice because in many cases they cannot speak English, they certainly cannot read English, and they do not understand the government system in Australia.

Many migrants have come from systems where, to get any government service, one has to fork out a few dollars in bribes to get anywhere. They do not understand the system, so they come along to people they trust. In a small community, the people they trust are their solicitors and accountants. They get advice from them and some help with filling in forms. It is not the sort of work that solicitors and accountants in country areas want to attract—there is no real profit margin in it—but solicitors and accountants, as with many things they do, do it simply as a public service and charge a very minimal fee for it.

The legislation as originally proposed had the ridiculous situation that a firm could register at a cost of $1,000 and any employees could register at a cost of $500. I know from my own experience that I fill in only one or two forms every year, and it would have cost $1,500. The end result would be that one simply would not register. In a small country town when those people came knocking at our door, we would try to help them anyway. But the proper thing to do would be to send them away and say, `We are not going to help you'. The alternative would be for them to get in their car, drive for three hours to a provincial city, find their way around, with no-one to help them because they do not know the people, and see whether they can get the advice. They would return probably more confused than when they left, because they would be dealing with people they do not know, do not understand and do not particularly trust.

I am pleased that, following representations made by the Law Council and also by the shadow Minister, Mr Ruddock, the Minister said in the other place that he would consider the matter and see whether some formula could be adopted which would overcome the sorts of problems I have identified and which are real. I am pleased that the Government has at least identified and accepted the problem and is doing something about it. Of course, the Government has simply reduced the fee to $50 and $100 instead of $500 and $1,000 if an agent assists in fewer than five cases. That is another $150 that has to be paid, which is not much.

As the Minister realises, if a solicitor handles five applications a year and pays $150 to be registered, the solicitor would simply add that on to the five bills, so the cost of justice would go up by yet another $30. From my experience, the bill for helping people to fill in the form, giving them advice or making a couple of phone calls would very seldom reach more than $30 in itself. Yet the bill will be doubled so that the solicitor can recoup the registration fee if he or she decides to go into it.

Most country lawyers and accountants will probably register just to provide this service. Many rural solicitors go for perhaps a year and do not see anyone, but then they may handle five or six applications in one year. Who knows? These things tend to follow. If a solicitor registers at a cost of $150, he or she will have to add an extra $30 to each bill. We will then find all the Labor Party people jumping up in a few months time berating the legal profession, saying how lawyers charge too much and how some people earn $10,000 a day. Of course, they are talking about the top QCs. They do not talk about the great majority of the legal profession who work for very modest fees, who themselves have very modest incomes and who provide an honest and trustworthy service right throughout their lives. I can guarantee that we will hear members of the Labor Party talking about the cost of justice and how it is all the lawyers' fault. They will conveniently forget that this is just one little example of where another $30 will be added on to the bill because this Government wants to set up a bureaucracy, register some people and somehow have more control and more fingers in the pie.

Because of engagements I will be unable to wait to hear the Minister's answer, but I will be able to read it in Hansard if he is able to answer my point. I would rather there be no registration at all but, if a solicitor has to be registered and deals with less than five applications, he or she should be put in a different category. I am not quite sure why the Government is bothering with this $150 fee. It is not a big amount, but it will not be the lawyers who pay it. The cost will simply go on to the immigrants and the people who need help. It is just another add-on. It is not a big thing, but why there needs to be any fee for those sorts of people at all I really do not know.

Time constrains me from any further pursuance of these matters. I commend the Bills to the Senate with the amendment that my colleague has moved and I ask that the Government give more consideration and a little extra thought to the necessity for lawyers to be registered in this instance. If the Government comes to the conclusion that it is unavoidable, I ask it to consider whether there needs to be any fee at all in those instances where lawyers and accountants are used on only a very small number of occasions. I might also say that, although there is obviously some reason for the $1,000 and $500 fee in the more major cases, the reason again escapes me. Is it just another attempt to balance the Government's $6 billion hole in the Budget? Is the Government trying to make it up in any way it can? Again, it seems to be quite unnecessary to have those sorts of fees simply added to the cost of doing business in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating Migration Amendment Bill (No. 2), Migration Amendment Bill (No. 3), the Migration Agents Registration (Application) Levy Bill 1992 and the Migration Agents Registration (Renewal) Levy Bill 1992. The migration amendment Bills come before the chamber now following a debate on 5 May of this year on amendments to the Migration Act.

PARA.TAB: On that occasion the amendments presented to this chamber followed the rush of the Bill through the House of Representatives. The purpose of that rush became evident on 5 May when it became clear to a number of us that the Government's intention was to prevent an appeal by certain asylum seekers held in detention and the appeal on their behalf to the Federal Court. I refer the Senate to the debate that took place on 5 May and to the comments that I made during that debate. I indicated a view that I strongly held, and still strongly hold, that the action being taken by the Government in detaining asylum seekers in the manner in which it does is contrary to Australia's obligations under international treaty.

I know what is being said at times by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to its officers on the ground at Port Hedland and elsewhere. Some of those officers have become concerned at the obvious fact that the asylum seekers have come here because they have been forced out of their own country because of persecution and are fearful of return because they have well founded fears that they will suffer persecution on the grounds of race, colour, religion, political opinion, et cetera. Some of those people are in a dreadful state as a result of the fact that they are virtually incarcerated.

Of course, their feelings spill over to those in the compliance section of the Department. A number of people in the compliance section get worried about the fact that those asylum seekers are being treated in a manner that is in fact a denial of their human rights. It is no good people from the top telling people in the compliance section on the ground that all of these people are economic crooks from China—and I challenge the Department to deny that that has ever been said. It is no good making an amorphous statement such as, `There are millions and millions of Chinese and others on the move', somehow thinking that the trade winds from China will send these millions down to Australia.

On one occasion Dr John Eddy said that trade winds have been blowing for thousands of years—and how many have arrived on the soil of Australia? When the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) took certain action in respect of Port Hedland and stated quite deliberately that we wanted to send a message to others, Dr John Eddy observed that human beings should not be used as post boxes or as parcels and that human beings should be treated in accordance with their dignity as individuals whose human rights must be upheld.

I do not stand here bagging the Department. Overwhelmingly in that Department, in my view, there are officers who have a professional and clear understanding of the need to uphold human rights. They are, however, acting on the basis of messages that they are getting from the Minister's office and, indeed, from official statements by the Minister.

One of the officers of the Minister's Department, Harriet Swift, was quoted, I think, in the Bangkok Post as saying that if the Government were to facilitate the applications for refugee status of certain of the Cambodian asylum seekers at this stage this would imply that the Government believed that it was not safe to go back to Cambodia. That would affect the Government's foreign affairs policy in Cambodia.

I have not got the paper with me, but I can get it. If I am wrong in saying that, the Minister will be able to get his Department to show him what, in fact, was reported. She may well have been misreported, but if that is the attitude that is being taken, then clearly the whole of the refugee question has been mixed up in foreign policy considerations. Under its various titles—the Department of Labour and Immigration, as it was; I will not go through all of the changes—the Department has done a mighty job over many years.

We should not confuse the criteria or the numbers that are necessary or desirable to be accepted as immigrants in the migration area with the criteria or the numbers to be accepted in the refugee area. In the latter case, the numbers are not the question: the question is, where we have persons arriving in Australia or seeking asylum in Australia, whether those persons are refugees.

They know whether or not they are refugees. They are the ones who will go through all of the trauma of dislocation from their own countries. Surely, they are the ones who should, in some way, be allowed to determine at what stage the actual application is made. As I will be asking in the Committee of the Whole, why impose upon certain asylum seekers a requirement to apply for refugee status within a certain time? That ignores the fact that the circumstances in the country from which they have been excluded by virtue of their race, colour, creed, political opinion and so on may change. Some people who come here may not wish to make application for refugee status, hoping that the situation in their country may change.

I sincerely believe that the migration program should continue apace. The picture being painted should not affect the migration program at all. I differ strongly from the view expressed by Senator Coulter. I believe it is totally naive to suggest that we ought to stabilise our population. This country needs more people. The fact remains that if it does not get more people we will never have a self-generating economy in this country. Of course, we may not achieve that even so, but one of the biggest problems in this country so far as employment is concerned is the fact that we do not have the population base for a self-generating economy. How can we compete with, for example, the manufacturing industries in some of the industrialised countries and, in future, with some of the less developed countries which are rapidly developing their manufacturing industries? How can we compete with them when, within their own countries, they have the population which enables them to produce in a massively cheaper way because of their economies of scale?
The other issue is resources. This country is blessed with great resources. What we need in this country—and, unfortunately, the Democrats very often oppose it—is value added industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't oppose that at all.

—The Democrats have opposed the pulp mill which is a value added project. We need value added industries which will take advantage of our great resources. One problem that Senator Coulter has is that he seems to accept the self-interested projections made by organisations such as the United Nations Fund for Population Activities. The worse it can paint the crisis, the more money it will get. He believes Paul Ehrlich; Ehrlich is his guru.
—Totally discredited.

—I agree with the Minister: Ehrlich has been totally discredited. I think it was in 1970, after he wrote The Population Bomb in 1968, that Professor Julian Simon said to him that he thought he was wrong. As honourable senators know, Ehrlich had suggested that by the year 1990 there would be a great scarcity of a number of natural resources to such an extent that there would be wars over them.
—There have been.

—Let me just explain. Julian Simon said, `I will bet you that that will not be the case', so they agreed upon the test of the scarcity or otherwise of resource material being its price. Of course, if it is scarce, the price will be sky high; if it is not, the price will be lower. Come 1990, on every single one of the resources the two had agreed upon, the price was lower. I think we ought to have a look at some of the outrageous and outlandish claims upon which important decisions are made. I know DILGEA and its predecessors have done a good job in many of these areas and have argued the question and put forward the viewpoint quite objectively as to how immigration affects the economic status of a particular country. There has been quite good work done by the Department in that area over a number of years.

PARA.TAB: On this question of the migration Bills, I fear that we are in danger of being deceived by the painting of a drastic picture, then applying strictures, and using refugees to send messages to others. I refer to the second reading speech which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past three years the number of applications for refugee status from persons wishing to remain in Australia has grown dramatically from below 500 applications per year to a current case load of 22,500.

I think that was not really an appropriate way to describe the situation. The Minister is comparing apples with oranges. The Minister refers to 500 applications per year growing to a current case load of 22,500. What the Minister does not say is that, of that 22,500, there are some 18,000 PRC (temporary) entry permit holders as a result of the Tiananmen Square massacre. I will be asking the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) a number of questions during the Committee of the Whole discussion as to whether in fact the number of applications is levelling off. Whether it is or is not levelling off, each individual applicant, each individual asylum seeker, deserves to be treated in accordance with the fundamental principles of human rights.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I refer to the `Welcome Stranger' conference that was held in Sydney from 19 to 21 June—yesterday, the day before and the evening before. This national forum on refugees was convened by the Australian Bishops Committee for Migrant Affairs and the Australian Council of Churches Refugee and Migrant Services. Senator Robert Hill, the Leader of the Opposition, and Senator Jim McKiernan attended the conference on Friday evening. Unfortunately, I could not attend on Friday evening but I attended the sessions on Saturday evening and the whole of Sunday morning. The conference was quite revealing.

A joint statement has been issued by the Australian Council of Churches Refugee and Migrant Services and the Australian Bishops Committee for Migrant Affairs. The forum called for a more humane processing of refugees. The statement pointed out that the Australian Government needed to change its current refugee policies and practices. It also said that the major issues of concern that the churches were urged to raise with the Government include: the infringement of human rights of asylum seekers held in detention for long periods; the recent legislation that takes away the power of courts to test the legality of detention; the lack of adequate family and counselling support services for those in detention centres; and the inordinate delays in the processing of entry applications.

Archbishop Barry Hickey, Secretary of the Catholic Bishops for Migrant Affairs Committee, said that Australians should not fear the stranger in their midst. He went on to say, `Mindful of our own diverse origins, we should respond generously to the plight of desperate people'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Senate very long in my short contribution to this debate on a number of migration Bills that are before the chamber. Senator Harradine was kind enough to acknowledge my presence at the `Welcome Stranger' conference in Sydney at the weekend. I represented the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and gave a speech on Friday evening. An essential part of that speech was an appeal that I made to the assembled audience for honesty and truth in the migration debate, and particularly the refugee issue. This is a huge issue: there are some 17 million displaced people around the world, not all of whom are, in the correct sense of the word, `refugees' as defined by the United Nations. Nonetheless, many millions of people are suffering right around the world.

PARA.TAB: I also made the point in that speech that Australia on its own could not solve all the problems but that we certainly could make a contribution. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) announced recently that, as part of our migration intake program, next year Australia will take some 10,000 people under the humanitarian category.

Unfortunately, my appeal on Friday night on behalf of the Prime Minister was not heard by one of my State colleagues in Western Australia. I note in an article in today's West Australian, under the headline `Free boat people', that the State Minister for Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs, Judyth Watson, has entered this debate. Unfortunately, Dr Watson is not particularly well informed on this refugee issue. It is a matter that I hopefully will take up with Dr Watson at a later time. But this is unfortunate, as one would expect people of her standing in the community at least to inform themselves before going public on issues of such great concern to the community.

The motivation for me to rise to my feet in this debate this afternoon came from some comments that Senator Harradine made in his contribution. I understood Senator Harradine to say that the individuals themselves should be the ones to determine who is a refugee and who is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I didn't say that.

—That was my understanding. If that is the case, I have taken Senator Harradine's interjection and the matter has been corrected. I want to go through the criteria very briefly for the purpose of the record. Every application for refugee status in Australia is examined on an individual, case by case basis. It is given extensive scrutiny. For an application for refugee status to be successful, it must comply with the United Nations convention in respect of refugees. Australia is a signatory to that convention and its guidelines are the ones that we, as a nation, use in determining whether or not a person is a refugee. We do not move away from that convention in any shape or form; nor should we move away from it.

PARA.TAB: If individuals choose not to put in applications for 12 months or more—and some boat people have—that might say something about their democratic rights. If such a delay does occur, of course it will in turn mean a delay in a decision being given on that individual's application. But every person coming to Australia, in a boat or by whatever other means, has the opportunity of lodging an application for refugees status. That application is given detailed scrutiny. If the person is unsuccessful with that application, if it is deemed not to comply with the United Nations convention, the application will be refused. The individual then has a right to apply for a review, and can provide a lot of additional information to the refugee review council. If the individual is not successful at this stage, then he or she will have to leave Australia, and only then. But the application may indeed be successful, as some 15 out of the many hundreds of applications with the Department and the review council were last week. The applicant will either win or lose.

I think the matter of whether or not Australia is sending messages overseas is one for other countries to determine. I think that one very strong message that should be sent to every part of the world is that in Australia individuals will not be allowed to select themselves for refugee status. The mere physical presence in Australia of a person seeking refugee status will not in itself be a criterion for approval of his or her application. I think honourable senators from all parts of the chamber would agree with what I am putting forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree.

—I accept Senator Teague's interjection. The Government has a responsibility to the people of Australia to control the program. It has a responsibility to each and every one of the people who are in the unfortunate circumstance of being displaced persons, and that responsibility is fulfilled by giving them the right to make an application and, if the application is rejected, the right to a review. It has cost the taxpayers of Australia a good deal of money to fulfil those obligations, particularly with the boat people.

PARA.TAB: My great concern in this refugee debate is not so much for the few hundred people who are held in detention in Australia or, indeed, for the 23,000 outstanding applications from people who are sitting out there in the community. My concern is for those millions of others, some of whom are truly refugees and have been determined to be refugees by the United Nations; for example, some 250,000 people who are sitting in camps on the border of Thailand and Cambodia. If we expressed more concern for those people and gave them more help, rather than expressing the concerns that were raised about the boat people, like Dr Watson did on the weekend, I think it would serve Australia's immigration program and our international obligations a great deal better.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Minister Assisting the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the debate on the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 and related Bills. The Bills are a very important part of the Government's expression, or the nub of the Australian people's desire, that we cope with increasing pressures on our migration program, whether in relation to normal entrants or, in particular, those who claim refugee status. In that regard the provision to make it impossible for applicants for refugee status to continue to delay assessment of whether they need to depart from Australia by simply deferring lodgment of an application for refugee status is very well timed.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is important as a matter of humanitarian concern that the status of those who claim to be refugees be determined in a reasonable time frame. That might be two to three months, but it certainly should not be extended for over two years, as has been the case in some instances. It is important to provide a processing regime which produces a better and more timely resolution and determination of the various claims that are made for refugee status.

I understand that the amendments in these Bills will also allow the Minister to determine processing priorities so that the processing of new applications for refugee status is not impeded by the existence of a backlog of unprocessed applications. Quite clearly, the Government wishes to eliminate any incentive for persons with no claim to refugee status to lodge ill-founded applications simply to achieve continued residence in Australia whilst awaiting processing of any other application.

Provisions have also been included to deter persons, primarily Indonesian nationals, from fishing illegally in Australian waters. I believe it is very important so far as our fishing industry, our quarantine laws and our maritime environment generally, is concerned—quite apart from illegal immigration—that we have a better regime applying to the incursions by foreign fishing vessels into Australian waters.

I know it has been a matter of some comment by various people that when these fishermen are put into detention or imprisoned, or put into custody of some sort, and are paid what to an Australian would be a very small weekly amount—that is, what would be a prisoner's entitlement in, say, Western Australia—the small gratuities paid can be a significant amount of money to the Indonesian fishermen who rather regard the whole matter, it is said, as something of a paid holiday in that respect. These people are then sent back to Indonesia and, as individuals, they have not suffered any great adverse economic impact as a result of the experience.

These amendments will render any crew member of an apprehended fishing vessel liable for the cost of his custody and removal from Australia. That seems to be a very sensible arrangement. The small amount that could be payable during imprisonment will be offset against the debt incurred for custody and removal from Australia. The capacity to confiscate fishing vessels, which affects the owner or the master of the vessel more than the crew members, and the imposition of gaol sentences will be increased disincentives for fishermen to fish illegally in Australian waters, and that must be to our benefit.

So far as business migration is concerned, there is a very real need to have a mandatory system of monitoring the real contribution to business activities of those who arrive in Australia under the business migration scheme, so the provision is very welcome. It is also linked to the fact that the Minister will be able to cancel permanent entry permits and entry visas of business skills migrants after their arrival in Australia if they do not enter into business activities which meet the objectives of the category or make a genuine effort to do so. I think that is over a period of three years. In that situation, I believe that Australians would expect that those who abuse this program would be politely shown the door after the situation has been identified.

There are also some provisions in the Bill which provide for people who make false or misleading statements or produce bogus documents or those with highly dangerous and communicable diseases or criminal records. Entry into Australia of all those sorts of persons is undesirable and the present section 20 of the Act defines those categories. People who fall into those categories are defined as illegal entrants unless they are excused for some reason or another.

The intention of the Government was always—and it has been asserted that this was the intention of the legislation originally—to bring about a situation in which a person who has committed a series of unrelated crimes but who has been sentenced in total to a period of 12 months or more imprisonment overseas should be categorised as a person whose entry into Australia is undesirable. That is a person to whom section 20 should apply. The amendment which has been put forward this afternoon will make this longstanding policy of the Government clear and overcome the narrow interpretation of the Federal Court without retrospectively trying to undo that decision.

The other important Bill that we are dealing with this afternoon, the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992, gives effect to the scheme for the registration of migration agents. It is designed to improve the professionalism and the standard of service of those who help and assist, as many do in a genuine way, those who require some assistance in filling out their forms and applications. It is a fact that amongst such agents are those who prey on certain ethnic communities and who are unscrupulous, at worst, or perhaps merely incompetent.

The complaints that many of us in this chamber are familiar with are now recognised in this Bill. It attempts to protect those in our society who are most vulnerable, who very often have a poor grasp of English, a fear of authority because of unfortunate experiences or the cultural or social situation in their homeland, and meagre financial resources. Even those meagre financial resources can be the object of greed of those with predatory instincts in some of those communities which prey on the vulnerability of such persons. We know of many cases in which applications have been lodged in a very tardy way, which adversely affects the application. There have been instances of these so-called migration agents holding passports as security and then demanding extra payment before they will return the passport. That is not an uncommon experience.

In considering this situation, the Government carried out very extensive consultation with ethnic community organisations, community based migration advice agencies and the legal profession, resulting in the scheme being developed. The central feature of the scheme is the establishment of the Migration Agents Registration Board, which will have the power to issue warnings, to suspend, to deregister, and to refuse applications for registration. It will comprise ministerially appointed representatives from industry, the legal profession, the ethnic community and the Immigration Review Tribunal. It will be chaired by the Secretary to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs or a nominee of the Secretary. Such things as investigations and application assessments will be conducted in the strictest confidence.

The code of conduct—a critical element of the scheme—is still being refined but it will be prescribed by regulation and, therefore, will be a disallowable instrument and will come before this chamber if honourable senators wish to examine it.

These migration agents are defined in a way which makes it clear—Senator Macdonald was not entirely happy with the distinction—that there is a distinction between such persons and lawyers who simply offer legal advice which is unrelated to the completion and lodgment of applications. If lawyers assist in the making of a visa or entry application under the Migration Act, they should register as migration agents. Despite Senator Macdonald's misgivings about this, it is interesting to note that in the House of Representatives on Tuesday, 2 June the Opposition spokesman on immigration and ethnic affairs, Mr Ruddock, put it beyond any doubt that the Opposition shared the understanding of the Minister in relation to the need for lawyers in certain situations to be registered and, therefore, the Opposition supported this particular provision.

I believe it was important that the Government should reduce the levy payable in those instances where, as Senator Macdonald said, a lawyer, as a small part of his or her practice, deals with three or four matters a year where people come in and ask for assistance. The levy of $1,000 would be too high in relation to the fees generated and the service provided to those few applicants who were assisted. Therefore, there are two different scales: those migration agents who deal with five cases or fewer will pay only a $100 fee; and the levy for those who deal with six cases or more will be $1,000.

I had representations from lawyers in Hobart who might do two or three cases a year. For them to pay a $1,000 registration fee would have meant that they would have declined to assist a person who came to them for advice in relation to the making of an application and help in filling out particular forms. That would have forced the work into the hands of those larger firms or migration agents who are prepared to deal with dozens, perhaps even hundreds, of cases and for whom the $1,000 registration fee would only be a small part of the costs of providing that service.
I believe that these Bills are very important as part of Australia's response to the need to regulate in a proper way the entry of those who come to this nation. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

—Can I ask the Minister to take a question on notice for further reply at a later stage? The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—Order! Before I call Senator Ferguson, I remind honourable senators that this is his first speech. Therefore, I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President, and my parliamentary colleagues. I can best express why I am here today, what I want to see accomplished for Australia and what I personally want to realise as a senator by simply telling honourable senators something of my past. I live near a small township called Weetulta. I am sure no-one here has ever heard of it, except perhaps for some of my South Australian colleagues. It is a two-hour drive from Adelaide and even most South Australians do not know it exists. In fact, it is home to just 10 people—forgotten people in many respects, certainly forgotten in terms of geographic equality.

PARA.TAB: The residents of many small rural towns to reach home have to drive over many kilometres of dirt road, their main road. If we need a doctor or a chemist for a sick child, the closest is 16 kilometres away, and we are more fortunate than most. As a parent, to ensure that child then has access to the necessary school curriculum and further education has become almost an impossibility without crippling financial outlays. For many rural families, it is an impossibility, and they watch the frustration of teenagers as they are unable to reach their education potential.

In today's highly technological age, it is a fallacy to believe that rural communities can survive without a higher degree of learning than has been necessary in the past. These children have as much right to access education as their peers in the city. The rural communities need in turn to access the knowledge for the future that their children acquire. But it is a sad fact that in 1992, in a country whose Government has christened it the clever country, we practise blatant geographic discrimination.

I remember my primary education at the Weetulta rural school, a one-teacher school with seven grades and no ancillary staff. There were between 15 and 19 students there attending at any one time. During the middle stages of my years at that school, there were only three students in year 7. One of those students was my elder brother, now a senior partner in an Adelaide law firm; the second student is now the head of the psychology department at Melbourne University; and the third became a triple certificated sister who topped the State in her final year. In another year was my younger sister who later studied at the Conservatorium, and as a Bachelor of Music is now head of the music department in an Adelaide school.

I could list many similar examples of such career successes from my fellow pupils during my years at Weetulta. But in the early 1970s that school closed. One of the spurious reasons given was that students of small rural schools were being deprived of opportunities to compete and succeed. Compare the successes from the many small schools such as Weetulta with the plight of rural students today where in rural South Australia only one in 20 is able to access tertiary education or training.

This Government may talk long about equal opportunity but it falls far short of this when it comes to reality. Just two hours out of Adelaide there is another Australia—an Australia which blatantly, through government policies, is denied equal opportunity for its citizens. That discrimination has increased significantly since I was a boy—not decreased. I think politicians, being pragmatic, have described it as a rationalisation of expenditure. But that is not what it is. It is actually the systematic devaluation of the rural communities of Australia. And what hypocrisy from a Labor Government embarking on overseas tourism promotions which describe rural and outback Australia as the `real Australia', while at home it does its best to make life difficult for those who live and work there.

As a farmer from a long line of farmers, as a father who has watched three talented daughters make sacrifices in the name of further education, and as a committed Liberal, I was no longer prepared to sit back and let others fight the rural battle for me. So I say: here I am, the first rural South Australian senator for many years. I am here principally because I want to halt what is happening to rural Australia and I want to help turn policy around. I want recognition, especially in Canberra, that families outside the major cities are not second-class citizens. They have the same right for their basic needs to be met as do city dwellers. The cities need rural communities for what we produce as much as we need them for what they manufacture and assemble, and therefore we should be treated as equals.

Surely there is not a senator in this chamber today who can condone a situation like one I heard of recently in South Australia. The principal of a rural high school broke down in tears. He had a son who was clever, a son who wanted to access a university education. But this father, with other children to support, with no family in Adelaide for his son to live with, could not afford the large outlay that his son would need to rent accommodation and study away from home. The amount of Austudy available just did not provide for even the basic necessities. So another rural teenager does not reach his potential, either for himself or for what he could have contributed back to our society. Who knows what we are losing for Australia because of this geographical discrimination.

I am a religious person, and I am proud of the values that religion has instilled in me. But nowhere have I come across anything to suggest that God has signified that the educated should be congregated in the cities. Yet here we have a government playing God with people's lives and making just that assumption. I do not believe that government has that right.

The other assumption that the present Government especially has embraced is that rural communities are not really poor: they are just pretend poor, or so temporarily poor that they are not worthy of understanding or more than token levels of help. Let me tell honourable senators from hard and at times heartbreaking personal experience that the sporadic good times no longer make up for the many bad. They did at one time—of course they did; that is, before the constant low commodity prices, before the long run of high interest rate years, before vastly increased government taxes and charges, and before the unfair trading practices of the United States and the European Community.

I suppose that, keeping a very essential sense of humour, I can sum up life on the Australian farm with the story of a farmer who won $1m in X lotto. When asked, `What are you going to do with all the money?', he replied, `I guess I'll probably just keep on farming until it's all gone'.

For all of those reasons, my commitment to redefining the place of the rural community in the formulation of policy in Canberra is total, as is my commitment to Liberal philosophies. To me, Liberal philosophies are about the kind of Australia we want for our families to live in and for individuals to achieve in. It is vitally important that we encourage the individual at every level, that we reward exceptional performance and that we support and encourage those who want to work harder in order to produce more and earn more in whatever field they work in, from the factory floor to the executive suite.

Being Liberal is not about winning for the sake of winning. It is about winning to deliver an industrial lifestyle conducive to individuals having the freedom from government and union shackles to succeed in their place of work. It is about winning to deliver taxation reforms—bold and controversial—so that families take home more of what they earn, with the choice of whether to spend or save. It is about winning so that our society can be economically restructured with fairness, right away from the excesses of the 1980s where so many suffered because of the actions of a few; where evil did, for a time, triumph over good; and greed triumphed over commonsense.

The two words which drew me into the Liberal Party in the first place—`freedom' and `family'—are still the core of Liberal policy development. To me, as I determined to seek preselection for the Senate, it seemed they were, unfortunately, also at the very core of Labor Government policy, but that it was bent on their destruction. The freedom of choice to exercise one's rights is surely so fundamental in a Western democracy that I cannot come to terms with a government which supports and encourages compulsory unionism; destroys the basic right of freedom of speech by banning political advertising; and now intends to conscript by legislation the payment of wage increases through increased superannuation contributions by employers. That is not government in the best interests of the people.

We have not seen government in the best interests of the family unit either. I am prepared to wear the hat of `old fashioned' if that is what it takes to fight for what I sincerely believe is the soul of any community—the family. My family is here today. They mean a lot to me, and their support and encouragement are vital to me. I do know how fortunate I am to be part of a happy family unit. But I also know that I am delivering this speech against a backdrop of family unit disintegration right across Australia. Every welfare organisation in the country is indicating that marriage has been one of the most catastrophic casualties of the present recession. A lost job, the colossal stress that goes with it and, in many cases, also the loss of the family home have created tensions many previously happy marriages have just not been able to survive.

As we know from the horrific youth unemployment statistics, many families are trying to cope with a double blow as their children leave school, often to join their parents in the lengthening dole queues. I looked at the bankruptcy statistics in the light of the welfare agencies' comments and I wondered how many of the 13,556 bankruptcies in the first nine months of the 1991-92 financial year will translate also into broken marriages and how many more distressed children there will be.

Much of the blame for such disintegration of the family unit lies at the feet of Labor economic policy. I strongly believe in, and will fight for, a taxation system which recognises and even displays a preference towards the family unit. I have long admired John Howard's stance on this issue and agree totally with him that a taxation system which is neutral when it comes to family dependence is economic purity gone mad.

Those who support members of their family should get taxation help for doing so. If we believe in the value of the family unit in our society, it is not enough just to say so. We have to act to help to preserve it in policy formulation across all areas of government. That has been totally ignored. The subsequent erosion of that unit during a decade of Labor has been substantial. It will not, unfortunately, be able to be redressed quickly but it is important to me, what I believe in and what I was brought up to believe in, to ensure that it is redressed.

It is quite obvious to me that the breakdown of the discipline of family life has been a contributing factor to the many social problems confronting society today. It is only too obvious in South Australia. As everyone in this chamber knows, unemployment in my home State is at 12.4 per cent, the worst of any State and the worst State figures on record—all this from the joint efforts of a Federal and a State government which claim a policy of social justice. In the past decade of Labor rule in South Australia, all social justice has meant is the delivering of more overwhelming poverty to a greater number of families, destroying many in the process.

Forty-five per cent of our youth in South Australia are unemployed. The rural youth unemployment statistics are often hidden because of those young people who have, frequently in desperation, left the area to try their luck in Adelaide. But most do not have the luck to find work there either.

There are many other factors of Federal and State Labor rule in South Australia which indicate the destruction by poverty of the family structure. Housing Trust waiting lists have almost doubled to more than 43,000 since John Bannon became Premier. Rent relief recipients have increased by a massive 72 per cent—many of those are single parent families. South Australian child-care centres say they receive between one and 10 cases each day of children who are either malnourished, inadequately clothed or otherwise neglected. I have been told that child poverty in South Australia would now exceed some 30,000, courtesy of a party which promised us no child poverty by 1990.

Our electricity is the second most expensive after Western Australia. A national report indicated that our public transport system was the worst of any State. Our State taxes and fees under Labor have increased at a rate 34 per cent faster than Australia as a whole. Is it any wonder that so many South Australian families are just not surviving as a unit with all those pressures and abysmal and expensive government charges and services? As well, Labor policies—or perhaps I should say a decade of lack of policy—for our manufacturing structure have left us the most economically vulnerable State. Economic research indicates that we are the State least likely to weather any further economic downturn and the State least likely to be able to recover significantly as the economy picks up. We have both Federal and State Labor governments to thank for this mess.

It seems to me, as I have watched from the political sidelines for a number of years, that Labor governments have quite forgotten or deliberately ignored the fact that their policy formulation is affecting lives, children and families. I want in my time in the Senate to make a significant contribution to try to aid those families across Australia.

I thank honourable senators on both sides of the chamber for the warmth of their welcome to Canberra. It certainly makes up for some of the sub-zero mornings that I am not quite used to. As a new senator, I would hope to live by a saying that has stayed in my mind for many years: `The service we give to others is the rent we pay for our place on earth'. I certainly hope no-one here ever has cause to tell me that my rent book is not up to date.
Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 May 1992, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health, Housing and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill is an omnibus Bill that includes provisions that relate to all aspects of the health, housing and community services portfolio. It amends the First Home Owners Act by correcting an anomaly in the Act whereby the failure of a person to supply a tax file number resulted in the suspension and cancellation of all future benefits irrespective of whether the tax file number was supplied at a later date. The amendment will allow for the resumption of payments immediately upon the tax file number being made available.

PARA.TAB: The Bill also contains a number of measures to improve the administration of nursing homes. Nursing home residents will now be able to use up to two days of their 28 non-hospital leave days immediately prior to entering the home. I have been arguing for this amendment for some time, for the sake of both the incoming residents and the staff. On too many occasions I have been told by directors of nursing, especially in small rural nursing homes and in rural areas, that they have had to fill empty beds almost before they were cold from the previous residents; otherwise the nursing home would lose money.

I see you smile, Madam Acting Deputy President. I will give one example of a small rural nursing home which was so strapped for cash that a brother passed away and his sister was admitted to the nursing home that same afternoon because the nursing home is only paid for the day people go in, not the day they go out. I asked whether money could be paid for the day on which the person died so that at least his sister did not have to go into his bed that night, and so that the staff could accommodate the fact that somebody they had been looking after for years was no longer with them when they changed shifts.
