Thank heavens the Government has found a way, without cost, of allowing residents two days notice in which they can fix up their affairs before they go into the nursing home, and so that at least the staff have time to accommodate the fact that one of their residents has passed away. The amendment introduces the kind of flexibility we have been asking for for a long time. I commend the Government for getting around to it at this stage in a way that is acceptable.

The Bill also allows the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services to provide prospective purchasers of nursing homes with information about the Commonwealth benefits advanced to that home. Previously, information was not able to be divulged and the proprietor was able to underspend the benefit and sell the nursing home before the overpayment could be identified. This amendment allows the purchaser to be fully informed about the sale.

The secrecy provision amendments enable the Department to divulge key information to receivers or liquidators. The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) has claimed that the current secrecy provisions have limited the Department's ability to deal effectively and cooperatively with receivers or liquidators, making it difficult to act in the interests of nursing home residents. Given the appalling number of nursing homes—and we are led to believe it is as many as 50 per cent—in or nearing receivership in Victoria, it is no wonder the Minister has introduced this amendment, but the Minister still refuses to acknowledge that there is a problem, particularly in private nursing homes in Victoria.

The Government has a responsibility to ensure that sufficient funding is available. If it restricts the funds available to nursing homes from other sources, it is up to this Government to provide greater funding so that the financial stability of the nursing homes is ensured.

In the last Budget the Government announced a new personal care assessment instrument, the PCAI, for hostel funding. Earlier this year when the restructure of the personal care subsidy was passed by the Parliament, I recall expressing my concern about it. The Minister said that the restructured personal care subsidy would provide clear incentives for hostels to provide care for more highly dependent and confused people, consistent with the objectives of the aged care strategy.

The new arrangements have only been in place for six weeks and, unfortunately, already they are causing considerable anxiety in the industry. There are concerns about the increased administration involved; about the fact that hostel residents who have good ADL skills—activities and daily living skills—but behavioural problems will often not qualify even for the lower subsidy; and about the fact that the hostels that were receiving dementia grants believe that the cut-back in those grants will not be offset by any increase in the personal care subsidy.That issue was being raised with me a long time before the PCAI was introduced.

The real concern is that reduced subsidies will lead to inadequate care for those who need it and those whom the Government supposedly targeted with this change. I call on the Minister and his Department to examine the recently introduced changes and ensure that they do not inadvertently lead to a lower standard of care in hostels.

A number of changes related to the health portfolio are also included in this Bill. These include changes in payments and penalties related to pathology services and the investigation of overservicing in radiology. They extend the pharmaceutical benefits safety net scheme to include medications dispensed from State hospitals. I might just add that this is well overdue. They also make a number of technical amendments to acknowledge that health funds are now known as registered health benefit organisations.

The Bill also removes the obligation for details of the borrowings by the Hearing Services Authority to be laid before both Houses of the Parliament. The only reason advanced for this change is that the borrowings of the Authority are small and that the paperwork involved in tabling the details is not warranted. The coalition thinks differently and feels that, unless a more substantive reason is given, the right of the Parliament should be upheld. Consequently, we will be opposing this amendment.

The Bill also makes a number of amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act, including the widening of the definition of `therapeutic device' to include devices such as breast implants. Unfortunately, I do not have time to go into these other amendments. However, they are sensible and are supported by both the therapeutic goods and devices industry bodies.

I cannot let this opportunity pass without raising another issue in the therapeutic goods area which I have been following for some time—the issue of the grandfathering of imported therapeutic goods products. A company in the heart of the Hotham electorate in which my office is situated has had to put off workers. This company has had long running problems with therapeutic goods administration. Headway seems to have been made in respect of export certification, but there are still problems with imported products. The parent company wants to put a large sum of money into capital investment in Australia. However, it is reluctant to do so because of the tardiness in dealings with therapeutic goods administration.

The grandfathering of imported goods has been an issue of great concern. The original promise was that grandfathered products would have to face the same stringent tests as therapeutic goods produced in Australia. I think the first promise was made in August 1991. The Minister then promised that it would be done by 15 February this year. I have been advised that those importers were written letters in April and told that this would be done in the next six months.

In the interim, firms which produce in Australia are competing with therapeutic goods that may not reach the good manufacturing practice standards. That is not good enough. Can the Department and the Minister explain why, almost a year after their first promise, we are still waiting for this to happen? I urge the Minister and the Department to ensure that everything is done to speed up the process of considering these grandfathered products.

One of the other major amendments in this Bill relates to the reversal of the co-payment. In the Budget last year the Government announced the introduction of a $3.50 co-payment for general practitioner consultations. Following an outcry from the left wing of the Labor Party, the introduction of the co-payment was delayed until 1 December and the co-payment for bulkbilled GP consultations was reduced to $2.50. The co-payment was a sensible way to prevent overuse and over-servicing.

Co-payments increase the incentive for patients to use services judiciously and to monitor potential over-servicing by medical practitioners. However, the co-payment lasted only three months before it became a victim in the Labor leadership battle between Hawke and Keating. Keating promised that, as leader, the co-payment would be dropped. His targets were those left wing members of the Party who had vigorously opposed the co-payment. Senator Crowley was used as the Keating messenger in the leadership struggle to deliver the vote grabbing promise. The promise had nothing to do with the effect that the co-payment was having on access, equity or cost; it was politics all the way.

I feel sorry—if I can feel sorry—for Minister Howe who had worn all the odium of introducing a co-payment. He was sold down the tube for a couple of votes—talk about a few shekels of silver! As he promised, Keating scrapped the GP co-payment to pay back a couple of supporters for the few votes he needed to scrape into the leadership. I bet there are some people on the other side who maybe wished they had never done that.

In a joint statement issued by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Brian Howe, it was claimed that the reversal would remove the uncertainty about the health system and address concerns about a decline in bulkbilling. However, Minister Howe knew this not to be true. When asked at a doorstep interview whether the co-payment was a burden on the health system, Minister Howe refused to acknowledge that it was because he knew it was not. His Department had figures showing that the co-payment was not a burden and that there was clear support for the Medicare change.

Four surveys commissioned by the Department and conducted by AGB Australia were dragged out of the Department and supplied to me during Estimates committee hearings. The total cost of these four reports was $87,000 and the findings make very interesting reading. Of those surveyed, 82 per cent thought it was important or very important to restrain the costs of Medicare. Of the three options open to people to keep down the increasing costs of Medicare, 23 per cent preferred an increase in the Medicare levy; 6 per cent preferred an increase in personal income tax; 59 per cent preferred a $3.50 co-payment; and 13 per cent did not know.

In addition, 53 per cent thought the co-payment would be effective or very effective in keeping the costs of Medicare down and 27 per cent thought it would be ineffective or very ineffective. Further, 66 per cent of people said they would not go to another practice in their area if their present GP introduced the $3.50 fee and another did not; 31 per cent said they would change. Seventy-three per cent of those interviewed said that a co-payment would be more acceptable to them if it were used to cover the costs of improvements to health services.

Few doctors reported discontinuing bulkbilling for pensioners or other card holders. Also, 28 per cent of consumers thought that an extra charge would make them consider more carefully about going to a doctor; 25 per cent of people said that they were likely to review their decision to visit a GP for minor needs but were unlikely to do so for major medical needs; and only 5 per cent said that they may review their decision to visit a doctor for major medical needs.

The survey also revealed that despite some concern expressed about recent changes to Medicare, support for specific changes made to Medicare remained high, with a large majority judging the co-payment as reasonable to encourage more careful use of medical services. It found that the co-payment was in line with community attitudes. Seventy-two per cent of people said that patients should make some payment themselves towards the cost of a visit to a GP. Poor Mr Howe! He was on a winner—people agreed that they should be charged. But he has to give it up for a couple of votes because Mr Keating did a deal. I would like to have heard his comments behind the scene.

There is only limited information available on the effect of co-payment on the billing practices of GPs. But on the information available, there was an initial decline in the number of GPs bulkbilling of 3 to 4 per cent. Over the three months that the co-payment was operating, this decline in bulkbilling was reversed. When the co-payment was dropped at the end of February 1992, the proportion of claims bulkbilled was back to the figure prior to implementation.

All those screaming left wing Labor members could not wait to see the effect of the co-payment on the health system. Not only was there significant support for the co-payment, but the effect on bulkbilling was almost negligible. Scrapping it cost Australians hundreds of millions of dollars. The loss of savings in 1991-92 will be in the order of $71.6m; in 1992-93, $277.4m; in 1993-94, $480.4m; and in 1994-95, $666.6m. Ask all those medical researchers, all those people who want equipment and all those hospitals which would like some of that money—they will tell us that the public agreed with the co-payment. The price of $71m this financial year will go up through the years to $666m in 1994. That is what those votes for Mr Keating cost.

According to figures supplied in Estimates, the co-payment had saved $70.1m in the three months that it was in operation. All Australians are paying for this decision and for the votes of a couple of left wing Labor members. Even the Industry Commission in its report Exports of Health Services, which was completed in December 1991 but not released until after Prime Minister Keating and Caucus dropped the co-payment, supported the use of co-payments for health services. So another interesting point is that the report was not released until after the co-payment was dropped.

There was no legitimate reason for co-payment being dropped. All the evidence suggests that it was operating effectively. As I said before, the only reason it disappeared was to pay a few debts for a few votes. I would like to ask the Minister: does the Department still expect to be able to provide Estimates Committee E with the figures on the real savings from co-payment over the three-month period it was in operation, and not just the pro rata figures based on the original Budget figures? These figures were promised by June—so the Department has a few days in which to do so. Finally, I move:

At end of motion, add ", but the Senate deplores the Government's failure to retain a price signal for medical services which is the major cause of over-servicing and overusage in Australia's health system.".

SPEECH.PARA: Another major issue in this Bill is the changes which relate to people with disabilities. I do not have time to deal with this matter. However, I am sure that my colleague Senator Tambling will cover it in detail when he speaks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even though I will not respond to Senator Patterson's analysis of the application and subsequent withdrawal of the co-payment, I do not want it to be thought for one moment that I do not disagree with her. I am sure the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who is at the table, will deal adequately with that aspect of Senator Patterson's contribution. Today I want to concentrate on the Health, Housing and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill, specifically its application to people with profound disabilities.

PARA.TAB: The Government has a long term commitment to achieving a better deal for people with disabilities, having begun the process of expanding opportunities in 1983 with a comprehensive review of programs and services—the handicapped programs review. The outcomes of this review culminated in the implementation of the Disability Services Act, which is recognised as being at the forefront of disability reform worldwide. Many of us took part in those consultations.

I remember with some pleasure the first occasion on which I saw a plane travelling from Melbourne to Perth with six or eight quite severely disabled people occupying a good half of the first-class seats. The people with disabilities coped with the trip perfectly well but, this being 1983, the flight attendants were quite unused to such an environment and reached Perth quite stressed, to my amusement. That would not happen today. It is perfectly normal, natural and acceptable, and quite common, to see people in wheelchairs and those with other disabilities making use of public and other transport. It is no longer a matter for amazement or even comment.

The introduction of the Disability Services Act was a historic first step in providing a framework for developing a range of support services, setting the scene for the achievement of increased independence, greater employment opportunities and fuller integration into community activities for people with disabilities. Since the introduction of the Disability Services Act in 1987, significant progress has been made in many areas. The national attendant care scheme has enabled about 300 people with severe physical disabilities to return home to the community after a lifetime of institutional care.

Competitive employment training and placement services represent a successful approach to assisting people with disabilities to find, gain and hold jobs in the open labour market. This scheme has been expanded recently to cater for people with psychiatric disabilities. Individual supported jobs is a similar employment venture which assists people to undertake jobs in the open labour market. I am reminded here of a project, small in scope but very effective, which commenced in Geraldton about 12 months ago and has a splendid record of placing people with intellectual disabilities in employment in Geraldton and the surrounding area.

We have not focused on bricks and mortar and total support such as hostel accommodation. DSA funded services are concentrating on providing personal and in-home care to maintain people with disabilities where they are or where they would prefer to be. The availability of respite care is crucial. There has been a considerable development of advocacy and consumer rights under the DSA. These successes show us that people with disabilities can live and work in the community. They demonstrate that the objects of the Act are achievable and that the principles and objectives remain vitally important in guiding appropriate service options.

I have a number of extremely interesting examples. One concerns a young man whom we will call Ben. Before the introduction of the Act, he lived in a residential institution and worked in a sheltered workshop on the same site as the institution. He had little choice about his life. The staff made all his decisions for him. Most of the time he just watched television. His work in the workshop was very repetitive. He spent all day putting serviettes and plastic spoons into airline bags. He was paid less than $40 a week and the conditions were poor.

After the introduction of the Disability Services Act in 1987, which set out the principles and objectives that I referred to before, Ben was faced with a number of important changes in his life. The first was the relocation of the workshop to another site. For the first time, his home life and his working life were separate from each other, just as they are for everybody else.

The residential service was also required to provide support in community houses rather than in large, segregated institutions. Ben received help from officers of the then Department of Community Services and Health who helped to progressively change the service which was caring for him to meet the principles of the Act. With extra transition funding provided by the Department, one of the project officers who visited the institution was able to help Ben carry out his desire to live on his own in the community.

He was told about and helped to gain access to the new attendant care scheme, which is funded by the Department. Although he took some time to adjust to living in the community after spending so long in an institution with everything done for him every day, it brought forth new challenges and, for the first time, he was making his own decisions. It was a very exciting state of affairs for him. At the same time, he had the opportunity to try, to fail and to learn by his experiences like everybody else.

Ben was still in the sheltered workshop, but beginning to think that he should be able to get a better and more demanding job. The project officer who had been close to him throughout his transition to more independent living encouraged Ben to contact the service operated by Competitive Employment Training and Placement. He was provided by CETP with some clerical training, eventually finding a job in a lawyer's office. The service provided regular training to Ben to help him stay on top of the job and also help his co-workers to accept Ben for what he was—a person first and disabled second. His co-workers also realised that they would have to be on their toes to keep up with Ben because, like many people in similar circumstances, he was revelling in being able to finally show what he could really do. He now has a wide group of friends and has the financial independence and confidence to truly have control over all aspects of his life.

There are many other people like Ben who are still working in sheltered workshops in poor conditions for little pay who also want to have the opportunity to get real jobs and real wages and live a real life. Our current package includes 4,000 new employment places in Commonwealth funded services and 4,500 new places under the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service over the three years ending in 1993-94.

The Government recognises that for some people with high support needs, neither employment in the open labour market nor supported employment may be the most appropriate options at this time and a range of supports will be required. For people for whom employment is not an option, we fund community access and support programs under the independent living training class of eligible services. Experience has shown that people who are considered at one stage to have no employment options at all, in the long term, given the opportunity to make decisions for themselves, given the benefit of improved technology and given the benefit of individual support and encouragement, may develop the capacity to be employed either in the open market or certainly with some support.

Western Australia has a splendid example of people who have high support needs in Nulsen Haven, a facility for profoundly intellectually disabled people, some also with physical disabilities. I saw this facility over the years during the time I was a trade union official covering the workers in the facility. Ten or 12 years ago the only option for many of the people in this particular place was confinement, which was traditional and acceptable at that stage and the only way of protecting the individuals from the self-injuries to which, in many cases, they were prone.

Chronic head-bashers, for example, and incorrigible wanderers are now being accommodated in group houses in the suburbs. Supporting neighbours are properly prepared for the advent of these profoundly disabled people in their midst, who still have high support needs but are living as normal a life as possible. This was unthinkable before the Disabilities Services Act and the provisions under the Act subsequently.

The change of course has been a grave challenge to many families who had never thought of their disabled children, who are now adults, as being able to be independent to any degree. They were often convinced that such a change was impossible. Their children now have a new found dignity and are learning new skills. Some are attending classes and creating all sorts of things. They are also expanding their social skills. In many cases they are changing their behaviour quite dramatically simply as a result of being taken out of an institution and given some responsibility for their own lives and behaviour, with the support that they need. This process needs considerable resources, highly skilled staff and sincere commitment on the part of the authority concerned. I congratulate, not for the first time, the staff and management of Nulsen Haven and officers of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services for the way in which this process has been carried out.

I have friends with severe physical impairments and who are wheelchair bound for a variety of reasons, including progressive neurone disease. Some have been in institutions for most of their lives, their disabilities being so severe as to have been previously considered as manageable only in such an environment. They have grown to adulthood with other people making all of the important decisions about their lives. Their needs are principally for help with showering and dressing, some needing more attention, some less. Two were the client representatives on the council of the institution in which they lived when it moved towards transition and democratisation with a special grant for this purpose, including the services of a full time officer of the Department attuned to the potential abilities of these clients.

At this stage, a number of people from this facility at Rocky Bay in Western Australia have been housed in specially modified group housing. Some groups are self-sufficient to the point where an occasional visit from the community nurse is all that is required. At the other extreme, 24-hour care is required, and this has been shown to be feasible. The enhancement of self-reliance, morale and psychological well-being is immeasurable. Once again, it is a great credit to the authority, which has moved with the times, with the encouragement of the Department and the goodwill and very hard work of a number of officers along the way. Once again, to the departmental officers and, most of all, the clients, some of whom are more than capable of income generating activities, congratulations are due.

One young couple has just settled into a home provided by the State Housing Commission, built to their requirements. I called them this afternoon just for the satisfaction of hearing a happy, enthusiastic voice on the phone saying, `So-and-so's residence'. A bit of a chat brought forth the fact that they are extremely happy. When I last saw these people they were in the course of interviewing for their attendant carers. For the first time in their lives they have had the opportunity to choose the people who care for them. The young woman to whom I spoke said, `When you rang I had an armful of celery', and she extended an invitation for me to have a meal with them as soon as it is possible. This is an amazing change in their lives. They are not unique; they are amongst an ever expanding group of people who have been given these opportunities under the Disability Services Act which we will be amending this evening in an altogether progressive and advantageous way. I commend the amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health, Housing and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 contains some very significant measures, most of which are supported by the Australian Democrats. We are particularly pleased to see the withdrawal of the provisions relating to the attempt to introduce the Medicare co-payment, which the Democrats voted against in this chamber last year. We are also very pleased to see the extension of the safety net arrangements for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme to include medication supplied through the outpatient departments of State public hospitals. This measure also is very much supported by the Democrats and, indeed, we called for this at a previous time in this place. We also welcome the continuing inclusion in legislation of the recommendations by Professor Peter Baume in his Report on the Future of Drug Evaluation in Australia.

PARA.TAB: However, in my time tonight I wish to speak mainly about the provisions in the Bill which amend the Disability Services Act. I want to make it clear at the outset that the Democrats have generally been supporters of the Disability Services Act and its underlying philosophy, although we have repeatedly called on this Government to adequately fund this whole Act. On several occasions we have resisted Opposition amendments similar to some of those which are before us tonight. However, I wish to flag at this point in time that, presuming agreement will be reached between now and when we get into the committee stage on the precise wording of the amendment, we think it is now even more important that we support the first amendment moved by the Opposition, as the Opposition has now indicated after due consideration that it will not be considering our amendment. We will deal with that in greater detail in the committee stage.

Perhaps this matter also can be dealt with in committee, but I note that we will not be supporting those Opposition amendments which actually relate to the inclusion of sheltered workshops in the Disability Services Act. We have stated that position consistently and will not be changing our minds at this stage. It is regrettable that we still have problems here. Obviously, the transition phase is difficult, but we do not believe what the Opposition is suggesting is the way that we solve these difficulties.

However, the main issue I wish to discuss tonight is the proposed changes to the objects of the Disability Services Act. The Bill proposes to alter the wording of the objects of the Act away from `ensuring' that people with disabilities have access to services towards `assisting' them to receive services. Regardless of whatever slant the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) and his Department might like to put on it, the words being proposed clearly represent a downgrading in the provision of services under the Act. In one swoop, we have gone from `to ensure that persons with disabilities receive the services necessary to enable them to achieve their maximum potential as members of the community' to `to assist persons with disabilities to receive the services necessary to enable them to work towards full participation as members of the community'. There is a very big difference.

The Government has been giving us mixed messages about these changes. First of all, when we inquired we were told that they were minor, they were superficial and there was really nothing to worry about. But, as we looked into this more and more, there came the realisation that they certainly were not minor or superficial and there was nothing to worry about. Indeed, in the Standing Committee hearing on this Bill Senator Tate himself conceded that the changes were, in fact, significant.

I do not care how much the Government now wants to play this whole issue down, but if we put those changes together with some of the internal memos we have seen from the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service—and these were available to us in the Standing Committee on Community Affairs—it is very clear that the aim of these changes is to allow the Government, and in particular the CRS, to move away from a commitment to `ensure'—within financial constraints, of course—and that there will be a downgrading in the provision of services to people with disabilities.

I stress that statement, `within financial constraints' because the line that the Government is running is that it needs these changes because the legislation as it stands could be construed by the Federal Court as conferring an entitlement to service which could have a major budgetary impact. I ask the Minister, in his summary of the second reading debate, to explain to us whether, indeed, there is legal advice and, if there is, could he please table that advice.

We believe it is entirely speculative as there has been no such decision by the Federal Court. It is by no means certain that the Court would arrive at such a decision anyway, especially as it is clear from section 35 of the Disability Services Act that there is a limited appropriation available for the Act. It might be wiser to wait for such an occasion to arise and put up a good argument before the Court, rather than change the objects of the Act and risk sending a contentious, unacceptable and very unsettling and upsetting message to the disability community.

Also, it is obvious in any area where the Government provides services that there are finite resources. Decisions are made every day about who gets priority of access and who waits on which list. Indeed, that also goes for the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service, which has a waiting list for service. As Senator Tate acknowledged in the Senate Committee, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal already takes into account the issue of available resources when reaching its decisions.

Members of the disability community understand this. Although, of course, they constantly argue for a greater overall level of funding, they certainly understand that there are finite resources, which means that not everyone who is entitled to a specific service will receive it immediately when it is actually needed. But they do know that the objects of the Act, as they presently stand, recognise a clear commitment from the Government to provide services for people with disabilities.

These changes give a signal to people with disabilities that the Government no longer feels the same level of obligation and that it now wants to offer a lower standard of commitment. I believe that these changes quite clearly do not favour claimants to service under the Act and that they reduce the onus on those administering the Act. It is obvious that claimants will have fewer grounds to appeal. I can only say that the tone of one of the CRS memos presented to the Committee, which spoke of having difficulty with wilful decisions of the AAT, suggests to me that this is precisely what these amendments are intended to do.

I am also concerned that this change is designed to enable government to move certain services for people with disabilities further away from being public services, more towards being private or business oriented services. I believe this approach is inappropriate, undesirable and certainly unnecessary in this area. Unfortunately, it seems to be a fashionable article of faith among some senior managers in the Public Service that a so-called business oriented approach can apply equally well to the delivery of services such as these as it does, for example, to the supply of electricity. The Democrats do not accept this line of thought. We reject the Government's attempts to advance such a flawed approach by undermining the objects of the Disability Services Act.

I also point out—and I will be asking the Minister for his opinions on this—that, as the States are expected to develop their own legislation complementary to the Disability Services Act, what we are doing tonight could have repercussions on the delivery of services within the States. I ask the Minister whether he could respond to this aspect of those changes in the course of this debate.

Although the changes to the objects of the Act have significance beyond the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service, it was CRS workers, through the Public Sector Union, who brought this issue to the notice of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. The PSU was concerned that the CRS management was looking for ways of being able to reject those clients who might cost money, and that the changes in the objects of the Act meant there would be no reliable safeguards to protect people with severe disabilities who could not pay for their rehabilitation.

Janet Braithwaite, the Executive Director of ACROD, in giving evidence to the Senate Committee, was quite clear that people with severe disabilities were not getting the service from the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service that they used to get. She said in her evidence:

SPEECH.PARA: We share the concerns. . . about CRS turning into a business venture concentrating on compensable clients and turning its back on more severely disabled clients. This is not what the mission of the CRS should be.

Mrs Braithwaite was quite clear that members of her organisation, particularly those dealing with very severely disabled people, were concerned that the CRS was moving towards a more commercial orientation and that this was not the role that the disability community expected or wanted the CRS to fulfil. Indeed, why should the disability community accept that the CRS should become more and more commercially oriented? It is one thing to be efficient—we have no problems with that. However, it is quite another to become commercial for its own sake, with little concern for the impact on clients.

PARA.TAB: As far as I am concerned, the CRS does not exist to compete with private rehabilitation services; it exists to provide a service for those people who are not necessarily able to obtain service elsewhere. After all, it is the Commonwealth's rehabilitation service and it has a public responsibility.

I believe that the Government's desire to change the objects of the DSA reflects a change in attitude about its commitment to people with disabilities. I believe that, to some extent, this attitude is being driven by senior bureaucrats.

With regard to these very significant changes in the Bill, one could almost be excused for missing them altogether. There was no mention of them in the explanatory memorandum, nor in the Minister's speech. There has certainly been virtually no consultation on these changes—and that includes not just the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service or its clients but the wider disability community. The implications of these changes have not been spelt out.

A senior departmental officer confirmed this lack of consultation to the Senate Committee. In fact, this change has been so low profile that the Government has been, if not secretive about it, certainly not especially interested in talking about the changes until forced to do so. I suggest that, if the Government really was up front and quite happy to face the disability community on these issues, it would at the very least postpone these provisions in the Bill until the Budget session to enable people with disabilities and people within the disability community generally to become aware of it and to comment on it. I also want to place on the record my concerns about the attitude of the management of the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service.

Finally, as it seems that the Opposition is going to support the Government on this legislation tonight, it really is doing a great disservice to people with disabilities. Many disability organisations are still unaware of what is happening. I received a phone call today from someone on another matter. That person was totally unaware that these changes were being proposed and that they would be going through tonight. Once the community becomes aware, it will show its displeasure and anger at what has happened.

In terms of the Opposition supporting the Government, I accept that considerable debate and discussion has occurred. I understand and accept that there has been considerable debate in the Opposition party room. However, I point out to Opposition senators that this is exactly the process that we often use on particular pieces of legislation, such as the superannuation legislation. When is detailed discussion and debate acceptable, and when is detailed discussion and debate called something else? I will not go into that tonight and I certainly will not use any derogatory terms, because I believe that on this occasion there has been a very considered approach by the Opposition. I hope that by us now supporting fully its amendment, which we have been looking at, we will get some redress in this area by making sure that in the guidelines we will still be ensuring a service rather than just possibly assisting somebody to receive a service.

I conclude by saying that both the Opposition and the Government are sending out the wrong signals to the disability community by introducing significant changes without proper consultation. Neither should be proud of the fact that they are watering down a piece of legislation that many people with disabilities have, until now, seen as an important guarantee of their entitlement to the services that they need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Health, Housing and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 and particularly on amendments to the Disability Services Act 1986. It is indeed unfortunate that we are faced tonight with debating this matter under the guillotine. The fact is that the Australian Democrats and the Labor Party have seen fit to bring into the Parliament a guillotine which affects such vital legislation as this, and thus many of the issues which have been highlighted by Senator Lees and Senator Patterson, and which will be highlighted by other speakers to follow, have had to take place in such an abbreviated debate and in such a short time.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Lees mentioned, this is an issue which has received considerable party room debate by all parties and also has received the attention of a Senate committee in some detail. It is indeed a pity that some of the information that flowed to us after that Senate committee was not made available at the time of the committee.

In turning to the legislation, it would first be useful to run through some of the background to the proposed amendments and to outline the coalition's position on the Act since its implementation in 1987. The Disability Services Act, passed in December 1986 with the support of all parties, replaced the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974. The Act was accompanied by a statement of principles and objectives setting out the right of people with disabilities to individual respect, freedom of choice and fulfilment of their individual potential. A key element was the integration of the disabled into the community through increased independence and greater employment opportunities.

It was proposed that the Act would be implemented over a five-year period to 30 June 1992, during which time consultations would take place with people concerned with disability services. Then, in 1988, just one year after the Act came into effect, the coalition and the then shadow Minister for community services, Mr Ray Braithwaite, cautioned against too quick a change. He warned that it would take time to adapt. In 1989 Mr Braithwaite spoke about concern and confusion amongst relatives of people with a disability and service providers during the DSA transition period. The implementation of the Act presented considerable difficulties, not least because of the inflexible interpretation of the Act by bureaucrats, their insufficient depth of understanding of the legislation and their lack of skills to implement the requirements in both the government and non-government sectors. Other reasons included the uncertainties of funding during the transition period; fear and confusion among parents as a result of changes to concepts and principles; a lack of sense of community and understanding between governments and the non-government sector; and the almost continuous and massive restructuring of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services since 1984.

This shake-up has led to considerable tension with the voluntary organisations and a lack of continuity and consistency of departmental decisions. It has also left departmental staff less professional than required. Since 1989 the coalition has attempted to address these problems and improve the Disability Services Act. In November of that year Mr Braithwaite presented to the Parliament a draft Bill proposing amendments to the Disability Services Act. In November 1990 he presented a private member's Bill proposing similar amendments. In September 1991 he again presented the Bill, proposing the same amendments, but the Government provided no opportunity for fuller debate and acceptance. In April this year he presented the Bill yet again.

For almost three years the coalition, on behalf of people with disabilities, parents and service providers, has been pressing the Government to accept the fact that the 1986 Act is not immutable, that change is needed and that a greater degree of certainty and compassion are required in the administration of the Act. It is intolerable that the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) has left carers and people with disabilities so uncertain over the future of their services after June 1992 and what service guidelines will follow.
The architect of the Act, the former Senator Don Grimes, said in February of this year:

SPEECH.PARA: The principles and objectives that were set out in the disability services legislation in 1986 are as clear and as sensible as can be found in most places. But I must remind those involved, as I used to at the time, that they are but standards and guidelines to help in the development of programs to assist people to fill their development in society. They are no more than that.

But the Government, the Minister and the bureaucracy have set their own agenda, creating uncertainty and risking the lifestyles of so many disabled Australians. The coalition has continually urged the Government to amend the Act to provide more flexibility and more certainty to people with disabilities, their families and their service providers. We proposed that the guidelines be formulated and brought before the Parliament for debate, and amended if necessary, so that the criteria for funding of services would be clearly laid down.

PARA.TAB: We also proposed that the transition date—the period in which financial assistance for prescribed services and for upgrading prescribed services is payable—be extended to give existing services more time to adapt to the requirement of the DSA. Our amendments also provided for security of contracts between the Government and the service provider, and an appeals procedure. We also proposed that the service-type supported employment services be amended to include specifically work crews, small businesses, enclaves, individual supported jobs and sheltered workshops.

The Disability Services Act has opened up new options for people with disabilities, and, as a result, the Opposition applauds and approves. However, we believe that there is a need for services such as sheltered workshops, hostels, nursing homes and activity therapy centres to coexist with the new service.

The Minister has stated that he and his Department are examining alternative services for people with severe disabilities who will never be able to participate fully in the open work force. Until an alternative service is in place, we strongly believe that, if sheltered workshops were not an option, it would be denying many people with disabilities the right to work, the right to training, the right to gain living skills and the right to a choice. They would be sentenced to an existence of boredom and frustration at home, with the consequent stresses on their families and carers.

Last November the Minister outlined his blueprint for action, saying that he would amend the Disability Services Act. He told the ACROD conference that the transition date of 1992 would be removed but that he would require all types of services—including sheltered workshops, activity therapy centres and large accommodation services—to meet certain standards by 1995 in order to continue eligibility for funding. The Minister also stated that he would formulate and table the section 5 guidelines.

One of the major amendments proposed in this Bill recognises that the five-year transition period was not long enough to deal with the complexity of change required. The Bill removes the transition date and provides ongoing funding to prescribed services—that is, services in existence pre-1987, such as sheltered workshops, accommodation services and activity therapy centres—provided they meet minimum standards. Parents and disability service providers welcomed this amendment.

Proposed new section 14A(1) in the Bill provides a safeguard for those who believe that this amendment will take away any inducement on the part of services to progress and offer greater educational and training opportunities to people with disabilities. This section provides that the Minister may terminate funding to a prescribed service, presumably if it is not meeting required standards.

The Bill removes the restriction on funding for profit organisations. This allows the Minister to fund, on a case by case basis, services that are provided by other than non-profit organisations. Some organisations in the voluntary sector are concerned about this amendment and believe it to be unnecessary. The Minister states that it will assist in the provision of attendant care services. It should be pointed out that under existing legislation there should be no reason why non-profit organisations approved by the Minister should not engage in private for profit attendant care services in meeting service delivery needs in accordance with their contract with the Government.

Voluntary organisations such as the Endeavour Foundation provide immeasurable support to the disabled and their families. The Endeavour Foundation is 76 per cent self-funded; the Government's contribution amounts to 24 per cent. This figure reflects the determination and commitment of the volunteers and representatives of the Foundation who tirelessly coordinate continual fundraising projects.

The Bill amends the objects of the Disability Services Act to clarify that the disability services program and the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service are assistance programs that operate within budget constraints. For any government there is only so much money available, and there will never be enough to fund all programs to everyone's satisfaction.

As much as we would like the disability services program and the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service to be entitlement programs, in reality they are not and they cannot be. The CRS is covered by a separate set of guidelines called administrative procedures. The coalition seeks an assurance that the substantial gains criterion applies also to the CRS, for people with more severe disabilities, and that the proportion of people with severe disabilities receiving a service from the CRS will be maintained. However, we would also request clarification of proposed new subsection 3(2)(b), which states that due regard must be had for `the need to consider equity and merit in accessing those resources'.

It was interesting to note the consideration by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, its report and the dissent in that particular regard. We hope that this applies to the actual services provided and that all people with disabilities requiring a service will receive a service, but that those people with severe and multiple disabilities that may require substantial resources are still able to have access to those resources. I have noted the answers that were provided, with quite detailed statistical information, to the Senate Committee after the various committee hearings.

The Minister has stated publicly that he will formulate and table guidelines under section 5 of the Disability Services Act. However, they are not included in this legislation. The coalition believes that these guidelines must not be tabled as disallowable instruments. The coalition is concerned that people with less severe disabilities will be given priority over those with more severe disabilities because of the costs involved. I ask the Minister again to give an assurance, perhaps by way of an inclusion in the guidelines, that new services for people with disabilities will include a significant proportion of people with severe disabilities. The guidelines must be introduced into the Parliament for debate, amended if necessary, and approved.

We will be moving an amendment to this effect in committee, as well as a number of other amendments proposed in my predecessor's—that is, the shadow Minister's—private member's Bill in the House of Representatives. Finally, I would like to acknowledge the contribution made by Ray Braithwaite and his staff in the area of community services and aged care prior to his recent resignation from the shadow ministry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Health, Housing and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill. I rise to speak briefly on a very basic aspect of health care. My colleagues Senator Patterson and Senator Tambling have certainly covered some of the other areas germane to the Bill, but I wish to speak mainly about the right of Australians to exercise free choice in providing for their own health care. This right is being threatened by the proposal of the honourable member for Canning, Mr Gear, to take away the right to private health insurance and to create a Medicare monopoly. To achieve this he proposes a one per cent rise in the Medicare levy. I suppose that sounds gorgeous, but what Mr Gear does not state is that an extra one per cent on top of the 1 1/4 per cent that we currently pay is actually an increase of 80 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) may state that there are no plans for the nationalisation of private health insurance along the lines that Mr Gear proposes, yet last Friday morning, I think it was, I was listening to Mr Gear on ABC radio and he was quite emphatic when he stated that the Government is seriously looking at his proposals and that he has sympathy for them from both the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Mr Howe. Of course, Mr Gear is a key supporter of the Prime Minister, and it would be very wrong for us to dismiss the possibility that his objectives would come to pass, because he did say that the Prime Minister and Mr Howe had both PM&C—for whatever reason I do not know—and the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services looking at his proposals with great seriousness.

Of course, Mr Gear adopts the same divisive style when he speaks of the need for the medical profession to be properly pulled into line. Who is he to say who needs to be properly pulled into line? The health profession is doing an excellent job under very trying circumstances which are certainly being made no better by the utterances of Mr Gear and others in the Labor Party.

Mr Gear displayed the same stunning lack of logic when, once again, on radio on 27 May he had the temerity to blame private health cover for hospital queues when the continuation of a besieged and eroded private sector was keeping Medicare from collapse and saving some Medicare patients from even longer queues. How absurd it is for the honourable member for Canning to be blaming private hospital insurance for people waiting and dying on the queues. He should ask the State Minister for Health in Western Australia how public hospitals would get along without the 20 per cent funding that comes from private health premiums.

At the moment, the public hospitals are aching to have private patients because they get more money for them and they charge over the top. It is not the fault of the public hospitals. The administrators in the public hospitals are doing their best under extremely trying circumstances. But Mr Gear is simply proposing to make them more trying.

Neither is there fairness nor logic in stating that private funds are unpopular because Australians are leaving them. I have never heard anything closer to blaming the victim in my life. It is not surprising that younger and healthier Australians give away private insurance in the midst of a recession when they are given no incentive to maintain their private cover. Many people today are losing their jobs and Mr Gear seems totally and utterly unaware of that. But the reality is that they are losing their jobs, they are struggling to maintain their mortgages, and they are struggling to feed and clothe their families. Of course they will look at ways in which they can cut their family budget and, sadly, private health insurance happens to be one of them.

Indeed, under this Labor Government, a privately insured Australian pays four times for his or her health care: through insurance; through the Medicare levy; through the gap; and also through the general taxation that meets 80 per cent of the totality of Federal Government health spending. It must be remembered that the current levy is paying only about 20 per cent of the total cost of health. So people are having to pay more and more tax in order to cover the cost of health to any degree. Of course, the degree we are seeing today is in the form of queues, queues and more queues.

Of course, Mr Gear's solution for shortening the queues is to have people die at the end of them. That is what is happening today. We are seeing it time and time again. We are also seeing families having to take out personal loans to ensure that their loved ones get treatment in a private hospital. If that is the ideal Medicare system for this country, not too many people are enthused about it.

There is a real concern that the nationalisation of private health funds and all of the doctor bashing that goes with it will appeal to the Prime Minister, who is absolutely desperate to prove his traditional Labor credentials—I might add, without thought to the long term social damage that may result from such a move.

We can only hope that this Government will pay some attention to the results of a survey undertaken for the Australian Health Insurance Association. Of those surveyed, 48 per cent only were covered by health funds and 45 per cent by Medicare only. Nonetheless, 73 per cent of those surveyed wanted the choice of health fund and only 13 per cent backed the Gear solution.

In Perth, the percentage in favour of choice was 77 per cent and the percentage of those backing the nationalisation of funds was down to 8 per cent. Of those with incomes below $10,000 per annum, free choice had 73 per cent support. Sixty-five per cent of Labor voters, as well as 82 per cent of Liberal-National voters, supported free choice. These same people strongly backed the principle behind the health policy of Fightback, where tax rebates will be provided for lower income families and the elderly in order to assist with private health insurance payments.

Over 70 per cent of pensioners in this country are taking out private health insurance because they are in fear of getting caught in a queue. They cannot afford it. They get no assistance whatsoever from this Government, yet this Government is running around the countryside lying about the goods and services tax being added to health costs. That is nothing short of a lie. Health costs under Fightback are zero rated. Therefore, all the input costs that people currently have and will have in the future will be fully free of wholesale sales tax because that will be abolished, and the goods and services tax will be fully refunded. When people get a bill from a doctor, they will have the cost of the bill—whether it is $30 or whatever it is—plus zero GST, so the total cost of the health bill will remain at $30. It is an absolute lie to say that a goods and services tax will make health care more expensive.

These same people to whom I referred earlier strongly backed the Fightback proposals. Eighty-two per cent of those questioned, including 79 per cent of Labor voters, believe in the principle of the rebate, and nearly 90 per cent consider that this would be a positive incentive for self-provision. These straws in the wind show clearly that the Australian people want to have the choice and opportunity for self-provision, just as 40 per cent of those Australians who have struggled to keep their private insurance have annual incomes under $31,000. These are the very people most of whom this Government does not give any tax benefit to, and does not give any encouragement to, to take out private health insurance.

One may just as well ask, I suppose: where is the true conscience of Labor when, in the name of a sterile and unworkable ideology, it is prepared to tolerate and reward the 20 per cent of Australians who earn more than $52,000 each year but are prepared to rely solely on Medicare? It is those higher income earners who choose not to be in the private health insurance system that the Liberal and National parties will ensure pay their contribution because they, if they choose not to take out private health insurance, will be confronted with a tax surcharge.

I must add that, contrary to the Labor lies, those who are on pensions and welfare will not be forced out of Medicare because Medicare will be retained. As George Bush said a few years ago, `Read my lips'. Medicare will be retained.

Nationalisation of health funds will not make for better health care but will deprive yet more Australians of the health care they need. It is socialism run mad and there is absolutely no guarantee that it will not become a reality. It is about time the people of Australia expressed to this Government that they are sick and tired—no pun intended—of being pushed to the end of queues and not being able to get health services of a high quality when they need them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health, Housing and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill, which we are debating tonight, covers a number of areas. It has amendments to the Disability Services Act, the First Home Owners Act, the Health Insurance Act, the Hearing Services Act, the National Health Act and the Therapeutic Goods Act.

PARA.TAB: As the Opposition has been forced by the guillotine into curtailing the debate on and consideration of this very large and most important piece of legislation, I am forced by the vote of the Government and the Democrats to curtail my speech to just a few moments so I will only be able to express my concerns in two areas. Those areas are, firstly, the amendments to the Health Insurance Act and, secondly, that part of the Disability Services Act which increases the length of time for accommodation services, sheltered workshops, activity centres and other similar services to continue to be eligible for funding during the transition period while their services fall into line with the requirements set down by the Government.

The changes to the Disability Services Act have taken much longer to come about than the Government expected. It was always pie in the sky stuff that such an extraordinarily enormous change could occur in such a short time as five years. Many of the services for the disabled had been available for many years. It was not only the service providers concerned with their clients' welfare who found the changes disturbing and threatening but also the disabled themselves who feared leaving the protection of either their accommodation or workplace. We have yet to be sure that these changes will be for the better, as so many services have not yet progressed very far.

The five years has now been expanded and the Government has been forced to make available ongoing funding for those services which are moving towards change. Minimum standards, which are a far cry from section 10, were introduced in February 1991. It is those services that meet these standards with a promise for ongoing changes which will receive funding under the new transitional funding services. The Bill assures us that that transitional stage for review will continue perhaps every five years. This will enable these transitional services to slowly but surely move until eventually they go into section 10.

I have always complained that when this Government in particular brings in its legislation it does not provide guidelines to the Senate. This is once again the case. As we are all well aware, the guidelines are usually brought in as regulations. Regulations cannot be amended; they can only be accepted or rejected in toto. On this occasion, the Opposition believes that the guidelines should be included in the Bill so that they can be scrutinised, debated and amended, if necessary, in the Senate. We will be moving our amendment in that regard.

I now move to the repealing of the Government's co-payment legislation in the health insurance area. This is another amendment in this particularly large Bill. As we are all well aware, the need for this change has more to do with the change of Prime Minister than with the equity or the health of the people in Australia. Indeed, it has nothing to do with equity; it has nothing to do with the taxpayers' money being abused; and it has nothing to do with the health of the community. It has to do only with the change of Prime Minister.

After the Budget last year, we were informed that because Medicare was going broke there would be a need for a co-payment of $3.50. At the time, Mr Howe put forward a very reasonable argument: the patient should pay an up-front $3.50 for every medical service untaken by a general practitioner. It was to start on 1 November 1991. That amount was to be increased by $1.50 to a co-payment of $5 from November 1992. The estimated savings from the Budget—and this is in Budget Paper No. 1—were $163.9m for the year 1991-92 and $306.1m for the year 1992-93. That was quite a saving. When that was announced in the Budget, all hell broke loose in the left wing of the Labor Party. That resulted in the $3.50 charge being reduced to $2.50.

This is how the Labor Party works. It was nothing to do with the health of the nation; nothing to do with taxpayers saving their money; and nothing to do with the proper expenditure of the health dollar—where it should be spent and where the priorities should be. It was purely and simply to do with the votes to change from one Prime Minister to another. We all remember that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) succeeded. As soon as he succeeded, Senator Crowley publicly said that she was going to extract her price. As I say, this is how legislation is dealt with Labor Party style.

The change made a big difference to the Budget. Instead of a saving of $306.1m for 1992-93, the Australian community got a saving of only $33.1m for the three-month period that that co-payment was functioning. However, the original cost of advertising and informing doctors and the community at large of the $3.50 charge, then of the change in that charge to $2.50, and of the next change to no co-payment at all following the change in prime ministership, has been costed at $8.325m. That is nearly $8.4m thoroughly wasted on advertising that should never have needed to take place. In other words, the cost to the taxpayer of the change of Prime Minister was $281m.

In the three-month period when the $2.50 co-payment was in force, there was a saving through reduced services of $1.7m. We just have to remember that that $2.50 was a co-payment only when bulkbilling took place. We do know that at least $1.7m was saved in reduced services—obviously unnecessary services—because patients were not to be bulkbilled, would have had to pay $2.50 and did not see the necessity to go to the doctor to be quite as urgent as would otherwise have been the case.

As I said, in 1992-93 there could have been a saving of $281m of taxpayers' money. If the Government did not want to give back that money to the people, it could have spent it on the present hospital crisis. We must not forget what is occurring in the hospitals around the States. In a recent newspaper article, Mr Keith Wilson, the Western Australian Minister for Health, said:

SPEECH.PARA: WA'S public hospital system is in crisis and does not have enough money to maintain present services. . .
He said this just a week ago. The article continues:

PARA.TAB: He blamed the crisis on the lack of Federal Government support at last week's Premiers' Conference.
Conservative estimates showed that the hospital system alone needed . . . $50 million to make ends meet—

SPEECH.PARA: not to increase services, just to make ends meet—

PARA.TAB: He was also awaiting a report from a special committee set up to investigate the impact of serious underfunding of public hospitals by the Commonwealth.
Commonwealth funding to hospitals had fallen by 22 per cent since the Medicare agreement was signed eight years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet the Government is willing to waste $281m for a change of Prime Minister when that money could have been spent in the public hospitals in various States that are now closing hospital beds and have even greater waiting lists because the Federal Government is refusing funding to continue them. It is a disgrace that, for the sake of a few votes from the Left, the Prime Minister would allow this hospital crisis to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak but on two matters; the first being the Disability Services Act 1986. On 6 November last year I spoke on this Act and its failure to implement proposals within the five-year timeframe ending 1 July this year. I commend the Act in this regard but report that there has been little progress in the nine months since I last spoke. The one point that I want to emphasise to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, if not to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe), is that there is an urgent need to involve the parents and carers in the implementation process or at least listen to their concerns.

PARA.TAB: I know that some action has been taken in this regard but their concerns may not be those of organisations such as the Endeavour Foundation. When the Act was introduced into the other place I was appalled to read an extraordinary attack on the Endeavour Foundation by the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), when she trivialised the whole debate and talked about gold taps in the Endeavour Foundation's headquarters. Subsequently, she has had to backtrack because they were brass taps. She obviously showed her ignorance of the appearance of the two; she probably cannot tell the difference. Her attack on the Endeavour Foundation is no way to get compliance of the people that are delivering services.

The other aspect that I wish to refer to is the co-payment issue. As my colleague Senator Walters said, it had nothing to do with the delivery of health care. The co-payment was rescinded because the Minister had trodden on the ideological nerve endings of the troglodyte Left and Centre Left of the Australian Labor Party. It was all about power, the position of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and had nothing to do with health care delivery. If those opposite do not believe me, I quote from the second reading speech on the Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1991 made by the Minister, Mr Howe, in the other place on 20 August 1991:

The major problem facing Australia's health care system is the growth in use of medical services per person. This growth means that every 20 years the number of medical services per person doubles. That growth is not caused by Medicare. The national health strategy has shown growth has been occurring fairly constantly since at least 1976. The cause is an open-ended fee for service system underwritten by insurance—whether public or private. The result has been that, as doctors' numbers have grown, so too has the use of medical services.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat:
The cause is an open-ended fee for service system underwritten by insurance—whether public or private.
The Minister said that Medicare was not the problem. That was the Minister's argument last year. With this reversal it must be evident, even to the Minister, that Medicare has failed.

PARA.TAB: The starting point to confront the reality of where we are, and then to show how to get where we want to be, is to recognise what the problems are. The reality is that we have an unstable health care delivery system. The Minister would recognise that. The fact that he set up the Macklin inquiry should be enough evidence for that.

We have a hopelessly overworked and inefficient public hospital system starved of funds. One can quote the State health Ministers on that; even a Labor health Minister from Western Australia. We have a grossly underutilised private hospital system. We have the demoralised general practitioners, with massive oversupply and lowering standards. We have entrepreneurial exploitation of the Medicare system. I quote the Department. We have a rapidly declining level of private health insurance which is now 41 per cent in Australia. Incidentally, the level is 31 per cent in Queensland, my own State, where we have had a public health system for over 40 years. That is the bottom line. That is where we are going.

Medicare is in crisis. The Australian Hospitals Association, representing the over 600 public hospitals—public hospitals; no axe to grind—has joined with the Private Hospitals Association in Operation Hospital Survival. We all know there will be a $10 billion Budget deficit federally. All the State Budgets are in trouble. Where will the money come from to fix the public hospital system? Hospital costs are increasing at about 12 per cent per year. Capital expenditure for the public hospitals of Australia is decreasing: it is about 3 per cent, when we need at least 7 per cent just to replace what we have at the moment. The basic problem is Medicare itself. The Medicare levy brings in only 18 per cent of total health expenditure.

I am pleased to see Minister Tate here. He keeps bringing up this comparison with the USA. I commend to him a book called Health Insurance in Practice by William A. Glaser. It details the various health systems in the world. I commend it to the Department, too. I know that nobody has taken it out from the Library, though admittedly it was published only this year.

The difference between the Australian health system and the American health system is that there is no system in the US. One-third of the financing comes from employers as part of the employment agreement. One-third comes out of private funds. That leaves another third of the cost uninsured. There is an element of Medicare. American Medicare covers all retired persons. Medicaid is public welfare provided through an agreement with the respective states to cover the costs of chronically disabled and socially handicapped people. There is private insurance for individuals from non-profit and for-profit insurance companies. Then there are the unemployed, who are not covered because of their varying employment situations.

What there is of a non-integrated system in America has failed because employer provided health insurance automatically goes when the employee shifts his place of employment. Dependants lose automatic coverage in groups run at employer expense. To compare what occurs in America and then say, as Minister Tate did the other day, that the Opposition is trying to sell the American system to Australia is absurd. It shows a total lack of knowledge of the American health care system by Minister Tate and Minister Howe as well.

It is no good talking about solutions unless we know where we want to go. Peter Ellyard, from the Commission for the Future, at the Syme Oration at the general scientific meeting of the College of Surgeons a couple of weeks ago in Canberra, said that Australia always approaches problems when what we should be doing is deciding what our vision should be—what do we want out of something—and then attaining it. He gave the instance of Korea, where 10 years ago 50 per cent of children did not get to grade 12. It decided that within 10 years it would get the majority into grade 12 level education. Now 95 per cent of its children reach that level, eight years after setting the standard for where it wanted to be.

We have to do the same. We have to have a vision. According to the Oxford English Dictionary, `vision' is statesman-like foresight. We need statesman-like foresight from this Government. Better still, we as an opposition are providing it. The vision is that we should have a health system which enables people to choose their own doctor, their own hospital and their own health fund. To do this, we need flexibility between Commonwealth, State and private funding to accommodate change. Change will occur. It is the only constant. Change will occur no matter what we do.

The Fightback health policy will accommodate change by maintaining community rating, by providing tax credits and tax penalties to encourage private hospital insurance, by preserving a government schedule of medical fees but allowing private medical insurance to cover the gap between refund and fees, and by introducing co-payment as a brake to overusage and overservicing, just as the Minister said in November last year. We agreed. Introducing co-payment will provide a brake to overusage and overservicing. The Fightback health policy will also reform the public hospital system by privatising support services. Of course, this will be done in an environment where a whole range of major taxes will be abolished—payroll tax, petrol tax, sales tax, et cetera.

All health related services will be quarantined from the one-off price effect of the goods and services tax. With no GST on health spending and lower infrastructure costs, health costs should actually fall. Added to this will be competition, encouraged by ending the Government monopoly on medical insurance and allowing private health funds and other insurers flexibility in other private health cover, subject to appropriate prudential requirements and basic standards.

In summary, under Fightback health policy we can expect a challenge to the Australian people to accept responsibility for their own health care while demanding better access and better quality of delivery but keeping a safety net for the disadvantaged. It is a prescription for the future which should be acceptable to all Australians.

In an article in the Bulletin last week, Mr George Gear said that the Government had done nothing since 1983. In response to a question from Senator Patterson last week, Senator Tate agreed that there was nothing that could be done. He gave us a whole litany of things that the Government would not do. He said nothing about the vision and nothing about what we hope to achieve and how we hope to get there. Edward de Bono, of whom honourable senators would have heard—he is the man who coined the phrase `lateral thinking'—has produced another book recently in which he said, `The risks of doing nothing are greater than the risks of doing something'.
