TALK.START.PARA: —We have had a most interesting debate on the Health, Housing and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. Whilst there are many segments of this Bill which might deserve full consideration and discussion, I will confine myself to some remarks about the more general ideological claims that have come from the other side concerning the various merits of our proposals in relation to the health system available to Australians and those which are put forward by the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: I always find it very intriguing that the Opposition should speak, as Senator Herron just did, in terms of freedom of choice of doctors, hospitals, insurers, et cetera, when it is prepared to overregulate medical practitioners and to say to medical practitioners—the general practitioners who offer primary health care to all Australians—`You will not offer bulkbilling to Australians, even if you wish to, apart from those who perhaps have a pensioner card'. The disciples of free choice—the people who say that they want the ideology of choice in the health system—are denying to the providers of health care, the general practitioners in our society, the choice that they might want to make for any variety of reasons to offer bulkbilling to their patients.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can charge them as they like.

—No, the Opposition will forbid them. Senator Herron said that it will forbid them to indulge in bulkbilling. The Opposition is doing this because it wants to create a situation where, in a typical practice adjacent to another typical practice, if one practice offers bulkbilling the other will be constrained perhaps in the sorts of charges it might levy. Whereas the Opposition wants to take away that particular possibility on the part of doctors to offer—
—That is a lot of rubbish. You can charge what you like. That is absolute rubbish.
—Senator, the coalition is forbidding bulkbilling to doctors. In doing that, it is creating an environment where there is a lack of competition; when that occurs we get the AMA schedule of fees.
—Would you stop your stupid—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Minister, if you address your remarks through the Chair—

TALK.START.PARA: —If you stop her interjecting, I will—
—Minister, I am speaking. If you address your remarks through the Chair you will be protected from interjections.
—I will address my remarks through the Chair.
—Senator Walters, one or two interjections may be tolerable but a constant stream of them is not.

—I apologise for my outburst, Mr Acting Deputy President. The fact is that what we have on the part of the Opposition is the development of a scheme which will allow doctors to charge up to the AMA fee without the possibility of bulkbilling which, of course, would be a restraint on that sort of charging practice.

PARA.TAB: Under the Fightback proposal the tax system would be used quite markedly in order to transfer funds from ordinary taxpayers through to the private insurance funds. I will tell the Senate how that will work. By the offering of subsidies, tax credits and so on, the Opposition would effectively be using the tax system to subsidise private health insurance. That is the Opposition's scheme. How would the Opposition pay for it out of the tax system? Of course, the Opposition would cut the payments to the States by 5 per cent which would mean that they would be less able to fund public hospitals. In fact, the Opposition would simply be taking tax funds away from the public hospitals and putting them into the private health insurance funds; taxpayers' funds would be directed into private health insurance funds rather than into the public hospital scheme. That is exactly what would happen under the Opposition's scheme. That point needs to be made. There is no golden pot of money somewhere; it would all come from the taxpayers. The Opposition would subsidise private health insurance; we prefer to see the money going via the States into the public hospital system.

In so far as the provision of health care for Australians is concerned, there is no doubt that we have to look at the question of hospital funding. That has to be tackled and is being tackled. That is being looked at by taking account of the obvious fact that much of the need for future hospital services will be brought about as a result of the ageing of the population. That means that there has to be a closer link between acute care and community care, particularly care for the aged within our community; we need to integrate acute care, post-acute care, community care and care for the aged. That is the way in which we need to develop strategies in order to relieve pressure in the hospital system. The next Medicare agreement will not simply be a hospitals agreement—that would be far too narrow; the next Medicare agreement will provide the framework for relations between governments across the full spectrum of health and aged care strategies. That is a very practical and sensible approach and I am sure honourable senators opposite would agree.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1992CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (TARIFF CONCESSIONS AND ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1992CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The three Bills we are debating cognately now are the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1992, the Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1992 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1992.

PARA.TAB: The Bills are very different in various respects. The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill deals with a range of matters. Essentially it deals with the extension of the motor vehicle export facilitation scheme to manufactures of vehicle components; it deals with the duty free importation of components for the manufacture and repair of wheelchairs; it deals with developing country tariff preferences being extended to the former Yugoslav republics; it amends the definition of off-road vehicles and it clarifies high clearances for these; it removes duty paid on New Zealand tobacco products in line with the CER; it allows certain technologically more advanced, more efficient or more productive capital equipment which is not available from Australian manufacturers to be imported free of duty. There are other changes concerning steel products as specifically induced materials, duty rates for TCF, new tariff structures for bicycles and minor administrative changes.

I will not comment on those in any detail. I simply say that, in relation to the requests that the Government has, I understand, circulated in the chamber to amend schedule 1 of the Customs Tariff Act to take account of `changes in the status of countries and places which qualify for preferential treatment', I should say that the Opposition continues to support the schedule 5 request with regard to the name of Macedonia which the Government has decided to incorporate in its amendments to the Customs Tariff Act.

The shadow Minister for industry and commerce, Mr McLachlan, moved a similar amendment in the other place on 27 May. The Liberal-National coalition believes that the descriptive name of `former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia' is presently an appropriate name to refer to the former republic in that it does not prejudice present and possibly future negotiations on the name that will eventually be agreed for the former republic. I will not go into any more detail on that aspect either other than to welcome the Government's agreement with the proposition that we put in the other place and the concern that we expressed in the other place about the particular wording in respect of that at the moment very sensitive issue.

In that regard, I noticed today—and on behalf of the coalition I note with pleasure—that there appears to have been some forward movement on the question of the naming of the former Yugoslav republic in the last 24 hours or so. Some compromise appears to have been reached—or is in the process of being reached—between the European community, Greece and the former republic. The coalition certainly hopes that that will lead to a satisfactory solution to what has been a very tricky problem.

The main issue, though, in relation to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill is, of course, the introduction of a $12,000 tariff on imported used cars on top of the 35 per cent tariff rate. The coalition has been extremely concerned about this proposition right from the outset. I will explain briefly the reasons for that, and other colleagues of mine will be doing the same in this debate. I will move an amendment in committee in respect of this matter. Indeed, I now also move on behalf of the Opposition a second reading amendment, namely:

At end of motion, add, "but the Senate requests the Government to refer to the Industry Commission for urgent inquiry and report its proposal to impose a punitive $12,000 duty on the importation of second hand vehicles into Australia".

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important item and a very important issue. It has considerable relevance to the motor vehicle industry as a whole in Australia. It was for that reason that the matter was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology for inquiry and report. Indeed, that Committee reported today with a divided report. A very significant minority report has been submitted by my colleagues Senator Archer and Senator Ferguson. No doubt Senator Archer will refer to that minority report in his own remarks during this debate, and I will not traverse those remarks other than to say in summary that we are extremely concerned that the Government should take such a fundamentally important decision—namely, the imposition of a totally punitive tariff on used vehicles, a tariff of $12,000—without any proper inquiry, report and investigation into the issue.

PARA.TAB: We believe that the matter should have been the subject of urgent inquiry and report before any proposal of this nature was made. That is the basis of the second reading amendment that I have moved. That Industry Commission inquiry should look at a range of issues since we are dealing with an unusual situation. The whole issue arises because of the particular registration requirements that apply to used motor vehicles in Japan where in effect motor vehicles are unable to stay on the roads after something like five years due to the punitive registration and other arrangements applying there. As a result, there is a very large backlog, a very large pool, of used vehicles to find homes for around the world if they can be found.

We believe that that is a matter requiring investigation and report so far as the possible importation of them into Australia is concerned. We believe that the Industry Commission should be asked to assess matters such as whether car registration arrangements in Japan, to which I have just referred, accelerate depreciation of older vehicles, thus depressing their resale value, and the extent to which this may constitute an effective subsidy to Japanese car producers. The inquiry should investigate the potential impact of second-hand imports on the automotive industry in Australia. It should assess the potential impact on car prices, the impact on Australian consumers, and whether imported used cars under current arrangements would meet all design, safety and consumer requirements imposed on local producers and dealers. We are not on our own on this. It is strongly supported by the Australian Automobile Association, which represents more than five million motorists. No evidence has been brought forward to this Senate to indicate that there has been any proper investigation into this matter.

If the Government is not prepared to have the matter referred to the Industry Commission for inquiry and report, then on behalf of the Opposition I shall be moving in committee that the $12,000 tariff be removed. In the event that that is not carried—and I understand it will not be carried because the Democrats have indicated that they will not be supporting that amendment—then on behalf of the coalition I give the assurance that when we win government, whenever that may be in the next few months, we will as a matter of immediacy refer the whole issue to the Industry Commission for urgent inquiry and report. I will not pursue that matter any further at this stage as I know that some of my colleagues wish to speak on it.

I will turn briefly to the other two Bills—namely, the Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1992 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1992. These Bills implement changes broadly in line with Industry Commission recommendations on tariff concessions and they introduce anti-dumping and countervailing measures announced by the Government on 5 December last. Whilst those changes are welcome and are generally an improvement on the current position, they do not go anywhere near meeting the demands of industry; nor do they go anywhere near meeting or matching the coalition's policy.

The main Bill—namely, the Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill includes a number of definitional changes, including replacing the goods serving similar function test with a more appropriate substitutability one and revised procedures and time limits. In contrast, the coalition's policy announced last December—which was a confirmation of an earlier announced policy, but firmed up some of the additional details—would go much further than that. We would reduce significantly the inquiry period required in anti-dumping applications. We would reduce the prima facie case hearing to five days and we would reduce the preliminary investigation to 60 days, with provision for an up to 30-day extension in special circumstances. We would also take other measures which would result in a maximum period of 155 days, or 185 days in exceptional cases, rather than the present 225 days for the investigation as a whole to be undertaken.

We would also make the Australian Customs Service responsible for determining whether or not dumping is occurring, while the Australian Anti-Dumping Authority would be responsible for determining material injury. We would also extend the three-year sunset clause to five years. That is something which I note the Government has adopted belatedly. We welcome the fact that it has done so, despite its belatedness.

We would also allow for the exchange of confidential information between the parties in order to speed up the process. We would ensure that material injury tests would not require virtual decimation before action was available. We would also ensure that adequate resources are available to the ACS and the ABA to make the system operate as intended. In other words, we would make the anti-dumping provisions quicker, fairer and cheaper. That would of course provide long and short term benefits to industry and, importantly, to consumers.

Overall, we will not be opposing the Bills, but we will be moving amendments, which I will move in the course of my remarks. The main amendment that we will move will reduce the prima facie hearing stage from the Government's proposal of 25 days in this Bill—which is a reduction on the pre-existing arrangement of 35 days—to five days. We do not believe there is any necessity at all for the delay to be as long as 25 days. There have been complaints progressively over the years as the number of days for these hearings has been reduced and there has been the frequent claim that all concerned would not be able to meet these new timetables. In all cases they have been met without great difficulty in the long run, and we see no reason why that will not be the case this time as well.

In that respect, the Opposition has a second reading amendment to add to the end of the motion for the second reading on the Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1992. I move:

At the end of the motion add `, but the Senate is of the opinion that, in addition to the amendments to the anti-dumping and countervailing procedures contained in the Bill, the Government should move immediately to make the current inadequate procedures faster and more effective:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) by reducing the prima facie hearing stage to 5 working days;
(b) by reducing the preliminary inquiry stage to 60 days, thus enabling the imposition of provisional measures after 65 days instead of the current 125 days; and

(c) by facilitating much speedier hearings by running parallel inquiries by the Anti-Dumping Authority and the Australian Customs Service into the extent of injury and extent of dumping or subsidisation respectively;
thus ensuring that Australian industries are not immeasurably disadvantaged by unfair trading practices before remedial action is taken'.

In addition to that second reading amendment, I foreshadow that I will be moving amendments in the committee stage, in particular to substitute the five days for the 25 days. We will come to the details of that in the committee stage. I understand that the Democrats have in mind a similar amendment to that which we are proposing.

PARA.TAB: The other point of amendment that I will now deal with briefly relates to the compliance required in respect of applications for hearings. As part of the trade-off, I guess, for shortening the time to establish a prima facie case to 25 days, the Government is amending the legislation to require that dumping or countervailing applications must `strictly' comply with the approved form. Indeed, in the second reading speech the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: To keep processing time for anti-dumping relief to a minimum, the Government also considers it appropriate that the applicant for that relief provide sufficient information to enable a prima facie case to be established. The technical requirements of applications have therefore been tightened by clauses 12 and 13 of the Bill.

I must say that we are concerned about the proposition in the Bill to insert the word `strictly'. There is no definition contained anywhere, as far as I am aware, of just what `strictly' means. I understand that there have been problems with the use of the word in tax legislation from time to time because of the lack of definition. The point I make on behalf of the coalition is that it does appear to place a significant additional burden on the Australian producer and it provides at least technically, and I think more than technically, a convenient legal out for the importer on the grounds that the application has not been strictly complied with, whatever that means.

PARA.TAB: Some representations have been made to the coalition, and I understand also to the Democrats and the Government, on this matter. For example, we have had representations from imported food processors, or the raw material producers. The particular example I am thinking of involves pig producers, which is an interesting one to be bringing up at this time with the piggery debate that has been going on. There is a section in the form in which processors have to detail the effect on their business of the import. This means, in the case of imported processed food, that processors have to be joined in the action as they are the producers of like goods.

We are concerned about this amendment because if one takes the word `comply' on its own strict meaning, then presumably people either comply with the requirements or they do not. There is no half-way house. The Act, as drafted before this latest amending Bill, just talks about `comply'. We do not understand the reason for inserting the word `strictly'. We certainly accept the proposition that if the number of days for the processing of applications for dumping and countervailing is to be reduced, that material has to be provided to the authorities in the shortest possible time. We do not see that the word `strictly' adds anything to that. In the absence of an adequate explanation as to how the word `strictly' really does change it, and given the concerns that we have about the interpretations that can be put on the word, I foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment at the committee stage—and I think the Democrats have a similar amendment—to omit the word `strictly' from the Bill.

Those are the main points I make in relation to those Bills. I will not go into them at any greater length because I know that there is a long speakers list; we once again have the guillotine applied and we have only two hours to discuss these very important issues. It is an enormous indictment yet again of the Government for its mismanagement in terms of handling the business of the Senate and the disdain with which it treats the proper parliamentary process. I have covered the main points I wished to cover. I hope that we will deal with more of them, if time will permit, at the committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1992, first of all, in my capacity as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1992 was referred to the Committee by the Senate on 2 June 1992 for examination of that part of the Bill that sought to impose a $12,000 tariff on the importation of used cars in large volume.

PARA.TAB: The background to the proposal to introduce this tariff is that in 1987-88 large numbers of used cars were being imported from Japan. At the time, the Government sought to restrict such importation by introducing the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989, which stipulated that all imported vehicles had to meet Australian design rules. It was expected that by enforcing compliance with Australian design rules it would become uneconomic for importers to seek to import used cars. At the time, that expectation was met and the numbers of such used vehicle imports declined dramatically. I should point out that it is still possible to import used vehicles for personal use or in low volume, that is, less than 100 vehicles per year per importer.

Over the last three or four years the automotive industry has been subject to an inquiry by the Industry Commission which reported in December 1990. Based in part on that report, the Government in its March 1991 industry statement announced new arrangements for the car industry essentially reducing levels of assistance. It is significant that, in the Commission's inquiry and in the Government's consideration of the Commission's report, the importation of used vehicles in large volumes was not anticipated, as it had been felt that the requirements of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act had eliminated that possibility.

However, over the last two or three years Taiyo Corporation Pty Ltd has been seeking to import used motor vehicles in large volumes from Japan and was attempting to do so by meeting all requirements of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act and the Australian design rules. Taiyo is almost at the point where compliance could be obtained from the Department of Transport and Communications for the importation of the Mazda 626.

The Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology was concerned about a number of issues raised during the inquiry. However, one point remains fundamental to our consideration of this matter: the Committee agreed that it is necessary for the Government to develop plans, such as the car plan announced as part of the industry statement, and that industry and the community should be able to rely on actions designed to achieve that plan. To the extent that the Government moved to introduce a $12,000 tariff to allow the smooth working of the car plan, the Committee supported the measure.

This fundamental issue became blurred because, when the Government moved in 1989 to restrict imports of used motor vehicles in large volumes through the use of the Australian design rules, it does not appear to the Committee that the motor industry was told of the Government's real intention in direct enough terms. The Government's real intention was to eliminate the importation of used cars in large volumes. This point became significant because companies such as Taiyo, which were observing the letter of the law, attempted to seek compliance for particular used motor vehicle imports and may well have been misled by the Government's approach.

Had tariff protection been adopted in 1989, there may have been less confusion over the importation of used vehicles than is currently the case in the car industry. By majority vote, the Committee recommended that the legislation should be passed in its proposed form. However, I point out that several members have expressed reservations about the recommendation contained in the report. I do not wish to canvass those reservations. No doubt they will deal with this in the debate.

To some extent the reservations of committee members centre on confusion expressed by various sectors of the motor industry as to the reasons for the Government imposing this tariff. These include safety issues and concern for protection of consumers. Indeed, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce canvassed such issues in detail in its response to the Committee. In so doing, it reinforced the confusion of the parties to the debate which attempted to explain, or defend or attack the logic of these issues.

The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) made it clear in his evidence to the Committee—I want to emphasise this—that the importation of used cars in large volumes would, in his opinion, adversely impact on the car plan as agreed between the Government and the industry. For that reason, action had to be taken. The Committee's majority recommendation to support the legislation was based on that decision.

I make my own support for the legislation abundantly clear. We are talking about an industry with 52,000 people, plus 20,000 people in the supporting industries. We are talking about a $2.5 billion investment between 1992 and 1995. That is a significant part of our manufacturing industry. We also are talking about an export industry worth $1.12 billion in 1990-91. This is probably the premier section of Australian manufacturing industries.

Unfortunately, the Opposition has foreshadowed an amendment to be moved at the committee stage which will frighten people in the industry: first of all, those people I have mentioned who are employees of the industry; and secondly, those in the boardrooms. We know that this is one of the industries in which there is overseas control or ownership. We are giving the wrong message to the owners of the car manufacturing companies. We are indicating a lack of faith in an industry which is, in good faith, restructuring its arrangements, management and techniques.

The industry is facing a consistent reduction—probably faster than most other motor companies in the world—in the protection that it has enjoyed over many years. For that reason, the amendment proposed by the Opposition will tell everybody in Australia—every motor worker, every person who gains from the motor vehicle building industry—at least one thing: at the next election there will be a clear choice between this Government, which believes in fostering a modernised vehicle building industry, and the Opposition, which is prepared to play around to score a point by threatening to take away the $12,000 proposal, thus threatening the nature of the motor vehicle building industry as we know it today.

I welcome the Opposition's folly in doing this, because I believe that all those people who directly and indirectly benefit from the vehicle building industry will support this Government and the continuation of the car plan, or the Button plan as it has been named, to credit the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce who has done so much to encourage the modernisation of this industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the three customs tariffs amendment Bills which are being debated cognately by the Senate tonight—the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1992, the Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1992 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1992. I firstly turn to the Customs Tariffs Amendment Bill 1992. This Bill contains a number of measures including provisions to allow motor vehicle component manufacturers to directly use import credits; to allow state-of-the-art capital equipment which is more efficient and more productive than equipment available from Australian manufacturers to be imported duty free; and to allow certain materials to be imported duty free for specific end uses in order to assist the competitiveness of certain Australian industries.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of other provisions, and the Australian Democrats support them. But I wish to specifically address two issues that are presented in this Bill. The first is the insertion of new tender quotas and tender extension rates for the TCF industries. I cannot help wondering at a government that proceeds on this path of destruction for the TCF industries—one of the largest employers in our country and, so far, a very active part of our manufacturing industries—in the same week in which the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) intends to bring down a statement to assist TCF industries.

In the Age of 20 June, Tim Colebatch wrote an article headed `Victoria loses 16% of jobs in manufacturing', which quotes the comments of Mr John Paterson, the director of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, on the number of jobs lost. We now have only 963,900 people working in factories compared with 1,096,800 only two years earlier. To turn specifically to TCF industries, in that time span we have lost 473 clothing factories. I find it absolutely incomprehensible that the Government will continue to proceed along this path of destroying our manufacturing industries.

I would like to advert to the question that I asked Senator Button at Question Time today in order to emphasise that, when we suggest there should be a pause in tariff cuts, we are not suggesting that we should return to across-the-board high protection levels. We are well aware that in past years they have produced lazy management, featherbedded labour and high costs to consumers. What we are suggesting is that we should have a deliberate, planned and strategically assessed industry policy and that we should use a pause in tariff cuts so that we have some industry left on which we can use some strategic thinking. But that does not seem to be included in the Government's thinking or, for that matter, in the Opposition's thinking, because it wants to proceed to zero tariffs within a number of years.

The other issue is the proposed imposition of a $12,000 tariff on second-hand cars. This issue arose because under a plan put forward by the Taiyo Corporation we can now expect to go well beyond the current system which allows 100 units of any one model to be imported by an importer in any one year.

In 1989 a number of companies in Western Australia had begun importing second-hand cars from Japan. These imports stopped when the Motor Vehicle Standards Act required the cars to be modified to meet the safety requirements of the Australian design rules applicable at the time when the cars were manufactured. By April 1989, before the Act came into effect, some 2,000 second-hand Japanese cars a month were coming into Western Australia. In the March 1989 quarter, this represented some 16 per cent of total first registrations. The second-hand car imports are threatening to take off again because one company, Taiyo Corporation, has successfully worked through the process required to get approval under the design rules. Clearly, other companies will follow if the $12,000 tariff is not introduced.

The Australian Democrats will be supporting this Government measure. We simply are not prepared to jeopardise local jobs and the currently fairly finely balanced industry plan by introducing yet another competitor from abroad. The second-hand cars are becoming available at low prices because Japanese authorities make re-registration prohibitive—

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you prefer to import fully manufactured cars?
—I know Senator Panizza does not care about the jobs of workers, but the Democrats do.
—Then why are you for importing fully made-up cars?

—The car industry plan is based on current levels of imports. The Australian car industry is struggling strenuously and somewhat valiantly, perhaps to the Opposition's regret, to become more competitive but at the same time to preserve jobs and to produce cars in Australia rather than to import second-hand cars which have been made redundant in Japan and for which the Opposition wants to make Australia a dumping place.

PARA.TAB: If these cars were allowed to come onto the market here, the small, medium and upper medium segments of Australian based producers would suffer most. Some 30,000 units would be at risk in the small segment, including brand names such as Laser, Corolla and Nova; some 30,000 in the medium range, including Camry, Apollo and Magna; and up to 25,000 in the upper medium segment, including Commodore, Lexcen, Falcon and Verada. It is clear that such losses in market share would affect the viability of production runs and endanger current jobs, future investment and long term employment.

Some other minor points were raised. I say `minor' because I believe they pale into insignificance against the major argument which juxtaposes the admitted consumer benefits of having yet another source of cars on the market and the task of preserving jobs in the Australian car manufacturing and car parts manufacturing industries. The argument was raised that spare parts would be hard to get. I believe that was answered satisfactorily by Taiyo.

Environmental factors were raised that these cars are probably cleaner in environmental terms than some of the second-hand cars which are now on our roads. Of course, that would not be true if they replaced new cars. The influx of the numbers that are forecast clearly would affect new cars—admittedly, both imported—and, perhaps to a larger extent, cars that are manufactured or assembled in Australia.

It is argued by some senators here and by Taiyo that it is spending approximately $2,000 per car more than an importer does. That is true. It is also substantially less than the locally made car. That is what the Australian Democrats are concerned about. We believe, on balance, that the jobs in the factories of Australian car makers and component manufacturers far outweigh the benefits to the consumer and the other concerns that were put forward. The Government's offer to compensate Taiyo Corporation for the initial outlay is a justified offer. I believe that Taiyo Corporation has been led to believe that it would be able to proceed with its plan. I believe that Taiyo is entitled to government compensation. The Australian Democrats will watch carefully the adequacy of that particular compensation.

I now turn to the Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1992. This Bill makes concessional entry more readily available for certain products without affecting the assistance given to industry. The Government claims it will improve the openness, clarity and consistency of the tariff concession system. The Australian Democrats see no problem with this section of the Bill and, therefore, will not be opposing the relevant clauses.

The other main area is the changes to current anti-dumping and countervailing arrangements so that Australian producers are better protected with adequate remedies to unfair trading practices. In particular, there is a reduction of the prima facie hearing stage from 35 to 25 working days and an extension of time from three to five years during which anti-dumping measures and undertakings are to remain in force.

The Australian Democrats are concerned that the proposed changes to current anti-dumping and countervailing arrangements do not go far enough to protect Australian manufacturers from overseas dumping. Consequently, I foreshadow a series of Democrat amendments which aim to level the playing field for Australian manufacturers. I will return to this issue later.

At present, tariff concession orders are made in respect of goods serving similar functions to those produced or capable of being produced by Australian industry in the normal course of business. The objective of the system is to ensure that industry is not taxed by a tariff which serves no protective function. This has the practical effect of lowering input costs so as to improve the international competitiveness of Australian industry. However, since the introduction of the present provisions in this area, there has been growing dissatisfaction with the operation of the system, particularly with the time taken to obtain a concession order and the lack of transparency in the decision making process leading to the grant or refusal of such an order.

The proposed amendments in this Bill aim to make concessional entry more readily available, without affecting the assistance given to industry, and to improve the openness, clarity and consistency of the tariff concession system. As already stated, the Australian Democrats have no real concerns with this area and will not oppose its passage.

I now turn to the amendments that the Australian Democrats will move during the committee stage. Amendments Nos 1 and 4 reduce the prima facie hearing stage from 25 days, as proposed in the Government's amendments, to five days, which is similar to the amendment that the Opposition intends to move. The rationale for this amendment is simply to ensure that Australian industries are assisted with a much faster anti-dumping process so that remedial action can be taken more quickly.

However, we are following that with a number of amendments which are designed to ensure that these five days are capable of being achieved. Amendments Nos 2 and 5 will delete the proposed heavier burden of proof which the Government is seeking to place on the applicant manufacturer, by inserting the word `strictly' before `complies'. Our amendment will make it easier for Australian manufacturers or producers to obtain anti-dumping relief. I am glad to hear that the Opposition is planning to introduce a similar amendment. These two amendments are, therefore, assured of passage.

Amendments Nos 3 and 6 are designed to weaken the burden of proof on the applicant when the comptroller considers an application, so that the comptroller will still be able to make an initial decision within the proposed five days. We believe that this is still in accordance with GATT principles, particularly Article 5(1) of the anti-dumping code. I am somewhat disappointed that the Opposition is not disposed to support us in that. I believe that if we wish—I think justifiably—to reduce the time during which a prima facie hearing is conducted to five days, we must also ensure, by weakening the burden of proof that the Australian manufacturer has to discharge, that the five days can be met.

Amendment No. 7 would impose the same evidentiary requirements on the Australian importer and overseas exporter as already exist for the local manufacturer under sections 269TB and 269TC. At present, the importer and exporter need not give the comptroller relevant information until after the comptroller has made a preliminary finding under section 269DT. This means that both the importer and the exporter can be selective in the preliminary information they give to the comptroller, whereas the local manufacturer cannot do so. This amendment, therefore, gives equal weighting to the evidence provided to the comptroller by all. In other words, it levels the playing field for Australian manufacturers. Once again, I am somewhat disappointed that neither the Government nor the Opposition is disposed to support this amendment which, I would have thought, was a matter of utter necessity for Australian manufacturers at this stage of our industry development.

I would like to address briefly the concept of the prima facie investigation of a dumping claim lodged by a manufacturer. The Minister claims that the Department needs 25 days to investigate the claim to prove that there has been dumping, that it affects similar products or that there is a similar industry in Australia, that the industry suffers damage and that there is a causal connection. In other words, the Minister and his Department are saying that it is not a prima facie case to initiate an inquiry but that the case must be proven. I believe that that is a rewriting of the concept of prima facie.

We should move to a situation—and I believe it can be met within current GATT guidelines—where we can accept evidence from the manufacturer that a particular product is being landed and offered on the Australian market below the price at which it is offered in the country in which it is manufactured. I would have thought that written evidence of a price list from the country of origin and similar evidence of what is happening in the Australian market would be acceptable to establish a prima facie claim. I would have thought that if an industry was in a competitive situation but has against it a product well below the cost at which it was able to market its own product, it would be reasonable to infer that that industry would sustain some damage.

All that Australian manufacturers are asking is that an inquiry be initiated. I would have thought that, once these basic elements are provided by way of information from the manufacturer, the Department should not require any more than five days to do whatever checking it needs to justify the initiation of an inquiry. I know the argument has been advanced that the prospect of an inquiry provides something like a trade chill. So be it. What we are dealing with here is a series of defensive measures on behalf of our manufacturing industry, and I believe it is time that our Government took the side of Australian manufacturers rather than the side of importers and producers in other countries.

I turn briefly to tender dumping, the final issue I wish to raise, and foreshadow that I will be moving a second reading amendment. The Australian Democrats believe that the Government should institute a system of measures directed against tender dumping. This matter is currently being investigated by the Department. The Australian Democrats wholeheartedly recommend the implementation of a tender dumping process similar to that which exists in Canada. I foreshadow that I will move that the Government should institute a system of measures directed against tender dumping, and I understand that amendment will be circulated shortly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1992, the Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1992 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1992. I wish to speak particularly on the issue of imported second-hand Japanese cars. It is with something approaching absolute dismay that I speak about the way the operation of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology took place. I was going to say inquiry, but it was an operation, not an inquiry.

PARA.TAB: As the minority report covers most of the issues, I will not go right through them. However, in the hearing three fundamentals emerged quite early in discussion on and consideration of the The minority report listed these three fundamentals. The first was:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has made an arrangement with the motor vehicle manufacturing industry, known as the Button car plan, that they and the industry expect to operate as planned.
That is one of the fundamentals under which we were operating. The second was:

The Government, the Automotive Industry Authority, the industry, and the Industry Commission ignored or underestimated the potential for imported second hand cars to influence the operation of the plan.

TALK.START.PARA: —We could not find out why this matter was so totally misjudged, overlooked or ignored in the Minister's office, the Department, the Automotive Industry Authority and apparently the Industry Commission. We are required to take this extraordinary step yet nobody could give us any information as to why it had not been dealt with by all the inquiries that had been undertaken, or why it was not even mentioned in the Automotive Industry Authority report, which came out only a month or six weeks ago. We are now taking this extraordinary move to try to clean it up. There must have been some terrible signals from overseas; and there must have been some absolute panic from the Minister's office down.

PARA.TAB: There was plenty of time, room and reason for this matter to have had a proper investigation. But there had been no research, back-up or authenticated estimate. There were no records. Witness after witness could not give us anything. With great respect, I believe that the jelly bean industry would have probably been better resourced than this inquiry found the car industry to be.

The New Zealand question provided us with a lot of spasmodic information which turned out to be completely useless when we challenged and investigated it properly. There had never been a study of the New Zealand situation, despite the fact that that was where the panic really started. We were told the figures would show that we would only have to use a multiplier factor. As I say, that was worthless. According to the evidence that was given to us, nobody had been to New Zealand to check out the information.

We were not told that the average age of Australian cars of about five years has now blown out to eight or nine years, and that 47 per cent of all the cars on the road in Australia are over 10 years old, while New Zealand's cars are getting younger and younger. A whole variety of little matters like that are involved, but I will not go into them now.

It was clear from the lack of information we were given that the whole subject was not up for debate or discussion. If that was the case, the Government should have moved straight in and declared a ban in the first place, and we would have known where we were. But we were told that we could not do that because that is against GATT. I cannot really see that there is any difference between doing something openly and doing it by subterfuge if one wants to achieve the same result.

We were also told that there had been no discussion with the automobile association or the importers; that there had never been any question of voluntary restraint with a view to trying to establish whether there was a market for a number of these sorts of cars and, if so, how many and under what conditions. When giving evidence, there is nothing wrong in the manufacturers saying, `Look, we made an arrangement with the Government and we expect it to carry it through'. The dealers should not be ashamed to say, `Our job is to represent the interests of our members'. I would not hold that against them at all. But no, we could not get that sort of admission. All we got from them was, `Oh, no, we are doing this for the good of the customer because these cars are faulty and this and that'. They could not provide evidence for this. The best story we heard was that we might have trouble getting the manuals in English. That was about the most impressive thing we found.

Records are made to be broken and it was easily the most unimpressive Senate committee hearing I have ever sat on, and I now have sat on quite a few. I regret that the hearing became a bit of a farce because of the handling of the issue by the Government and the groups that were supporting the decision that it had made. I do not blame them for supporting it. It is in their own interests to support it, but the matter should at least be dealt with properly if it is to go before a Senate committee as an inquiry.

The issue of whether imported second-hand cars would or would not compete with new Australian made cars was never clarified by the Government or its supporters. The information varies, but nobody was prepared to come forward and claim that a reasonable proportion—and probably a very substantial proportion—would be competing with second-hand cars. It was intimated to us at one stage, I believe by the manufacturers, that they were expecting approximately 150,000 second-hand cars a year to compete against the new car market. That is just nonsense, particularly as the figure it is based on is quite crazy. There was never any effort made to try to close the difference between the 40,000 cars that the importers believed was possible and the 330,000 cars that somebody dreamt up as a means of frightening the devil out of the industry, the Minister and everybody else.

The Government, the Authority, the industry and the Industry Commission between them provided no information on the total car sales per year that would be involved. We were certainly disappointed that so little information could come forward. We certainly tried to get it. The manufacturing industry certainly is guilty of crying wolf at the time and I think it grossly misled the Government. The Government thought its most inadequate advice had got the better of it, panicked and raced to a conclusion to cover its inadequacies of knowledge and advice. I believe both the manufacturers and the Government will regret this as time goes by.

I fully understand the industry taking advantage of the Government for its own protection. I have no argument against the industry endeavouring to do that any time it likes, but it comes back to the fact that the Committee received grossly inadequate evidence on which it was impossible for a decision to be made. Of course, the issues are very wide and they require more proper research than we had the opportunity to do in the time available to us. Clearly, it has to come back to the Industry Commission, which should produce real evidence and make a recommendation to the Government on which mature and proper decisions can be made. I support the amendment moved by Senator Short.

Those people who are considering this debate should look at the process by which this $12,000 tariff was arrived at. The Senate has already been informed that the Government tried to keep out these imports by imposing new design rules a few years ago. When that did not work it decided to put on a punitive $12,000 tariff.

I have not read the full report of the Senate Standing Committee, but in all of its considerations no-one ever told the Committee—and I will stand corrected—why $12,000 was chosen. It literally doubles the price of these imported cars. I think the same effect would have been achieved with a $10,000 or a $6,000 tariff. I do not think any of the work done by the Department or anyone else really told us why it should be $12,000. PARA.TAB: The Custom Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1992 and the Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1992 relate to changes that the Government has made to our anti-dumping and countervailing laws in response to the Senate inquiry which I initiated on behalf of the coalition in November 1990. Senator Button's Department had an inquiry into our anti-dumping and countervailing laws.

I commend the Government on the changes it has made to our anti-dumping and countervailing laws. They were found necessary by the Senate inquiry in order to make these laws more effective. The Senate inquiry was set up in 1990 to look into our anti-dumping and countervailing laws. Prior to the Senate inquiry's report in June last year, the Government in its March industry statement picked up some of the terms of reference and shortened the time to establish a prima facie case from 55 days to 35 days. I believe that Senator Short will be moving an amendment to reduce that period considerably. The Government extended the period for duties to three years. It extended actions to farmers; it has half done that. In response to the Senate inquiry last December, Senator Button announced further changes which are being introduced in the Bills that are being debated today.

Of particular importance to any Australian industry suffering from the enormous burden of e growth in dumped products—a special aspect in these Bills—is the time limit for a prima facie case, which has been r puced a further 10 days to 25 days. The coalition, supported by the Australian Democrats, will move an amendment to reduce that to five days.

These Bills follow up several of the Senate recommendations which were announced by Senator Button in his ministerial statement last December. Senator Button announced that other Senate inquiry recommendations would be implemented, such as Customs assisting applicants with certain information in the application form. The adoption of the recommendation to extend duties to five years is very welcome. The recommendation of a review prior to the expiry of the duties to see whether the duties should be continued will remove the difficult situation that presently exists where, once duties are lifted, Australian industries have to suffer a further period of material injury and then go through the long and expensive process of providing dumping before new duties are imposed.

However, of concern is the matter of whether anti-dumping and countervailing remedies have been extended to primary producers. Before last year's changes, the action could be brought by the producer of light goods. As most imports are in the process form, it was up to the Australian processor of agricultural goods to bring the action. The March industry statement announced that the Government:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . will help our farmers and manufacturers take effective action against foreign producers who seek to dump theirCroducts on the Australian market at unfair prices.

When the Customs Tariff Act was amended last year, it was generally represented that the effect was to extend anti-dumping remedies to certain primary producers. This was to be done by extending the Act to persons producing raw agricultural goods from which processed goods are produced. However, a lot of uncertainty still remains as to whether anti-dumping actions have been extended to the affected primary producer.

PARA.TAB: In practice, many primary producers are finding themselves in a difficult situation. The application form, as it now stands, requires certain information about the effect of imports on a processor's business. It is information that can only be supplied by a processor. Also, in practice, for any action to be taken, support must be provided for at least 50 of the Australian processors. Yet in reality some processors use dumped imports in their products. Processors also benefit from an unrealistically cheap domestic price which has been forced down by the dumped import.

It is a situation that requires a little flexibility on the part of the Australian authorities. For example, a newcomer to the Australian dumping scene, subsidised Canadian pork, is flooding into Australia at the rate of $1.5m a month. Canada traditionally overproduces by 30 per cent and admits to subsidising its producers at 26c a kilo, or 17.5c of the price received by the Australian pig producer. Australian prices are forced down below the cost of raising pigs, despite our producers being internationally competitive in price and quality. Pork producers are having trouble in bringing anti-dumping action because processors must join with them and fill in a certain part of the application form. Some processors stand to gain if the dumping continues.

The Government has shown concern and consideration when this kind of conflict of interest has arisen between the primary producer and the processor. So it is surprising that this Bill contains an amendment that states that applications must strictly comply with all the paperwork requirements. This area of compliance is always governed by the general principle that evidence required is that which can be reasonably accessed, and the principle that an applicant can only make his best efforts to get data. Therefore, in view of the Government's intention to extend action so closely related to primary producers, considering how flexible its actions have been and in accordance with the well established principle of compliance, it does seem strange that at this stage the Government is moving to insist on strict compliance. I understand that the Democrats will support an amendment which has been moved by Senator Short to remove the word `strictly' from the legislation.

With food imports increasing each year and now being over $2.2 billion a year, and with massive subsidies continuing to distort world prices of agricultural exports leading to dumping, I support the strengthening and quickening of the procedures to enforce anti-dumping and countervailing actions in this I commend the Government for adopting many of the reforms suggested by the Senate inquiry. Due to the time restrictions, I will halt my contribution at this point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Due to the shortage of time for the debate, I will confine my remarks to that part of the Customs Tariff Legislation Bill that concerns the imposition of the $12,000 tariff on imported second-hand Japanese cars. This Bill comes at a time when the Government has the same tariff policy as the coalition—that is, zero tariffs by the year 2000. The policies are the same except on those occasions when the car industry comes to town and scratches Senator Button's back and he rolls over, and except when there is a Wills by-election and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) goes down there and makes his own arrangements.

PARA.TAB: This Bill comes at a time when the Government has told every industry—and I have, too—that it has to compete with the rest of the world. It comes at a time when the agricultural industry has to compete with that of other countries which produce at a much lower cost, and with those countries which make use of subsidies and quota restrictions. It comes at a time when New Zealand and Canada are dumping horticultural products and pig meat in Australia. As Senator Boswell said, it comes at a time when Canadian pork has nearly ruined the Australian pig industry, and continues to do so. It comes at a time when Queensland sugar growers have had their tariffs reduced from $77 to $55 a tonne. I support all of these measures.

But it is different when it comes to the Australian car industry—Senator Button's sacred cow. In 1986 we saw the beginning of the importation of used Japanese cars. In five years, 29,140 cars came in. The car industry saw this as a threat and so it used the non-tariff barrier instead—safety. Of course I support safety and I hope everyone else in this chamber supports safety. In 1989, their imports had to meet with the ADR. Most importers went away but Taiyo of Western Australia met the challenge. Mr Bob Brown said it was designed to provide a level playing field for both local and importing manufacturers. What happened to that, Senator Button?

Taiyo spent $750,000 to meet the challenge for compliance with the Mazda 626 series. The company did everything that was asked including work on lights, brakes and seat belts. The car industry went to Senator Button and he obliged with $12,000 not even ad valorem. There was no IC inquiry, which is mandatory when any industry asks for help. But Senator Button got away with it by four days under the 12-month rule.

Let us explode a few myths about this: first, whether cars have been forced off the road in Japan; second, whether the cars comply with ADR—we have already dealt with that; third, whether in New Zealand the imported cars have decimated its industry; fourth, whether there is a lack of spare parts; and, fifth, what is the number of cars coming into Australia. Let us look at each myth. The first was that the cars were forced off the roads in Japan. In a press release Senator Button said that the Government was not willing to let into Australia cars forced off the road in Japan by tough registration laws which are there to undermine the Australian industry.

What happens in Japan is that, when people buy a new car, they buy a three-year licence for the equivalent of $A650. At the end of that the car is inspected and they pay $800 for two more years, plus new tyres, new brakes and a new battery which cost an extra $600. So it is only an extra $284 a year to license that car in Japan. Can Senator Button and all his advisers who have done nothing tell me how the cars are forced off the road, especially when a new car costs $20,000 to $25,000? It is illogical to say that they have been sent off the road. In the five years they have done only 20,000 kilometres, so what is wrong?

The second myth concerns whether the cars comply with ADR. Of course they do; we have already gone into that. In 1989, the Government amended the Motor Vehicle Standards Act. Senator Cook said in his second reading speech on the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989:

The amendments proposed to the Motor Vehicle Standards Act demonstrate the continuing commitment by the Government to maintaining that a high level of safety is met by all road vehicles supplied to the Australian market for the first time.

The major amendment provides for a proper link between the Act and the Customs Act to ensure that vehicles are not allowed to enter Australia unless they meet the requirements of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act. It ensures that vehicles subject to the Motor Vehicle Standards Act will not be allowed to enter Australia without the specific approval of the Minister administering the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government did not have the guts and determination to come out with the right reason in 1989; it used the non-tariff barrier. That is what happened. When Senator Button was challenged on this matter later on he said that anyone who thought the 1989 amendment on ADR was simply for safety was naive—it was his hidden agenda.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the New Zealand experience: it is claimed that imported cars ruined the New Zealand car industry and reduced new car sales by 25 per cent. Well, in Australia sales went down by 19.7 per cent anyhow without the help of imported cars. However, the true picture is that locally assembled vehicles have dropped from 51,240 to 33,874—a drop of 38 per cent, although fully built new cars increased by 30 per cent. Australian distributors are continually advertising fully imported vehicles. I ask Senator Spindler to tell me where these Australian car manufacturers are being dinkum. They have convinced the Democrats to buy that.

The next myth is the lack of spare parts—what a joke. Mazda Australia cannot supply parts from the shelf for vehicles that are three years old. One may talk about Taiyo not being able to supply new parts for the vehicles it sells, but Mazda cannot supply parts for the 1988 model. Anyhow, Australian manufacturers only guarantee to have parts available for five years—but not off the shelf; delivery takes three or four days. Taiyo promises delivery within 48 hours.

The figure of one million has been bandied about as the number of second-hand cars that will come into Australia in three years—in other words, 333,000 per year. What a joke! The biggest seller of second-hand cars in Perth sells 4,800 per year. That is a lot of extra cars. The whole show is a fiasco. It makes a mockery of the Government's tariff reform policy. The Government should be consistent; it is guilty on its own admission.

Perhaps the Democrats could still look at where their support lies. Senator Sowada gives us every reason in her minority report why we should vote against this legislation. She has told the newspapers that she is going to vote against it. I give her credit that she is a Democrat with a bit of hope and a bit of sense. All the reasons are in this minority report. So I urge her not to listen to what the Government has to say, to vote with us and bring the rest of the crew with her.

We have been told that the cost of these cars in Japan is minimal. As I said earlier, in Japan cars such as these are not forced off the road. I think even Senator Short was a bit misguided. It costs only an extra $254 to keep one of these cars on the road in Japan. So there is no way anyone can say that these cars are forced off the road.

I have some figures for what Taiyo may be paying for these cars in Japan. The cost of a used Capella or a Mazda 626 f.o.b. Japan is $2,200. The freight is $1,000. Import duty of 35 per cent and wholesale tax of 15 per cent adds $1,300 to the cost of this car. Work carried out in Australia—for example, on brakes, lights, tyres and whatever is needed—which puts it in a far better condition than any five-year-old Australian car that comes through the yards, adds up to $3,000. The total is $7,500. I know that Senator Button does not want to listen to this, but that adds up to a selling price of $10,000 to $13,000.

If Senator Button had thought the Australian car industry needed protection, he would have looked, without getting advice from anyone else—and I presume that he did not ask for advice, otherwise he would have come up with something that was not ad valorem—

TALK.START.PARA: —They just changed the rules after the game had started.

—That is right. That is what the Government did; it changed the rules. He could have looked at a far lower figure. By adding the $12,000, the Government's costing comes to $19,500 on that car. The selling price is $12,000 to $13,000, so the transaction is negative and the seller is gone. Mr Crean, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in the other place, is always telling us about the value adding prospect in Australia. To have value adding, Australian firms have to be willing to take a punt and go into business. I am not a full advocate for Taiyo in Western Australia, but I can assure—
—Not much.
—I assure Senator Button that those principals have been in business since at least the late 1940s in other ways.
—They know the car industry backwards; that's the problem.

—They were not in the motor car business; they were in the bulldozer repairing industry, actually, when I first knew them in the late 1950s. We have people like this willing to put their own dollar on the line, not the Government's dollar or anyone else's dollar. It is a private company, so it puts its own dollar on the market. So what do we do? The Government changes the rules, turns around and slaps on this tariff so that it has to shut down.

PARA.TAB: Senator Button is guilty by his own actions since then. What did he do after closing Taiyo down? He offered the company compensation—he is not saying a word; he is silent—by letting in 400 cars to settle things down and hopefully to make up for what it spent. If I had spent $1m setting up a business and someone wanted to shut me down and buy me out so that I did not annoy them or provide competition, I would expect to make a profit on what I had put in. You do not build up a business just to get your costs back. You do not build up a farm as my father did—he passed it on to me and my brothers—just to get the cost back. Hopefully, you produce, and produce for Australia.

But, no, just close it down.If the Minister was going to close Taiyo down by offering compensation, one would have thought he would offer it a figure by which it would make a profit. Obviously there was going to be a profit; it employs people, and manufactures and imports parts for these vehicles. One would think that the Minister would give it compensation. But no, he just told it that he would give it back the money it had spent and shut the door. Senator Spindler, who has a mortgage on the conscience of Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —More than you've got.

—I will ignore that comment. I could probably have it withdrawn, but I will ignore it. I do not pretend to be a champion of the downtrodden and drive a Volvo. I do not think I will worry about that. If Senator Spindler wants to be recognised as a champion of the downtrodden he should at least act as though he is. The point is that Senator Spindler is going to sit here in judgment tonight. He said that he would make sure the Government would compensate Taiyo. What a hypocrite! In the meantime, he will shut it down and take off millions of dollars of profit that it might have made in the years to come. Now he thinks that he will win back its support by making sure that the Government pays compensation. God, he is hopeless! That is the situation that the Democrats and the Government are in.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at a few registration figures that Senator Archer passed me earlier. I thank him for that. In 1991-92 the number of new Australian vehicles produced was 208,900 and a total of 325,600 vehicles were registered. In 1991 local production was 70.5 per cent of registration. In 1991-92 local production went down to 64.2 per cent of registration, and Nissan still has to go. There is this great car plan of Senator Button and this Government, and Nissan is going.

TALK.START.PARA: —Precisely.

—I am glad that Senator Button agrees with me. The percentage of registrations in Australia is going down. What are we doing? We must be importing new cars; we are not allowed to import second-hand cars. Someone in Australia started a business to import second-hand cars, but we cannot do that. The car manufacturers scratch Senator Button's back every now and then and plug fully imported cars. There is nothing at all wrong with fully imported cars, but why promote them? Mazda had a good run with its 626. This crowd was importing second-hand Mazda 626s. If Mazda or anyone else wanted to be dinkum about it, they would promote Australian manufactured or assembled cars. But no. That is where the whole legislation is a fiasco.

PARA.TAB: This Bill has come at a very bad time. At the outset, I said that we are telling everyone in Australia that they have to compete internationally. Wheat farmers have been belted about the ears by the United States subsidy scheme and the EC subsidy. They are getting it good and proper. I have already mentioned the Canadian pig meat which is ruining pig producers in Australia. The sugar industry still has some sort of a tariff and it has to compete. But when it comes to the car industry it is vastly different. For all the reasons that I have outlined, this legislation needs to be looked at a second time. I ask Senator Sowada to try to talk some sense into Senator Spindler—the Volvo driving champion of the downtrodden. I appeal to the Democrats to think again and support us on this matter. We expect everyone else in this country to compete in the world. Jobs are being lost left, right and centre because of the way the Government has run the economy for the past 10 years. Why should the car industry not compete in the same way?

The myths that are being thrown around about second-hand Japanese cars are worthless. These cars are thrown off the roads in Japan because of the licensing laws. I have already told the Senate that it costs only $284 per year to keep those cars on the road in Japan. As I have said, they have done only 30,000 kilometres. I believe that the average age of an Australian car is 9.7 years. A five-year-old Japanese car could double its life and still be inside the average age of an Australian car.

Would the Minister tell us why he was not game to send this matter out to an Industry Commission inquiry instead of hiding under the last one that he got in by four days? I would like to hear his answer. I think an inquiry would have shown that he was completely wrong in going ahead this way without referring the matter to an IC inquiry.

That is the situation. Australian people—whether young or old, undergraduates or graduates—who may have been in a position to buy cars, who could have bought reasonable cars at reasonable prices, cars which had done only 30,000 kilometres, were denied that opportunity by the Minister.
