TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise some important questions tonight in relation to Senator Cook's press release about the TAAATS inquiry mark II. At something after twelve o'clock at night, I do not propose to go through the history of how the Parliament got into the position of demanding an independent inquiry, but at the heart of the matter is the action of the Civil Aviation Authority. It has not followed accepted tendering procedures and, furthermore, it has failed to explain how it arrived at the decisions that it has arrived at when it has been given every opportunity to do so.

PARA.TAB: The matter came to a head when the CAA virtually asked for an open cheque from the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works when the Committee was inquiring into a request from the Civil Aviation Authority to underwrite roughly $50m worth of a civil works program in relation to the TAAATS contract. That led the Chairman of the Public Works Committee, Mr Hollis, to say in a report to another place on 3 June that these concerns include the following:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . whether the Thomson equipment is the best available; whether the selection process conducted by the CAA was doctored to favour the Thomson bid; and why the preference of the technical and operational evaluation teams for Hughes was overturned.

Instead of doing what the Parliament wanted the Government to do, the Government turned to the Civil Aviation Authority to investigate itself. That was very like saying to a prisoner in the cell, `You can pick the judge, you can pick the jury, you can pick the prosecuting counsel and then you can write the charge you want to be charged with'.

PARA.TAB: The CAA did just that: it picked the chairman and it picked the consultants or advisers—one of whom, in one of the principal technical roles, was a Swedish company called Swedavia. Swedavia was in no sense an arm's length adviser. It has a long and proven history of association with Mr Baldwin, Mr Edwards and Thomson CSF in New Zealand. From there, it went on to write the terms of reference. The terms of reference of the first inquiry stated:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)Was the selection process soundly based—
the answer to that is yes—
(b)Was the process conducted in a fair and unbiased manner including:
.What was the basis of changes, if any, to project objectives, Registration of Interest (ROI) requirements or evaluation procedures (including evaluation criteria and delivery schedule)?

.Were any changes made to project objectives, Registration of Interest (ROI) requirements or evaluation procedures (including evaluation criteria and delivery schedule) to favour or disadvantage any Company—
the answer to that would be no—
.Was there any disclosure of information by the CAA which had the effect of favouring or disadvantaging any Company or which contravened commercial-in-confidence undertakings given to the Companies—
the answer to that would be no—
.Were the results of the operational, financial and technical evaluations treated in accordance with the evaluation procedures laid down and were these evaluations properly taken into account—
the answer to that would be yes—
(c) Was the Board properly and adequately informed of the results of the evaluation in a fair and unbiased manner—
again the answer to that would be yes—
(d) Were the actions of the CAA Board on this matter in accordance with its obligations—
of course, that would be yes.

PARA.TAB: Two things happened after that first inquiry. The first was that the person nominated as chairman, Mr Brazil, declared that he had a conflict of interest and quite properly withdrew as chairman of the selection process. I would like to quote from the relevant part of the letter tabled by Senator Cook in the Senate last week where Mr Brazil withdraws. He says in relation to his withdrawal:

SPEECH.PARA: This is based both on professional requirements, and a concern that the proposed inquiry be free from any appearance of anything less than being fully fair and impartial. Personally, I was honoured by the request to chair the inquiry, and regret that this is no longer feasible.

That was a quite proper action for Mr Brazil to take. The second thing that happened was that there was a public outcry at the CAA sitting in judgment of itself. That led to the mark II inquiry that was the subject of a press release yesterday from Senator Cook setting out slightly modified terms of an inquiry. That is why I seek the time of the Senate tonight.

PARA.TAB: I am not here to argue about who the chairman should be. I think it is a great irrelevance to argue who the chairman might or might not be. My concern, and the concern of the Parliament, is that there be an independent inquiry set up. If Senator Cook can achieve an independent inquiry working through the CAA, he has my full support on it. But at the moment the portents for that to come about are not very favourable.

It is essential that we have an independent inquiry because it is the only way the Civil Aviation Authority can clear its name. It is the only way the board and the management can clear their names. I am surprised that someone like Mr Bosch cannot see that. Mr Bosch, I learned from Senator Cook's press release, is now the acting chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority. This is the same Mr Bosch who has gone around Australia for many years lecturing Australian business on morality and accountability on the boards of companies. We now have the opportunity for Mr Bosch to apply the ethical and correct principles that he has tried to instil in Australian business in the last decade into the actions of the Civil Aviation Authority. Unless we have an independent inquiry, the board of the CAA and the management will not be able to clear their own names of any allegations of impropriety which might or might not have taken place.
I want to deal with the questions that arise from the press release issued by Senator Cook yesterday. I quote from the fourth paragraph first of all. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Macphee—
who is the nominated chairman—
as a first step will satisfy himself that the Terms of Reference are comprehensive enough to enable the Review to address all of the concerns which have been raised about the project.

What Senator Cook is saying, I take it, is that Mr Macphee, or whoever the chairman might be, will satisfy himself that the terms of reference are broad enough to cover anything in relation to the selection of Thomson as the preferred tenderer.

PARA.TAB: The first point that becomes apparent is that it will need time. For anyone who is not familiar with the subject, who has not been reading and does not know the tortuous path that has been followed over the last 18 months in relation to this contract, I think it would take at least three to four weeks of solid reading—there is at least a week in the Public Works Committee Hansards to be got through—before one could make one's mind up as to what the correct terms of reference should be. That leads me to ask Senator Cook: if the terms of reference can be changed by the chairman, can they be changed once the inquiry gets under way? If they cannot be changed then, why not just give the inquiry open slather to look at all aspects of the selection program? That is exactly what Mr Hollis was saying when he presented the report of the Public Works Committee to the Parliament. The next paragraph of the press release says:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Macphee will also choose the specialist advisers with the necessary technical and financial skills. He will draw on whatever advice he considers appropriate in their selection.

The choosing of the specialist advisers, both in a technical sense and in a legal sense, is absolutely crucial to the workings of this committee. The standard that needs to be applied is the standard laid down by Mr Brazil himself in his letter of resignation as the first nominated chairman that `anything less than being fully fair and impartial' will not be acceptable.

PARA.TAB: It is possible to get advisers who are impartial, despite what Senator Cook told the Senate last week. From my own experience, I have been phoned up by several Australian companies in the field appropriate to assess air traffic control systems and they have offered their services to me. I have had phone calls from a number of individual consultants in the air traffic control field and from legal tender evaluation people. I have even had a phone call from someone from Canada. So the people are around, and I know from other sources that there are numerous people in the United States and in the United Kingdom who could act as independent consultants who have the technical and professional skills and the established professional integrity to operate in these fields. So those people are about. It is most important that the inquiry is not saddled with nominees by the Civil Aviation Authority. The third point in Senator Cook's press release relates to time. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that the Chairman be satisfied that the Review has been given the necessary time to carry out its duties and finalise its report.

When the first version of this inquiry was brought out, the CAA decided that six weeks would be an adequate period in which to hold the inquiry. Such a proposition is quite ludicrous. I would not think an inquiry into the selection process could be held in much under three months, and it may well run considerably longer. I fully endorse the statement of Senator Cook that the chairman will be the person who makes the determination on the amount of time required for the report. The fourth point is a most important one. Two further paragraphs down, the press release states:

However, it will be a matter for the Review alone to determine the procedures under which it will operate and to ensure that there are arrangements in place which will respect necessary confidentiality of individuals and organisations making submissions during the Review's proceedings.

I do not think there is another aspect in the press release which is more important than that. Senator Cook is limited in the powers that he can confer on the chairman with respect to the confidentiality of individuals and organisations and, most importantly, with the protection he can offer witnesses. It is absolutely crucial to the findings and the workings of this committee that protection for witnesses is provided. It is the usual practice of this Parliament when we have an inquiry to grant the committee the powers to summon documents, to summon witnesses and to grant privilege to witnesses appearing and giving evidence before that committee.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook cannot confer those powers on the chairman of the committee. To do that basically requires some legislation to be passed through this Parliament conferring powers similar to those of a royal commissioner. I do not see any sign at the present time of any legislation being introduced this week to create a committee of inquiry with those powers. If those powers are not conferred, I think the committee is going to get nowhere. The only other way it could be done would be by setting up a parliamentary committee.

We need to provide protection for witnesses; the actions of Mr Baldwin and Dr Edwards make it crucial. They make it crucial on two grounds. The first is in respect of the documentation. There is a known history of non-cooperation and evasion by the management of the CAA where evidence is trying to be collected. We have only to look at the long histories of the Hansard of the Public Works Committee hearings of the last two months to see that the CAA is simply not prepared to cooperate with the Parliament in providing evidence that the Parliament is properly entitled to collect. We have to look at the Senate Estimates committees, where again we get no cooperation at all from the CAA on the provision of essential evidence.

As recently as a couple of weeks ago when the Appropriation Bills were passed through this chamber we had obdurate non-cooperation from Edwards and Baldwin on essential information in relation to this TAAATS contract. Unless the chairman of the committee has the power to compel the attendance of people and to compel the production of documents, essential information will not be provided.

Another reason, apart from the documentary one, is for the protection of the individuals themselves. Both Dr Edwards and Mr Baldwin have a history of suing for libel. Last week someone in New Zealand telephoned me in my office and, amongst other things, told me that he was the subject of a libel action taken against him by those two people. There are allegations in the press gallery that Mr Tom Burton, a journalist with the Sydney Morning Herald, and the Sydney Morning Herald have been the subject of a heavy writ. Furthermore, it is alleged that the CAA board has agreed to underwrite the costs of any legal action taken by Baldwin and Edwards in this matter.

If that is true, it is quite extraordinary. It is one thing for an employer to help an employee by providing financial support if that employee is the subject of a legal action, but it is a totally different matter for a public servant to use taxpayers' funds to pursue a private citizen. I made a reference once to the actions of the Civil Aviation Authority being conducted along the lines of a Third World country. To allow an employee of the Civil Aviation Authority to pursue a third party in a libel action with taxpayers' money—if that is true—is another Third World practice. The upshot of this is that protection must be provided to the witnesses if people are to stand up and say something.

While I am on the subject of New Zealand, I have had sent to me in the mail a cutting from a publication called Aviation News: New Zealand's National Aviation Newspaper. The first paragraph of an article in that publication says:

New Zealand and Australian members of Parliament have agreed to swap findings on separate investigations going on in both countries concerning multi million dollar tenders for calibration work and radar installation. Centre of the investigations are ex-NZ Airways Corporation principles Frank Baldwin and Rob Edwards, both now working for the Australian Civil Aviation Authority (CAA).

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know anything about that, but it is unusual that senior Australian public servants should be the subject of a major inquiry in the Parliament of another country.

PARA.TAB: The final point I make is that the contract negotiations which are currently taking place between the preferred tenderer, Thomson, and the Civil Aviation Authority should cease while the inquiry is going on. Thomson is blackmailing the CAA by saying, `If you don't proceed with this, the introduction of the new air traffic control systems in Sydney and Brisbane will be deferred for years and you will have a major political issue on your hands, and probably a safety issue as well'.

The facts of the matter are that the equipment at Brisbane and Sydney is old Thomson equipment that has been installed for about 30 years. Thomson has contracted to support that equipment with spare parts until about 1995, so there is a little leeway between 1992 and the expiration of that support program. Most importantly, an emergency kit can be moved in by a whole range of companies if Thomson cannot do it. Companies like Siemens, Hughes, IBM and Raytheon can certainly move in emergency air traffic control procedures to see us through in a short term crisis. There should be no pressure at all to carry on the contract negotiations while the inquiry into the selection of the preferred tenderer is taking place. I would be very grateful if the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Cook, would answer those questions in the Parliament within the next 24 hours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words about the matter that Senator MacGibbon has raised tonight. Firstly, I congratulate Senator Cook, as the Minister responsible for the Civil Aviation Authority, for announcing yesterday the appointment of Mr Ian Macphee to chair the independent inquiry into the letting of the contract for air traffic control, as described by Senator MacGibbon.

PARA.TAB: Senator MacGibbon is well known in this place for having raised this issue in the Estimates Committee and with other members of parliament over many months. I have been lobbied by the contractors, as I suppose he has. Representatives of AWA, which is a part of the Hughes consortium, and representatives of Thomson-CSF have come to see me in recent times to outline their cases on this issue. I do not believe it is appropriate for members of parliament to try to be technical experts and to pick between Thomson-CSF, one of the major tenderers, and the Hughes Corporation, the other major tenderer. We may be expert amateurs, but we are all amateurs. I think that if we start trying to argue the technical merits we will find ourselves getting into a fair bit of strife.

In the past five years that I have been a member of this place, I have had briefings from Thomson on other contracts it has bid for, some of which have been based in South Australia. As well, I have received briefings from AWA. My interest is because they have been based in South Australia, and employment opportunities and the development of high-tech industry in South Australia are things I support strongly.

Some of these queries and matters of controversy have been raised in recent times. Several weeks ago I took the trouble to get hold of the Hansards of this place to see all the questions that have been asked by members opposite. I am not a member of the appropriate Estimates Committee, but I read the Hansards of the Committee hearings in which many questions were asked on this matter earlier this year. I sat down and laboriously read the transcripts of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works on this contract. After several hours of reading, I became concerned that the processes of the CAA in letting the contract for this large capital expenditure for air traffic control were, to quote Tom Burton from one of his articles in the Sydney Morning Herald, `rather odd'.

I have been an observer and have asked questions and been briefed in the Department of Defence where it has let contracts of a measurably larger size than in the air traffic control area. The Defence Department has let the Anzac frigate contract, which was worth $5 billion or $6 billion, and the submarine contract, which was worth $4 billion or $5 billion. In those contracts there were big winners and big losers. In all of those contracts, the losers, despite some initial disappointment and a few comments that they thought they had been hard done by, basically accepted the decision. However, in this case, when the contract was finally let in March this year to Thomson-CSF, there was such an outcry from across the industry about the way the process was conducted that it seemed to me that there was a real reason for a review of the way this contract was let.

I do not think anyone who reads the Public Works Standing Committee transcripts would be other than unimpressed by the performance of the senior officers of the CAA, Mr Baldwin and Dr Edwards, in their inability to answer quite reasonable questions to the statutory authority responsible for approving these sorts of expenditures—that is, the Public Works Standing Committee.

Some time ago there was a debate about whether under commercialisation such authorities as the Civil Aviation Authority should have themselves removed from the surveillance or the overseeing of the Public Works Standing Committee. This recent episode proves a very strong case for why the Public Works Standing Committee of this Parliament should maintain some surveillance of major contracts of bodies such as the CAA, even though it has a commercial obligation and a commercial charter.

It seems to me that, if it had not been for the Public Works Standing Committee's ability to ask the questions and call for evidence, we probably would not have got a review. I think the members of that Committee, particularly Mr Hollis, the Chairman, are to be congratulated for not putting up with some of the obfuscation that had come from senior officers of the CAA.

To me, the most fundamental issue about this whole process is to ensure that any government department or authority has an open, transparent set of rules about the way it lets contracts. I understand that in the Defence Department those rules have been rigorously adhered to. There are always winners and there are always losers. But, if one loses in a decent tendering process, one has only oneself to blame for not being good enough.

It seems to me that, with the apparent lack of transparency, the clear-cut rules by which this contract was let and the process adopted, we could not have confidence that all reasonableness was adopted and all fairness was applied to all tenderers. As a result, Thomson-CSF, as a major tenderer, has copped a bit of flak that it probably does not deserve. The process the CAA adopted for letting the tender gave rise to suspicions on the part of some people that Thomson-CSF was getting an inside running for its own advantage. That may be the case; it may not be. But I suspect—and I told this to Thomson-CSF officials when they came to see me—that its reputation has been unduly affected because of the way in which the CAA went about letting the tender. All of that is on the record in the transcripts of the Public Works Standing Committee. Of course, a couple of those hearings were held in camera, and the transcripts are not available to other members of the Parliament who are not members of the Public Works Standing Committee.

I believe that Mr Ian Macphee, a former senior Minister in a former government of this Parliament, a longstanding member of this Parliament and a representative of an employer organisation in Victoria before he came into the Parliament, is a person who has a good range of commonsense experience. Although he may not have all the technical requirements and expertise that Senator MacGibbon would like, he certainly has the experience in government and parliament to be able to make a proper investigation and ask the decent questions.

If Senator MacGibbon's concerns are realised in relation to witnesses being afraid of giving evidence or information to him because they do not have parliamentary privilege or protection as in a court, I am sure that Mr Macphee, in carrying out his duties, will report that to the Minister. If he finds that the technical advice that he is getting is inadequate, I am sure he will make the appropriate request to the Minister.

In relation to the concerns that Senator MacGibbon raises, we ought to see how things develop before we jump to the conclusion that Mr Macphee is not able to conduct a decent inquiry. I am confident that if the obstacles that Senator MacGibbon has outlined tonight arise, Mr Macphee, with all

SPEECH.PARA: his political experience as both a Minister and member of parliament and with his experience in industry, will be making a request to the Minister for an adjustment to his terms of reference to give him the appropriate powers to investigate all aspects of this particular tender.

PARA.TAB: I hope that at the end of the day we can establish for the CAA a set of rules and procedures for letting major tenders that advantage the CAA but, above all else, advantage the Australian taxpayer, and that we have an open, transparent and firm set of rules which gives confidence to people all around Australia and the world to tender openly for contracts, knowing that they have a reasonable chance in an open competition to win that tender. Once that is established, the CAA will be able to provide to the Australian public a very decent air safety regime in this country that we all want.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 5 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the outcome of the inquiry into the incident in March 1992 in Western Australia relating to a BAE 146 passenger jet which lost power while in flight, probably due to icing.

(2) Why has an altitude limit of 28,000 feet been placed on aircraft of this type flying in Australia, particularly when it is understood that the manufacturers, British Aerospace, suggest an altitude limit of 31,000 feet.
(3) Why has the Australian Civil Aviation Authority placed a higher ceiling limit than the 25,000 limit which civil aviation authorities in the United Kingdom have decided for the BAE 146 jet.
(4) What on-going monitoring and investigation is continuing in Australia and elsewhere into the operating safety of this aircraft type.
(5) Are any modifications to the BAE 146 proposed.

(6) Can the Minister assure the Parliament that subject to the ceiling limit being observed, the BAE 146 is safe and that passengers may have every confidence that the factors causing the incident in March 1992 will not be repeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation inquiry phase has been completed, but continuing research is being undertaken and this will delay the publication of the final report. At this stage the Bureau cannot predict when the report will be finalised, but it is expected that the various interested parties will be provided with a draft report during July 1992.

The actual incident appears to have been triggered by a meteorological phenomenon, which resulted in a very unusual temperature variation. Effectively, the outside air temperature rapidly increased and the engines suffered a power decrease, commonly referred to as a "roll-back". It appears that the engines may then have been affected by icing conditions which delayed the recovery process until the aircraft had descended through the icing level.

(2) The altitude limitation of 28 000 feet in non-icing conditions was imposed by the CAA on Australian operated BAE 146 aircraft as a precautionary action, pending investigation of the Western Australian incident. The basis of the limitation was that none of the known multiple engine power loss events world-wide, including the Western Australian incident, had occurred below an altitude of 28,000 feet.

This limitation has now been relaxed to permit day operations in non-icing conditions up to 31,000 feet, in line with the manufacturer's suggested limitation. The altitude limitation of 28,000 feet in non-icing conditions has been retained for night operations at this time, but will be reviewed as further information is received from manufacturers on the engine power loss problem.

(3) The 28,000 feet limitation introduced by the Australian CAA applies to operations in non-icing conditions, whereas the altitude limitation of 25,000 feet introduced by the UK CAA, which has also been imposed by the Australian CAA on Australian operated BAE 146 aircraft, applies to operations in known or forecast icing conditions.

(4) The Australian CAA was briefed in Canberra, on 5 May, by a team from the BAE 146 aircraft and engine manufacturers on the current status of their investigations into the engine power loss problem and recommended corrective actions. The team also presented details of their continuing action plan and gave assurance that the Australian Authority would be kept informed as the plan progressed. Dialogue is also continuing between the Australian CAA and the regulatory authorities of the UK, USA and New Zealand, as well as the Australian operators of the BAE 146 aircraft.

(5) Details of modifications to BAE 146 aircraft engines and engine fuel control units, recommended as corrective action for the power loss problem, were given by the manufacturer's team at the Canberra meeting in May. The Australian CAA has requested further substantiation of the recommended corrective modifications.

(6) The Australian CAA considers the BAE 146 aircraft to be safe and that the altitude limitations currently imposed on Australian operated BAE 146 aircraft, in particular the limitation of 25 000 feet in known or forecast icing conditions, will prevent the occurrence of an engine power loss incident similar to the Western Australian event.
